FIGREF13.text: Uterine Bleeding Due to Immature Vascularization. M Basar, UA Kayisli, N Semerci, H Atkinson, T Summerfield, O Guzeloglu-Kayisli, JS Huang, J Shapiro, F Schatz, CJ Lockwood. Obstetrics and Gynecology, College of Medicine, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA. INTRODUCTION:Long-acting progestin only contraceptives (LAPCs)associated abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) occurs intermittently and focally from irregularly distributed superficial, enlarged, thin-walled capillaries and venules. The cellular mechanisms of these irregular changes are unknown with the exception of abnormal angiogenesis. Vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) maintain vascular tone. We hypothesize that LAPC suppressed VSMC proliferation and differentiation produce thin-walled and hyperdilated vasculature. METHODS: Cultured VSMCs were processed for whole genome gene microarray analyses using Illumina Human microarray kit and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis. In vitro effects of LAPCs medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA, 10 -7 M), and etonogestrel (ETO, 10 -7 M) were investigated on VSMC proliferation using BrdU incorporation. PCNA and a-SMA double-labeling immunohistochemistry assessed in vivo differentiation and proliferation of VSMC in paired-endometrial tissues from women preand post-DepoProvera (depo) use (n=6) and in endometrium from guinea pigs (GPs) treated with vehicle (n=3) or MPA (n=3) pellets for 49 days and from oophorectomized-(OVX-) GPs treated with E2 (n=6) or E2+MPA (n=6) pellets for 21 days. Relevant statistical analyses were performed. RESULTS: Endometrial vasculature in women post-Depo administration revealed fewer a-SMA positive cells and decreased PCNA immunoreactivity among a-SMA cells. Microarray analyses revealed several genes that were altered by MPA or ETO, including increased TMEM119, which suppresses myoblast differentiation and decreased RARRES1, which induces proliferation. VSMCs treated with MPA or ETO displayed reduced BrdU incorporation (p<0.01). Fewer PCNA (+) endometrial VSMCs were present in MPA treated GPs determined by a-SMA double-staining vs vehicle treated GPs (p<0.05). Similarly, fewer PCNA (+) endometrial VSMCs were present in E2+MPA-treated OVX-GPs vs E2-treated OVX-GPs (p<0.01). CONCLUSIONS: LACP mediated inhibition of endometrial VSMC differentiation, proliferation and/or migration results in insufficient VSMCs to cover and control tone of newly formed vessels. The resulting generation of naked, hyperdilated, thin-walled vessels explains AUB in the endometrium of LACP users.T-261A Sixth Sense: Does Subjective Assessment of Menstrual Bleeding Correlate with Measures of Anemia amongst African American Women (AAW)? Lia A Bernardi, Marissa S Ghant, Carolina Andrade, Hannah Recht, Erica E Marsh. FIGREF15.text: Expression Profile of the Lgr5 Cell Population in the Human Endometrium. Oriana Genolet*, 1 Irene Cervello*, 1 Claudia Gil-Sanchis, 1 Aymara Mas, 1 Amparo Faus, 1 Juan M Moreno, 1 Juan A Martinez-Conejero, 2 Carlos Simon. 1,2 1 Endometrial Stem Cell Research, Fundacion IVI-Instituto Universitario IVI-University of Valencia, Valencia, Spain; 2 IVIOMICS, IVIOMICS, Valencia, Spain.INTRODUCTION: Lgr5 (Leucine-rich repeat-containing G-proteincoupled receptor 5) is a universal stem cell marker for endodermal and ectodermal stem cell niches such as small intestine and skin respectively. Our objective is to investigate whether Lgr5 is also a marker for a mesoderm niche such as the human endometrium and to perform wide genome analysis of endometrial Lgr5+ cells to identify gene signature and surrogate candidate markers for endometrial somatic stem cells (SSC). METHODS: Human endometrial biopsies (n=12) were obtained after patient's written informed consent. Cells were stained with Rabbit Anti-GPR49/LGR5 (Novus Biologicals) and a secondary FITC-coupled antibody (Life Technologies). The Lgr5 population was isolated via cell sorting (MoFlo, Dako). Lgr5 + cells from both fractions were hybridized on the Human GE 4x44K v2 Microarray (Agilent Technologies). Data was analyzed by the GenePix Pro 6.0 software (Molecular Devices) and results were validated via RT-PCR analysis. R E S U LT S : E n d o m e t r i a l L g r 5 c e l l s w e r e l o c a l i z e d b y immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization in specific regions of the epithelial glands and the perivascular stromal compartment. The percentages of Lgr5 isolated cells ranged between 0.92 ± 0.67 % in the epithelial and 0.62 ± 0.18 % in the stromal fractions, regardless of the phase of the menstrual cycle. Wide genome analysis of these cells revealed the existence of 604 up-and 59 down-regulated genes in the Lgr5+ stromal fraction and 479 up-and 554 down-regulated genes in the epithelial, among others the top three up-regulated genes were shared by Lgr5+ cells from both compartments: IL1B, C1QB and CSF1R.

FIGREF16.text: RESULTS: SP induced transcriptomic changes associated with leukocyte and endothelial cell recruitment and proliferation of eEC and eSF. Pathways associated with cell viability were increased, while those associated with cell death were decreased (P<0.05). Analysis of conditioned media revealed that SP induced secretion of pro-inflammatory and pro-chemotactic cytokines, as well as pro-angiogenic and proliferative growth factors (P<0.05). Conditioned media from SP-treated cells significantly increased (P<0.05) chemotaxis of CD14+ monocytes and CD4+ T cells. Exposure to fresh semen induced similar sets of pathways in eEC and eSF. CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that SP induces pathways associated with promoting immune cell recruitment and viability of eEC, eSF, and potentially other endometrial cells. Furthermore, SP and fresh semen induce similar sets of genes and related pathways, validating the use of SP to understand the effects of semen on the female reproductive tract. FIGREF17.text: used to collect gestational tissues 8 hrs after intrauterine injection on day 14.5 of pregnancy with either control medium or peptidoglycan (PGN, a toll-like receptor (TLR) 2 agonist) plus polyinosinic:cytidylic acid (poly(I:C), a TLR3 agonist), modeling Gram positive bacterial and viral infections, respectively. Western blot analysis and immunohistochemistry were performed for various chaperones and LAMP2. RESULTS: PGN+poly(I:C)-treatment led to decreased expression of chaperones Hsp90, Hsp60 and Hsp25, and decreased lysosome marker Lamp2A in uterus and placenta, and increased cell death in uterus and placenta. CONCLUSIONS: PGN+poly(I:C) treatment leading to preterm delivery may interfere with the normal progression of CMA and lysosome function in uterus and placenta by decreasing tissue levels of LAMP2A and Hsp90. This effect may be augmented by interference with normal protein folding and removal of damaged proteins caused by decreased expression of Hsp60 and Hsp25. Restoration of normal CMA function might be a useful therapeutic target for treatment of preterm labor.

The aim of the study was to determine the concentration and the prognostic value of selected chemokines in sera of patients with premature birth without clinical signs of infection, and compare them with a group of women with false preterm labor.METHODS:The study group consisted of 128 patients: 76 patients with preterm birth (24-36 weeks) and 52 patients with false preterm birth. To assess the concentration of chemokines in the blood serum we used a multiplex method based on traditional sandwich ELISA which allows the simultaneous determination of 40 chemokines per sample. The sets consist of the following chemokines: 6Ckine, Axl, BTC, CCL28, CTACK, CXCL16, ENA-78, Eotaxin-3, GCP-2, GRO, HCC-1, HCC-4, IL-9, IL-17F, IL-18 BPa, IL-28a, IL-29, IL-31, IP-10, I-TAC, LIF, LIGHT, Lymphotactin, MCP-2, MCP-3, MCP-4, MDC, MIF, MIP-3a, MIP-3b, MPIF-1, MSPa, NAP-2, OPN, PARC, PF4, SDF-la, TARC, TECK and TSLP. RESULTS: In the group of threatened preterm labor we demonstrated a significantly higher risk and higher levels of preterm birth when the serum concentration of: MIP-3a > 3.6 pg/ml (sens. 0.71, sp. 0.50, p=0.018); I-TAC > 33.3 pg/ml (sens. 0.72, sp. 0.56, p=0.004 ) and TARC >41.55 pg/ml (sens. 71, sp. 53, p=0.008 ) whereas higher risk and lower concentrations of HCC-4 <1268 pg/ml (sens. 0.71, sp. 0.42, p=0.047).

FIGREF19.text: A retrospective review of all births 2002-2011. The rate of EOGBSD was ascertained among all neonates <7 days old, as determined by either a positive blood or cerebrospinal fluid culture for GBS. The rate of compliance with the hospital protocol was evaluated by review of all case-records in two thee month periods, one in 2006 and one in 2011. RESULTS: There were 30,207 births in our hospital between 2002-2011, inclusive. There were 12 cases of EOGBD (rate: 0.4/1000 births). There were no neonatal deaths due to GBD sepsis. During the 2006 and 2011 audit periods there were 532 and 531 eligible births, respectively. There were 5 and 8 protocol violations in these periods, affording protocol compliance rates of 99.1% and 98.5%, respectively. During the 2006 period 129/532 (24%) women received intrapartum antibiotics for EOGBSD prophylaxis.

Data were analysed using the Student's unpaired t-test. P<0.05 was considered significant. RESULTS: Exposure to hypoxia reduced the maternal PaO 2 (106±2 vs. 47±1mmHg). Maternal hypoxia reduced fetal body weight (4.0±0.1 vs. 3.2±0.3kg) and increased the ratio of bi-parietal diameter to hind limb lower length (3.7±0.1 vs. 6.5±0.6). Lungs of fetuses from hypoxic pregnancies showed increased mRNA expression of ENAC-b, ATPase-a1 & -b1, AQP-1 & -4, SP-B, -C & -D(Fig 1). CONCLUSIONS: Maternal chronic hypoxia in late gestation stimulates processes mediating lung liquid reabsorption and surfactant system maturation in the fetus. FIGREF32.text: Estrogen Signaling in Stem Cells from Uterine Fibroid and Adjacent Myometrium. Sangeeta Nair, Archana Laknaur, Chakradhari Sharan, Ayman Al-Hendy. Ob Gyn, CWHR, Meharry Medical College, Nashville, TN, USA.INTRODUCTION: Uterine fibroids are benign tumors originating from the myometrium with a higher incidence in African American premenopausal women. They are estrogen dependent and the enhanced sensitivity to estrogen has been shown via an increase in estrogen binding sites. Lately, new theories have evolved based on the isolation and tumor initiating characteristics of somatic stem cells in fibroids and adjacent myometrium to help in understanding the pathophysiology of uterine fibroids. The aim of this study is to investigate estrogen responsive element transactivation in stems cells from normal uterine myometrium (MyoN), uterine fibroids (F), and adjacent myometrium (MyoF).METHODS: Stem cells were isolated based on surface antigen CD44& STRO1 from fibroids (F), corresponding myometrium tissue (MyoF) and myometrium from normal uteri (fibroid-free) (MyoN) from women undergoing hysterectomy. All human research procedure was approved by Meharry IRB. The stem cells along with matched primary cells were transduced with Ad-ERE-luc, an adenoviral reporter vector carrying two copies of the estrogen-responsive element (ERE) upstream of luciferase reporter, at 10pfu for 5 hours and swapped with fresh media containing estradiol at concentrations of 10 -6 , -8 and -10 M for 48 hours. In another experiment Ad-ERE-luc and Ad-ERa (estrogen receptor alpha) at 10pfu was transduced into MyoF and MyoN stem cells. Luciferase activity was measured using luciferase enzyme assay systems, according to the supplier's protocol (Promega, Madison, WI). Reverse transcriptase-PCR (RT-PCR) was carried out for ERa gene expression in the three distinct stem cells and corresponding primary cells. RESULTS: Expression of ERE activity was significantly lower in the stem cells from MyoF and MyoN in comparison to corresponding primary cells (P<0.05). Introduction of ERa significantly increased the ERE-luc transactivation activity in these stem cells (P<0.05). RT-PCR evaluation showed higher expression of ERa in MyoF stem cells than in MyoN and F stem cells (P<0.05). Overall, primary MyoF and F cells showed a greater expression of ERa in comparison to corresponding stem cells. CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that estrogen receptor a expression is in a dynamic state in stem cells and may be modified by exogenous influences. Further investigations are required to establish the role of steroid hormone signaling in myometrial stem cells and its potential role in fibroid formation. NIH/NICHD R01 HD046228.

They are confronted with demand for PCC and the majority of GP's and midwifes point out the availability of PCC in daily care. Actual PCC consultations, however, are scarce. All 3 professionals have positive perceptions regarding PCC. Identified prerequisites for delivery of PCC in the future were effective recruitment strategies, more evidence for PCC and more knowledge. CONCLUSIONS: Despite numerous efforts to offer PCC, actual delivery of PCC by is still small scale. INTRODUCTION: The uterus is a remarkably resilient organ with tremendous regenerative capacity. Mechanisms coordinating regeneration of the endometrium during the menstrual/estrous cycle and following parturition are poorly understood, but likely involve resident stem (and/ or progenitor) cells. Current techniques employed to assess endometrial stem cell qualities include in vitro assays, characterization by stem-cell markers or label-retention, and engraftment of endometrial cells under the renal capsule. The objective of this study was to develop an orthotopic transplantation model to assess endometrial stem cell qualities in vivo.enlarged with time indicative of clonal expansion within the tissue. Donor cells derived from early postnatal endometrial tissue had greater engraftment efficiency and resulted in larger engraftment sites compared to adult donor cells. Daughter cells derived from donor epithelial and stromal cells expressed epithelial and mesenchymal cell markers, as well as steroid hormone receptors. Importantly, the function of engrafted cells was maintained following transplantation. Urinary excretion of [ 14 C]HPC and labeled metabolites was 0.3% of the dose from 0-24 h, 0.8% from 24-48 h, and 1.0% from 144-168 h. HPLC analysis showed 32-40% of the radioactivity to be associated with very polar metabolite(s) presumably related to the caproic acid. 40-53% of the radioactivity was associated with hydroxylated metabolites. No unchanged [ 14 C]HPC was present. CONCLUSIONS: Hepatocyte studies indicated rabbit as a reasonable species for evaluating HPC metabolism. Parent HPC comprised 9-16% of the radioactivity in plasma. The primary metabolites are mono-, di-and tri-hydroxylated forms of HPC, with most hydroxylation occurring on the caproate chain. A human study is underway. Streptococcus agalactiae or Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is the leading cause of infectious neonatal morbidity and mortality in the United States, yet the mechanism by which GBS interacts with the gestational membranes has not yet been elucidated. Recently, we demonstrated in a two-compartment in vitro model of extraplacental membranes that GBS inoculation on the decidual side of the membranes stimulates expression of human beta defensin (HBD)-2 in the amnion epithelial cells. Here, we test our hypothesis that HBD-2 increases in the amnion epithelial cells are mediated by a secreted cytokine produced by the choriodecidual tissue. METHODS: Human extraplacental membranes were collected from healthy, non-emergency, non-laboring cesarean sections. Membranes were blunt-dissected to remove the amnion from the choriodecidua. The etiology of preterm birth (PTB) includes factors such as infection, placental hemorrhage and stress. Existing tests have poor performance and are limited in utility, especially in nulliparous patients. Thus, there is a compelling need to identify biomarkers of PTB to enable interventions for patients at risk. METHODS: The Proteomic Assessment of Preterm Risk clinical trial (11 sites) enrolled 5500 patients representative of the US population. We employed a 2-phase discovery strategy(Fig 1). First, candidate protein biomarkers were assembled by both hypothesis dependent database query and a fi rst-pass shotgun proteomics discovery effort. Second, a single MRM-MS assay was developed to quantify over 200 candidate biomarkers in serum samples from approximately 90 PTB cases and 180 controls. Univariate p-values and AUROC values were calculated. Multivariate classifi er performance using panels of signifi cant analytes was assessed by a bootstrap method with LASSO and Random Forest models.RESULTS:Univariate analysis of the MRM-MS discovery studies identifi ed analytes amongst multiple functional pathways of relevance to PTB, with immune response highly represented(Table 1, DAVID Software). Multivariate classifi ers demonstrated a highly statistically signifi cant separation of cases and controls in these training models. CONCLUSIONS: Our strategy for identifi cation of biomarkers enabled greater predictive power than obtained from clinical characteristics alone and revealed functional pathways important to the etiology of PTB. Once classifi ers have been fi nalized, their performance will be assessed in follow-up validation studies. The offspring of low-income families have disproportionately high rates of growth restriction, preterm birth and neonatal mortality. Little is known about the underlying biological mechanisms responsible for these disparities. Recently, methods have been developed and validated for measuring gene expression patterns in living fetuses via amniotic fl uid. By measuring gene expression patterns in amniotic fl uid, we aim to discern whether SES affects the early stages of fetal development.METHODS:Pregnant women referred for amniocentesis at a community hospital associated with an academic medical center are recruited prior to amniocentesis. Inclusion criteria include maternal age > 18, singleton pregnancy, and gestational age < 24 weeks. Patients complete a series of validated questionnaires regarding socioeconomic conditions, acute and chronic stressors, depressed mood and lifestyle variables. Electronic records are queried for medical history and neonatal outcomes. RESULTS: Mesenchimal cells on the histological sections were positive for desmin and vimentin (specific for mesenchimal cells), while amniotic epithelial cells showed a co-expression of epithelial and mesenchymal markers (cytokeratin 7 and AE1/AE3 and vimentin) and showed a positive cytoplasmic reaction to the AAT antibody in samples of amniotic membranes both with or without PROM. Amniotic epithelial cells from cases without PROM showed a high percentage of positivity to AAT (high production) localized on the top layer of the cells indicating a release of AAT. In cases with PROM we observed the same percentage of cells expressing AAT. However, the expression of AAT was only intracytoplasmatic suggesting a lack of release. CONCLUSIONS: Our results show that amniotic epithelial cells from both PROM and controls express AAT. However, the location of AAT inside the cells is different, suggesting a lack of secretion of AAT in PROM as compared to controls. However, the exact mechanisms and the identity of the PKC isoforms involved remain unknown.

TABREF42.text: Epithelial Cells by IL-1b, Endotoxin and Vitamin D. Evonne C Chin-Smith, Rachel M Tribe. Division of Women's Health, King's College London, London, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION:Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), including trappin-2/ elafin and cathelicidin, are a first line defense peptides released from epithelial cells in response to pathogens. Vit D also plays an integral role in the acquired and innate immune responses and a correlation between Vit D deficiency and infection is well established. However, the cellular impact of Vit D on AMPs in the reproductive tract has not been fully defined. We hypothesize that pregnant women at risk of SPTB express altered AMPs profiles and that this may be linked to Vit D deficiency and existing inflammation/infection. The aim of this study was to describe AMP expression in a human endocervical cell line (END1/E6E7) and determine the impact of Vit D in the presence and absence of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1b and the bacterial product LPS on AMP profiles. METHODS: END1/E6E7 cells were cultured to ~80% confluence and assessed for AMP (elafin, hBD2, SLPI, cathelicidin) mRNA expression by qPCR. Cells were treated ± 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (Vit D), IL-1b or LPS or with IL-1b/ LPS pre-treatment followed by Vit D. Cell AMPs were differentially stimulated by inflammation and Vit D in END1 cells. Further investigation into the specific functional roles of the AMPS in this system and the potential for Vit D treatment to enhance cathelicidin defenses against pathogens is warranted. Funded by Tommy's Charity.

TABREF55.text: RDS) and neurodevelopment disabilities. We have previously shown that treatment of U.parvum IAI with azithromycin (AZI) reduces the severity of fetal lung and brain injury. Our long-term goal is to assess neonatal outcomes following U.parvum IAI and AZI therapy, with emphasis on neurobehavioral & cognitive development and pulmonary function. This initial study will 1) focus on expanding the scope of newborn infant care at the ONPRC to enable survival of prematurely born rhesus, 2) develop critical care management plans to ensure optimal chance of neonatal survival, and 3) assess the feasibility of neonatal survival following U.parvum IAI in the NHP. METHODS: Our Special Care Nursery provides specialized housing and 24-hr care for preterm neonates. Two Air-Shield isolettes and Servo 300A ventilators were used to provide temperature & respiratory support. Clinical management plans were developed for moderate to intense critical care levels, extrapolating from current NICU & veterinary practices. Preterm infants had mild-moderate RDS and were supported with supplemental O2 and/or assisted ventilation (CPAP) as indicated by clinical symptoms. For infants with clinical signs of respiratory failure, surfactant was administered (100mg/kg). More intensive care (mechanical ventilation & nutritional support) was required for those neonates exposed to U.parvum IAI alone compared to those treated with AZI. Provision of parenteral nutrition (PICC) was essential due to poor suckling reflex. Enteral feedings were gradually introduced to reduced risk of NEC. CONCLUSIONS: Extending our maternal-fetal NHP model of prematurity to successfully include neonatal survival, provides unique opportunities for establishing new research initiatives that will provide clinically relevant and translational data from both the maternal-fetal environment and postnatal period.

TABREF60.text: Although the adverse effect of maternal tobacco use has been well validated, its harmful impact in the setting of gestational diabetes is still unknown. Given the vasculopathy induced by tobacco use and the fetal growth stimulated by maternal insulin resistance, we aimed to assess the impact of maternal tobacco use on glycemic control and pregnancy outcomes in women with gestational diabetes. METHODS: Retrospective cohort study of all singleton pregnancies delivered at a single center with GDM from 2007-2012. Women were excluded for major maternal medical illness, fetal anomalies, and unknown maternal tobacco use status. The exposure of interest was self-reported smoking at any time during pregnancy. Outcomes of interest are included in table 1 and include use of glyburide, dose of glyburide, and use of insulin. Groups were compared using Studentâ€™s t-test, Mann-Whitney U, or chi-squared test, as appropriate. P-value of <0.05 was considered statistically significant. Logistic regression was used to refine point estimates while adjusting for the appropriate confounding factors.

TABREF62.text: Forceps use in operative vaginal delivery (OVD) has declined in the U.S. It is unclear whether this decline is linked to residency training or other demographic factors. Before encouraging further resident education in both methods of OVD, it is important to understand how training translates into practice. We therefore aimed to determine if residency experience (volume and type of OVD) affects instrument choice for OVD in independent practice. METHODS: We surveyed all Ob/Gyn residency graduates of 4 institutions from 2004-12. The average number of vacuums and forceps per resident in each graduating class was obtained from Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education data and linked to survey respondents based on their residency program and graduation year. Practice pattern for OVD reflects residency training experience for both vacuums and forceps. Resident educators influence instrument choice for OVD in post-graduate practice. METHODS: Women at 'high-risk' (n=19) or with 'threatened PTB' (n=32) had a cervical IGFBP-1 swab at recruitment and their plasma AEA, OEA and PEA concentrations analysed by UHPLC-tandem mass spectrometry. The recruitment-to-delivery-interval (RTDI) was recorded.

Catherine M Albrigt, 1 Joshua D Dahlke, 1 Lindsay Maggio, 1 Hector Mendez-Figueroa, 2 Nina Ayala, 1 Suneet P Chauhan, 2 Katharine Wenstrom. 1 1 Division of MFM, Department of OB/ Gyn, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Women & Infants Hospital, Providence, RI, USA; 2 Division of MFM, Department of OB/ Gyn and Reproductive Sciences, UT Health-University of Texas Medical School, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Pregnancies complicated by fetal growth restriction (FGR; estimated fetal weight <10% for gestational age [GA]) deliver neonates that are either small (<10%) or appropriate (10-89%) for GA (SGA, AGA, respectively). Outcomes in SGA versus AGA neonates of FGR pregnancies are not well defined.METHODS:Retrospective cohort of all singleton, non-anomalous, fetuses who had umbilical artery (UA) Doppler studies for FGR and delivered at our institution from January 2008 to July 2012. Maternal characteristics and delivery outcomes, and neonatal outcomes were compared for both groups. Alexander nomogram was used to categorize newborns as SGA or AGA. RESULTS: Of 11,785 evaluated at our center, 789 had FGR and 530 met inclusion criteria. SGA was noted in 69% of neonates. There were no differences in maternal characteristics or mode of delivery.

TABREF146.text: The spectrum of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy is a significant cause of maternal morbidity. Among the classic disease processes there are many variations involving elevation in blood pressure & some level of organ dysfunction. Of these, Atypical HELLP is very poorly defined. We aim to investigate whether demographic differences exist between patients with Severe Preeclampsia, Classic HELLP, & Atypical HELLP. Atypical HELLP was characterized as patients with severe elevation in blood pressures, proteinuria & thrombocytopenia.CONCLUSIONS:In the first study of this kind, atypical cases of HELLP displayed a similar demographic profile as Classic HELLP & Severe Preeclampsia. This suggests atypical forms may result from a common etiology & may be considered in the spectrum of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. Further characterization, including molecular studies, are warranted.

TABREF148.text: Twin pregnancies are at increased risk to develop preeclampsia (PE) which leads to the necessity for an aligned obstetric treatment. Angiogenic factors like soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase (sFlt), Placental Growth Factor (PlGF) and the sFlt/PlGF ratio are reliable tools in the assessment of PE in singleton pregnancies. We describe alterations in twin pregnancies with preeclampsia and controls in third trimenon. Patients with early-onset PE displayed an increased sFlt level compared to patients with late-onset PE, but there were no alterations detectable in PlGF or sFlt/PlGF ratio. CONCLUSIONS: The sFlt/PlGF ratio is a useful diagnostic measure for PE is in twin pregnancies. Antiangiogenic factor sFlt may play a role in onset of PE in twin pregnancies.

TABREF150.text: CONCLUSIONS: UTI in pregnancy is strongly associated with PE, even after controlling for potential confounders. This association supports the hypothesis that the risk of PE is enhanced by an increased maternal inflammatory burden. Prophylaxis against UTI represents a potentially low-cost global intervention to curb the development of PE.

TABREF155.text: INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia is a multi-system disorder with potentially life threatening complications for mother & baby. Fundamentally, preeclampsia is a state of increased oxidative stress and endothelial dysfunction, with current therapeutic interventions limited to controlling maternal hypertension to prolong pregnancy. The holy-grail of preeclampsia has been to identify novel treatments aimed at mitigating this oxidative stress & subsequent angiogenic dysfunction. We propose the hormone melatonin as one such candidate acting as a powerful antioxidant, up-regulator of other antioxidants & with excellent biosafety.METHODS:We have commenced a pilot study of antenatal maternally administered melatonin in human pregnancies affected by preeclampsia (The PAMPR Trial). Participants: 20 women with preterm preeclampsia (24 +0 -35 +6 weeks gestation).Intervention & Comparison: Oral melatonin 10mg tabs t.d.s.. Comparisons made pre-& at multiple time points post-treatment. Outcomes: Diagnosis to delivery interval compared to historical controls, biomarkers of oxidative stress & preeclampsia, clinical outcomes, maternal & fetal ultrasound parameters, & serious adverse events.

Sukainah Y Alkhalaf, 1 Sinead M O'Neill, 2 Linda M O'Keeffe, 2 Louise C Kenny, 3 Ali S Khashan. 3 1 Epidemiology&Public Health, University College Cork, Ireland; 2 National Perinatal Epidemiology Centre, University College Cork, Ireland; 3 Irish Centre for Fetal&Neonatal Translational Research, University College Cork, Ireland. INTRODUCTION: Cesarean section(CS)rates are increasing worldwide& are associated with numerous offspring disorders. The microbiota was suggested to play a crucial role in the development of normal social behaviors in germ-free mice 1 . We tested the hypothesis that mode of delivery,particularly elective CS,affects childhood behavioral development with sex-specific associations. METHODS: Using data from the Growing Up in Ireland cohort we conducted a cohort study of 9973 children randomly selected to represent all Irish births in 2008 (N=73662). Child behaviors were assessed with the 'Strengths&Difficulties Questionnaire'(SDQ) when children were 3 years old. Multivariate logistic regression was used for data analysis. RESULTS: 59% of births were born by spontaneous vaginal delivery(SVD), 14% by instrumental vaginal delivery(IVD), 12% by elective CS & 13% by emergency CS. Emergency CS children had an increased odds of having abnormal total SDQ, hyperactivity & peerproblem, which persisted after adjusting for potential confounders. There was evidence of sex-specific effects in females born by IVD for hyperactivity & peer problems in females born by emergency CS.Males had an increased risk of hyperactivity in emergency CS only. adjusted for maternal age,education,race,preeclampsia,gestational age,sex,birthweight, parity

Sinead M O'Neill, 1 Esben Agerbo, 2 Louise C Kenny, 3 Tine B Henriksen, 4 Patricia M Kearney, 5 Richard A Greene, 1 Preben B Mortensen, 2 Ali S Khashan. 3 1 National Perinatal Epidemiology Centre, University College Cork, Ireland; 2 National Centre for Registerbased Research, Aarhus University, Denmark; 3 Irish Centre for Fetal & Neonatal Translational Research, University College Cork, Ireland; 4 Perinatal Epidemiology Research Unit, Aarhus University Hospital, Denmark; 5 Epidemiology and Public Health, University College Cork, Ireland. INTRODUCTION: Cesarean section rates have peaked worldwide,yet the longterm effects are unknown.This study assessed the risk of explained/unexplained stillbirth following primary Cesarean. METHODS: In a Danish cohort(n=832,996),we identified women with primary livebirth between January 1982 & December 2010.Followup continued until the next event(explained/unexplained stillbirth) or censoring by other events,death,emigration or study end.Analyzes included Cox regression & cause-specific competing-risks. RESULTS: An increased risk of stillbirth was found in emergency & elective Cesarean. Adj.HR=Adjusted Hazard Ratio; *Model1:maternal age,origin,history of stillbirth,education,marital status,mother&father's income **Model1 + medical complications ***Model2 + gestational age,birthweight Data for the causes of stillbirth was available from 1982-1996,where causespecific competing risks found an increased risk of explained stillbirth in emergency[HR1.26,95%CI 1.09,1.46] & elective[HR1.30,95%CI 1.04,1.62]Cesarean in the crude and adjusted models.For unexplained stillbirth,an increased risk was found in emergency Cesarean only[HR1.42,95%CI1.00,2.01] (Data not shown). CONCLUSIONS: Overall,an increased risk of stillbirth was found in emergency & elective Cesarean.An increased risk of explained stillbirth was found in emergency & elective Cesarean. For unexplained stillbirth, an increased risk was found in emergency Cesarean only.Rigorous adjustment modelling did not attenuate these findings.An acknowledged limitation of the study is the lack of data on antepartum/intrapartum stillbirths.This study confirms findings by Smith et al. in the Scottish data.Women need to be advised of the risks for all modes of delivery. TABREF178.text: Jimmy Belotte, 1 Nicole M Fletcher, 1 Michael P Diamond, 2 Ghassan M Saed. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) is the principal cause of death of all gynecologic malignancies. Genomic studies have demonstrated the heterogeneity nature of this disease and identified novel molecular signatures.Recently identified ovarian cancer stem cells, a subpopulation of malignant cells with characteristics of self-renewal and pluripotency, are sustained by a core regulatory positive feedback-loop involving transcription factors Sox2, Nanog and Oct4. The objective of this study is to determine whether Sox2, Nanog, and Oct4 are associated with EOC and poor outcome. METHODS: Ovarian Serous Cystadenocarcinoma genomics data from the cancer genome atlas (TCGA) database was queried through the Cancer Genomics Portal website. Copy number alterations or variations (CNAs or CNVs) are genomic structural polymorphisms, identifiable by genomewide analytic tools such as comparative genomic hybridization. Presence, frequency, and survival outcomes associated with CNAs of Sox2, Nanog and Oct4 were evaluated. They consist of changes in the number of copies of chromosome segments, and genes consisting of deletions, amplifications, insertions, and translocations. We also consolidated the following tumor and clinical variables into binary categorical schemes: FIGO stages into early and advanced, grade low and high, platinum sensitive or resistant and others, which were excluded. Cox regression and Kaplan-Meier analyses were used for outcome predictions. RESULTS: CNA and CNV were present in 35 % of the cases (N=488). There is a 26, 9, and 6% amplification of Sox2, Nanog and POU5F1 (Oct4), respectively. Sox2 amplification, FIGO grade, TRD and "Prim. Tx. Out. Succ." are shown to be significant predictors of death. Additionally, K-M survival analyses showed a significant median overall survival differences (41 vs 48.3 months, p=0.01) for Sox2 amplification. There was no differences observed for Nanog (44.1 vs 36.2 months, p> 0.05) and POU5F1 (43.5 vs 45.0 months, p> 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Our results indicate that Sox2 gene amplification is significantly associated with Serous Ovarian Cancer and impact survival outcome. These findings suggest the presence of cancer stem cells in serous ovarian cancer and more importantly highlight an important role for Sox2 as a potential molecular target for outcome prediction in serous EOC. Additional studies are needed to validate our results.To Vaccinate or Not?: How Perceived Susceptibility to and Severity of HPV and Cervical Cancer Impacts Administration of the HPV Vaccine in African American Women (AAW). TABREF179.text: Malignant Degeneration of Mature Cystic Teratomas. Jonathan D Black, Dana M Roque, Thomas J Rutherford, Peter E Schwartz, Elena S Ratner. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Division of Gynecologic Oncology, Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Mature cystic teratoma (MCT) is the most common germ cell tumor and accounts for 10-20% of ovarian masses. The rate of malignant degeneration is low and prognosis is poor. We sought to better understand these tumors and associated risk factors. METHODS: A single-institution retrospective chart review of MCT cases which exhibited malignant degeneration from 2004-2012. Multiple variables were examined including procedure, surgical stage, histological type, recurrence status, use of chemotherapy, and progression free and overall survival. RESULTS: 8 out of 729 (1.09%) MCT specimens exhibited malignant degeneration. The mean age at presentation was 59 years (range 40-74 years). Mean follow-up was 22 months (range 1-56 months). The most common presenting symptoms were bloating and abdominal pain. Mean tumor size was 23.8cm (range 18-33.5cm). Over 50% of cases were at least stage IIIC, the remainder were stage IC or lower. 5 out of 8 cases (62.5%) were mucinous adenocarcinomas in addition to one case each of malignant melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Of mucinous tumors, 100% were positive for CK20, CDX2 and 40% were positive for CK7. The case of recurrence was malignant melanoma and occurred 328 days after diagnosis. The case of squamous cell carcinoma was stage IC and the case of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma was stage IIIC; both died within 6 months of diagnosis. 75% of patients received adjuvant chemotherapy. One patient had a known MCT that was being followed expectantly and subsequently grew 14cm in one year and exhibited malignant degeneration to a mucinous adenocarcinoma. At one year, overall survival was 67% and at 3 years, 40%. Progression free survival was 17.5 months among those who received chemotherapy and 26.8 months among those who did not. CONCLUSIONS: A large ovarian mass suspected to be a MCT should be managed aggressively in older patients. While malignant degeneration is rare, it is more likely when patients are older than 40 years old and the mass is greater than 18cm. We observed a higher rate of malignant degeneration into a mucinous neoplasm relative to published data. Like most ovarian cancers, these tumors most often present at later stages and can be difficult to treat. It is unclear what role chemotherapy plays in this disease.Flutamide and Risk for Ovarian Cancer: Pre-Clinical and ClinicalStudy. INTRODUCTION:This study examined associations of treatment characteristics for cervical dysplasia (type of procedure, cone depth and volume) with surgical margin status, recurrence, and preterm delivery in pregnancy immediately following excisional procedure. METHODS: Women ages <49 who underwent an excisional procedure for cervical dysplasia between 2000 and 2010 at Yale-New Haven Hospital were linked to birth registry data. Data on demographics, cervical dysplasia, treatment (LEEP vs. cold knife cone vs. laser cone biopsy), cone dimensions (horizontal diameter -D1, vertical diameter -D2, depth -D3), pathological features of cone biopsy, and subsequent pregnancy were collected. Characteristics were compared across oncological and obstetric outcomes using Fisher's exact tests, Wilcoxon rank sum tests, and logistic regression models when appropriate. Cervical cone volume was calculated based onPapoutsis et al. 2011  where cone volume = (D1xD2xD3) x Pi/6. RESULTS: The analysis included 65 women. Mean age at time of excisional procedure was 25.4 and mean age at delivery date was 29.1. The average cervical excision dimensions were 2.3cm transverse diameter,

Obstetrics & Gynecology, Yale University School of Medicine, USA. INTRODUCTION: This study analyzed presentation, treatment, pathology, and survival of patients with uterine leiomyosarcoma (LMS) at a single institution from 2000 to 2012.METHODS:We performed a retrospective chart review on patients with LMS as identified by pathological records. We collected data on demographics, presentation, operative procedure, FIGO stage, histopathological features, treatment regimens, and survival. We performed statistical analysis using Fisher's exact tests, Wilcoxon rank sum tests, and Kaplan-Meier curves. RESULTS: A total of 44 women with LMS were analyzed. The most common presenting symptoms were vaginal bleeding (55%) or increasing abdominal girth (47%). 43% of patients had stage I disease, 14% had stage II disease, 13% had stage III disease, and 30% had stage IV disease. 10% of individuals declined chemotherapy. Of patients who received initial adjuvant chemotherapy, 41% received doxorubicin and ifosfamide, 35%

TABREF182.text: Sexual Function among Older Female Cancer Survivors. Sudeshna Chatterjee, 1 Divya Patel, 2 Elisabeth Erekson, 3 Elena Ratner. 1 1 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Yale University School of Medicine, USA; 2 Obstetrics & Gynecology, University of Michigan, USA; 3 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, USA. INTRODUCTION: Sexual health greatly impacts quality of life and may be negatively affected in cancer survivors. The aim of this study is to compare sexual function of older female cancer survivors relative to other women without a history of cancer. METHODS: We performed a cross sectional analysis of the 2005-2006National Social Life, Health, and Aging Project (NSHAP) database to investigate sexual attitudes and function of female cancer survivors ages 57 to 85. We compared sexuality in older female cancer survivors to other women and sub-stratified by age and years since cancer diagnosis. Outcomes measured included sexual partnership, activity, frequency, attitudes and beliefs, and dysfunction. RESULTS: A total of 1550 women were included in the analysis, of which 6.5% of women were cancer survivors. The most common cancer was breast cancer (38.6%) followed by gynecological malignancies (32.4%). Female cancer survivors were less likely to report a current sexual partner (p=.004) or sexual activity in the previous 12 months (p=.03), and reported decreased interest in sex (p=.04) compared to their non-cancer counterparts. No differences were observed regarding types of sexual activity between cancer survivors and other women as measured by degree of foreplay (p=.13), vaginal coitus (p=.10), and masturbation (p=.90). Common sexual problems, such as vaginal dryness (p=.36), anorgasmia (p=.47), dyspareunia (p=.46), lack of pleasure (p=.15), performance anxiety (p=.07) and avoidance of sex (p=.19) were similar between female cancer survivors and other women. Sexual attitudes, values and beliefs, and sexual dysfunction were also similar between age groups of cancer survivors (57 to 64 years old, 65-74 years old, and 75-85 years old). Female survivors within 5 years of cancer diagnosis reported increased vaginal dryness and dyspareunia compared with female cancer survivors greater than 5 years since their diagnosis (p=.038 and p=.0055 respectively). CONCLUSIONS: Although there are issues unique to female cancer survivors such as decreased interest and sexual frequency, we found that overall, sexual activity and sexual attitudes were similar to the general population.Lipoxygenase (LOX) Pathways Are Activated in EndometrialCarcinogenesis. M Cummings, K Massey, G Mappa, N Wilkinson, R Hutson, A Nicolaou, NM Orsi. Pathology, Leeds University, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Endometrial cancer (EC) is the commonest gynaecological malignancy in the developed world, affecting 15-25:100,000 women/year. ECs are classified as Type I/II according to their aetiological, histological and molecular characteristics. Type I ECs (~75% cases) typically arise from premalignant hyperplasia, whereas Type II Ecs arise from atrophic endometrium, are high grade and carry a worse prognosis. Although some eicosanoids (e.g. the cyclooxygenase (COX) product PGE2) are recognised inflammatory mediators associated with carcinogenesis, the roles of other eicosanoid species such as LOX/ epoxygenase metabolites are poorly understood. This study aimed to characterise the eicosanoid spectrum of normal, hyperplastic and cancerous endometrium using a lipidomics approach. METHODS: We profiled 48 eicosanoid and related lipid species in 81 normal, 30 hyperplastic and 118 cancerous endometrial specimens (Types I/II). Specimens were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80ºC. Each was cryosectioned and resultant slides marked up for areas of interest.

Catha Fischer, Elisa Jorgenson, Ysabel Ilagan, Hugh Taylor. Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Sciences, Yale University, USA. TABREF184.text: Dicholoroacetate Increases Sensitivity to Chemotherapy by Modulation of Antioxidants in Epithelial OvarianCancer. Nicole M Fletcher, 1 Jimmy Belotte, 1 Mohammed G Saed, 1 Husam M Abu-Soud, 1 Michael P Diamond, 2 Ghassan M Saed. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Georgia Regents University, Agusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION:Chemoresistance presents a challenge in treatment of ovarian cancer. Epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) manifests a persistent prooxidant state and reduction of this state induces apoptosis. Dichloroacetate (DCA), which converts anaerobic to aerobic metabolism, was shown to induce apoptosis in EOC cells. We sought to determine whether DCA modulates key antioxidant levels as part of a mechanism of increased apoptosis. METHODS: Resistant and sensitive MDAH-2774 EOC cells were treated with DCA (10 mM) for 24 hours. Real-time RT-PCR was used to determine mRNA levels for glutathione reductase (GSR), glutathione peroxidase (GPX1), catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD3), as well as caspase-3. Data was analyzed using SPSS and a student's t-test, p<0.05 was considered significant. RESULTS: DCA differentially altered antioxidants, increasing GSR and SOD3 and decreasing GPX1 in resistant EOC cells. Additionally, caspase-3 expression increased in resistant EOC, suggesting an increase in apoptosis.

TABREF185.text: Results of real-time RT-PCR analysis of antioxidant enzymes in the sensitive and cisplatin (50 µM) resistant EOC cell line, MDAH-2774. Results are expressed as fg/µg RNA ± standard deviation. a denotes p<0.05 as compared to CONCLUSIONS: DCA alters the redox balance by differentially regulating antioxidants in resistant cells suggesting a role for these enzymes in the acquisition of chemoresistance. Modulating the redox balance may serve as a therapeutic intervention, decreasing chemoresistance. Histologic Characterization of the Postpartum Fallopian Tube. Gillian Hsieh, 1 Kathleen Antony, 1 Ramya Masand, 2 Matthew L Anderson. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA; 2 Pathology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA.INTRODUCTION: Accumulating evidence implicates the distal fallopian tube as a source of many high grade serous carcinomas. This evidence has heightened clinical interest in salpingectomy as a tool for ovarian cancer prevention. Women requesting postpartum tubal ligation are potentially ideal candidates for risk-reducing salpingectomy. However, existing histologic descriptions of the postpartum fallopian tube are often conflicted. Clear definitions of the normal histologic appearance of the postpartum fallopian tube are needed before postpartum distal salpingectomy can be adopted for cancer prevention on a population scale as well as to understand the protective impact of pregnancy on ovarian cancer risk. METHODS: After obtaining permission from the IRB, specimens of fallopian tube were collected from women undergoing distal salpingectomy as part of a prospective feasibility study. Informed consent was obtained from all subjects. Specimens were paraffin-embedded and sectioned according to the SEE-FIM protocol. Expression of Ki-67 and TP53 were examined by immunohistochemistry. Cross-sections were reviewed by a fellowship-trained gynecologic pathologist.

TABREF186.text: Long-Term Data on the Value of HPV-Related BiomarkersPost-Treatment for CIN. Maria Kyrgiou, 1 George Valasoulis, 2 Melina -Sofia Stasinou, 5 Maria Nasioutziki, 4 Aristotelis Loufopoulos, 4 Petros Karakitsos, 3 Evangelos Paraskevaidis. 2 1 West London Gynaecological Cancer Center, QCCH -Hammersmith Hospital,Imperial Healthcare NHS Trust, London, United Kingdom; 2 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University Hospital of Ioannin, Ioannina, Greece; 3 Cytopathology, Attikon University Hospital, Athens, Greece; 4 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; 5 IVF unit, Create Clinic, London, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: The aims of this study were to evaluate changes in the biomarkers after treatment for CIN and to assess the accuracy of biomarkers in the prediction of treatment failures. METHODS: Prospective observational study. Setting: University Hospital of Ioannina. Period: Sep 2008-Sep 2013[. Population: Women planned to undergo LLETZ for CIN. Intervention: An LBC sample was obtained prior to the first colposcopy assessment and it was repeated at 6,12,18,24,30,36, 48, 60 months after treatment. This was tested for HPVrelated biomarkers (HPV typing, E6 & E7 mRNA by NASBA and flow cytometry and p16INK4a). Outcomes: We calculated the positivity rates of HPV-related biomarkers pre-treatment according to the grade of CIN at treatment and the positivity rates at different time points post-treatment.

TABREF187.text: Follow-Up and Outcomes of Women with Untreated CIN2 Lesions: Is There a Role for the Use of HPV-Related Biomarkers? Maria Kyrgiou, 1 Priya Abrol, 1 Katerina Papakonstantinou, 1 Miranda Cowen, 1 George Valasoulis, 2 Melina Stasinou, 2 Petros Karakitsos, 3 Evangelos Paraskevaidis. 2 1 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Imperial Healthcare NHS Trust, London, United Kingdom; 2 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University Hospital of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece; 3 Cytopathology, Attikon University Hospital, Athens, Greece. INTRODUCTION:There is increasing awareness that not all HSIL lesions are precancer and a large of proportion of CIN2 lesions may regress spontaneously without treatment particularly in young women. To review outcomes of women with untreated CIN2 lesions and to identify whether HPV-related biomarkers could safely discriminate which of these women require treatment and which are likely to regress. METHODS: Setting: Three University Hospitals; Imperial NHS Trust, London-Ioannina, Greece. Population: Young women with histologically proven CIN2 lesions under close surveillance. Interventions: Follow-up data on cytology, colposcopy and histology were retrieved. In a subgroup with CIN2, an LBC specimen was prospectively obtained prior to colposcopy and tested for HPV typing, E6 & E7 mRNA by NASBA or flow cytometry, p16INK4a and microspectroscopy. Outcomes: Progression, persistence, regression. The sensitivity, specificity, PPV and NPV were calculated for the biomarkers alone or in combination. The gold standard was histology.

TABREF188.text: Fertility-Sparing Treatment for Young Women with AtypicalHyperplasia and Early Endometrial Cancer with High-Dose Medrocyprogesterone Acetate. Maria Kyrgiou, Rebecca Pugh, Vicky Hird, Richard Smith, Sadaf Ghaem-Maghami, Alan Ghaem-Maghami. West London Gynaecological Cancer Center, QCCH -Hammersmith Hospital,Imperial Healthcare NHS Trust, London, Greece. INTRODUCTION: Fertility-sparing treatment using high-dose medroxyprogesterone (MPA) may be an option for selected young women diagnosed with atypical endometrial hyperplasia (AH) or presumed early endometrial cancer (EC) with no myometrial invasion. The aim of this study was to assess the complete response, pregnancy and recurrence rate in women treated conservatively with high-dose MPA. METHODS: Retrospective observational study. Setting: Gynaecologic Cancer Tertiary Center. Population: young women with AH or presumed stage IA grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus and no myometrial invasion that wished to preserve their fertility. Interventions: high-dose medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA). Outcomes: primary: complete pathologic response (CR) rate -secondary: spontaneous and assisted pregnancy and live birth rate, disease-free interval, toxicity. RESULTS: We identified a total of 21 women, 17 (81%) had AH and 4 (19%) EC. The complete response rate was 71%. The duration of MPA administration varied across patients. A total of 3 pregnancies and 3 live births were recorded; all of those were conceived spontaneously.

TABREF189.text: Proportion of Cervical Excision for CIN as a Predictor of FuturePregnancy Outcomes: A Prospective Study. Maria Kyrgiou, 1 George Valasoulis, 2 Sofia-Melina Stasinou, 3 Christina Founta, 4 Antonis Athanasiou, 2 Sadaf Ghaem-Maghami, 1 Phillip Bennett, 1 Evangelos Paraskevaidis. 2 1 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Imperial Healthcare NHS Trust -Imperial College, London, United Kingdom; 2 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University Hospital of Ioannina, Ioannina, United Kingdom; 3 IVF, Create clinic, London, United Kingdom; 4 Gynaecologic Oncology, Gateshead NHS Trust, Newcastle, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION:The aim of this study was to assess how the proportion of the cervical volume/height removed during CIN treatment varies and to assess whether this correlates to gestation at delivery.METHODS: Prospective observational feasibility study. Period: January 2009-January 2013. Population: Women (21-45y) planned for excisional CIN treatment. Interventions: The cervical dimensions/volume was calculated with MRI, 3-dimensional (3D-TVS) or 2-dimensional transvaginal sonography (2D-TVS) before treatment. The cone dimensions/volume was assessed by a measuring tape and a fluid-filled volumetric vial; the percentage of excision was computed. Analysis: Pearson's correlation (SPSS statistical package). RESULTS: A total of 142 women have been recruited (MRI:62, 3D-TVS:41, 2D-TVS: 39). The volume (/dimensions) of the cervix pre-treatment (mean=22.19 cm3, standard deviation (SD)=5.9; range 11-40cm3) and the cone volume (/dimensions)(mean 2.58 cm3, SD=1.3; range 0.6-8 cm3) varied substantially. Similarly, the proportion of excision ranged between 2.2 to 39.4% with a mean of 12.09 (SD 7.17).

TABREF191.text: Endometrial Cancer Cytokine Profiles Discriminate CarcinogenesisStage and Tumour Subtype. G Mappa, M Cummings, R Hutson, N Wilkinson, N Orsi. Pathology, Anatomy and Tumour Biology, University of Leeds, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Endometrial cancer (EC) is the commonest gynaecological malignancy in the developed world and falls into two categories. Type I ECs are generally oestrogen-sensitive, develop from premalignant hyperplasia and are low-medium grade. By contrast, the rarer high grade Type II ECs are frequently eostrogen receptor negative, have no premalignant lesion and have poorer clinical outcomes. This study aimed to characterise cytokine-based microenvironmental features associated with endometrial carcinogenesis given their role in immunoregulation and determination of cell fate. METHODS: Fresh specimens were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80ºC. Each was cryosectioned and slides marked up to identify representative areas, which were dissected on dry ice from frozen tissue and finely crushed in lysis buffer under liquid nitrogen. 38 normal, 25 hyperplastic and 97 cancerous (46 Type I, 51 Type II) endometrial samples were profiled for 49 cytokines by multiplex immunoassay and ELISA.

TABREF192.text: at Time of Cancer Diagnosis and Relationship to Stage and Tumor Grade for Breast, Cervical, Endometrial, and Ovarian Cancers. Laura Meints, 1 Alexandra Edwards, 1 Candace Brancato, 2 Heather Bush, 2 Ann Coker. 3 1 Obstetrics & Gynecology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky, USA; 2 Biostatistics, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky, USA; 3 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Epidemiology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky, USA. INTRODUCTION:Depression has been shown to negatively influence many health conditions, including diabetes, heart disease, obesity, and pregnancy. These health outcomes also have gender differences associated with them. Little is known about the effect of depression on outcomes of female cancers at time of cancer diagnosis. Our aim is to determine whether depression at time of cancer diagnosis portends a worse stage at diagnosis and tumor histology than for no depression at time of cancer diagnosis, for persons with breast, ovarian, cervical, and endometrial cancers. METHODS: This IRB-approved study included women from the Kentucky Cancer Registry (KCR) who agreed to be contacted for phone interviews to collect information on demographics, cancer well-being, and psychosocial factors. Depression was queried via a validated tool during phone interviews. KCR verified pathology reports and collected clinical information on patients. Demographic data was analyzed according to presence/absence of depression at time of diagnosis using t tests and chi-square tests. Adjusted models were then created for stage at diagnosis and tumor grade at diagnosis based on presence/absence of depression at diagnosis. RESULTS: 1153 women with breast, cervical, endometrial, or ovarian cancer were enrolled in this study between 2010-2013; 443 women had depression and 710 did not have depression at time of cancer diagnosis. This data does not contain sufficient power to find statistically significant differences between depressed and non-depressed women at time of diagnosis by cancer type, but does find a trend toward a more-advanced stage at diagnosis for breast (p= .11) and ovarian (p= .11) cancers and less differentiated tumor grade for breast (p= .066) cancer among women with depression at time of cancer diagnosis. No difference according to presence/absence of depression was observed among women with cervical and endometrial cancers. CONCLUSIONS: This data suggest that women with depression at time of cancer diagnosis may have more-advanced stage at diagnosis for breast and ovarian cancers and less differentiated tumor grade for breast cancer.Knowledge and Perceived Susceptibility and Severity of HPV amongst African American Women (AAW). Gricelda Mendoza, 1 Marissa S Ghant, 1 Anna E Strohl, 1 Kenzie A Cameron, 2 Melissa A Simon, 1 Julian C Schink, 3 Erica E Marsh. 1 1 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Feinberg School of Medicine of Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA; 2 General Internal Medicine and Geriatrics and Preventive Medicine, Feinberg School of Medicine of Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA; 3 Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health, Spectrum Medical Group, Grand Rapids, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION:In the United States, HPV is the most common sexually transmitted disease with 6.2 million people contracting it each year. It causes 99.7% of cervical cancer cases along with genital warts. HPV vaccines exist but vaccination rates differ by race and ethnicity.

TABREF193.text: of Fibroblast Activated Protein (FAP) in the Tumor Stroma Is a Predictive Biomarker for Cisplatin Resistance and Shorter Overall Survival in Patients with Epithelial Ovarian Cancer. Paulette Mhawech-Fauceglia, 1 Tanja Pejovic, 2 Kate Lawrenson. 3 1 Pathology, USC, USA; 2 Gynecologic oncology, Oregon Health system, USA; 3 Preventive Medicine, USC, USA. INTRODUCTION:Tumor micro environment has recently gained an interest in oncology. Fibroblast activated protein (FAP) seemed to have a prognostic value in several malignancies and FAP inhibitors could be a potential target therapy. The aim of this study is to evaluate the role of FAP expression in epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC). METHODS: FAP protein as detected by immunohistochemistry was conducted on paraffin-embedded tissue from 338 EOC samples. Clinical data and follow-up were obtained from the medical records. Fisher's exact test was performed to test the association between FAP and disease outcomes. Kaplan-Meier method with log-rank test was used to calculate the cumulative survival difference between patients and FAP expression. In vitro, EOC cells were co-cultured with mesenchymal cells to induce a cancer associated fibroblast (CAF) phenotype. To test the function of FAP,EOC cells were treated with FAP alone or in the presence of cisplatin. Conversely, FAP expression was silenced by siRNA knock down and cells were evaluated for cell viability using PrestoBlue. RESULTS: FAP immunoexpression was independent predictive factor for cisplatin resistance (p=0.0154) in patients with EOC. In addition, patients with tumors FAP stroma-had longer 3 years survival rate in comparison to those with FAP stroma + (p =0.027). FAP expression was significantly increased in mesenchymal cells co-cultured with EOC cells compared to mesenchymal cells co-cultured with normal epithelial ovarian cell controls. Addition of FAP to EOC cell lines treated with cisplatin showed a 10-12% increase in cell viability and proliferation in comparison to cisplatin alone. Furthermore. siRNA knock down in EOC cell cultures induced a 20% reduction in proliferation. CONCLUSIONS: 1-FAP expression by tumor associated stroma is a potential negative prognostic biomarker in EOC. 2-In vitro studies showed that FAP+ decrease sensitivity for cisplatin. 3-There is a real need for clinically meaningful prognostic biomarkers and novel targeted therapeutic regimens in EOC and due to the frequent presence of FAP by tumor associated stroma, we believe that FAP inhibitors should be further investigated for the clinical management and treatment of EOC.The Significance of Prior Tubal Occlusion in Uterine Papillary Serous Carcinoma. Caroline Nitschmann, Michael Worley, Colleen Feltmate. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Objective. Uterine papillary serous carcinoma (UPSC) often presents with high grade and advanced stage disease. Compared to endometrioid type endometrial carcinoma, UPSC has a higher propensity for intraperitoneal spread and extra-abdominal disease.Trans-tubal exfoliation has been hypothesized as one mechanism by which UPSC spreads intra-abdominally. We sought to evaluate the significance of prior tubal occlusion among women with UPSC.METHODS:Methods. Medical records of patients diagnosed with UPSC between January 1995 and December 2010 were reviewed. Patients were separated into two groups based on the presence or absence of prior tubal ligation that preceded the diagnosis of UPSC. Groups were then compared with respect to patient characteristics, histopathologic findings, stage distribution and rates of optimal cytoreduction (<1cm residual disease). RESULTS: Results. We identified 183 patients. A total of 29 (15.85%) patients had a history of prior tubal ligation and 154 (84.2%) did not. The tubal ligation group had a greater percentage of patients with stage I disease (72.4% vs. 49.4% <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">p=0.072). Groups were similar with respect to other histopathologic findings including myometrial invasion (62.1% vs. 69.5%), cervical stromal invasion (17.9% vs. 23.0%), lymph-vascular space invasion (21.4% vs. 37.7%) and the presence of positive lymph nodes (29.2% vs. 27.0%). Patients with prior tubal ligation were significantly less likely to have adnexal involvement (93.1% vs. 75.3%, <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">p=0.047) and positive cytologic washings (88.5% vs. 66.7%, <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">p=0.035). Rates of optimal cytoreduction were similar between groups. CONCLUSIONS: Conclusion. Patients with a history of uterine papillary serous carcinoma and prior tubal occlusion are significantly less likely to have adnexal involvement and positive cytologic washings.In Vivo Raman Spectroscopy Detects Cervical IntraepithelialNeoplasia with High Accuracy in Diverse Population. TABREF194.text: : In 160 patients, 65 (41%) had tumors with no REST expression. REST expression was not associated with tumor grade, stage, or histologic subtype. Patients with no REST expression showed a more favorable recurrence-free survival curve, with median time to recurrence for REST-less tumors of 20.3 months compared to 35.8 months for RESTexpressing tumors (p=0.002). REST expression was positively correlated with FANCD2 expression (p=0.003), though FANCD2 was not associated with prognosis or tumor characteristics in this cohort. CONCLUSIONS: REST has been shown to have tissue-dependent expression, acting as either a tumor suppressor or oncogene. In contrast to what has been observed in other epithelial cancers, decreased REST expression may be associated with a more favorable prognosis in ovarian cancer. TABREF196.text: Treatment of UterineCarcinosarcoma with Cisplatin/Ifosfamide, Paclitaxel/Ifosfamide, or Carboplatin/Paclitaxel. Dana M Roque, 1 Joyce Varughese, 1 Diana P English, 1 Gregory M Gressel, 1 Lisbet Lundsberg, 2 Elena S Ratner, 1 Thomas J Rutherford, 1 Peter E Schwartz. 1 Gynecologic Oncology, Yale School of Medicine, USA; 2 School of Public Health, Yale University, USA. INTRODUCTION: Carcinosarcomas (CS) represent 4% of uterine cancers, but constitute 26% of deaths. Ifosfamide-containing regimens and carboplatin/paclitaxel (CP+T) have compared favorably in phase II studies. There is no consensus regarding optimal therapy. This study describes the institutional experience with treatment for this entity. METHODS: Patients with a histologic diagnosis of stage I-IV uterine CS from 1990-2013 treated with cisplatin/ifosfamide (C+I), paclitaxel/ ifosfamide (T+I), or CP+T were identified retrospectively. RESULTS: 56 patients were included. 35 patients had early and 21 had advanced disease; 58.9% received C+I, 12.5% T+I, and 28.6% CP+T. Presence of a heterologous component was an independent predictor of overall survival (OS) (p=0.02); age >70 yrs was not. There were no differences in progression free survival (PFS) (p=0.86) or OS (p=0.3) among patients with stage I/II disease who received C+I, T+I or CP+T. Among patients with stage III/IV disease, PFS and OS were improved in those who received I (44.0 vs 17.0 mo, p = 0.03/74.3 vs 29.0 mo, p=0.02).CONCLUSIONS:Ifosfamide-based regimens may be associated with improved PFS/OS in patients with advanced uterine CS. This advantage is not apparent in patients with early-stage disease. Integration of the vaginal microbiome with urinary NMR data facilitated identification of urinary metabolites whose concentration correlates with the presence of specific bacterial classes. CONCLUSIONS: Our data reveal disparate vaginal microbiomes exist in PPROM indicating differing underlying pathologies and thus the need for targeted treatment strategies. Urinary metabolic profiling may provide an effective method for stratifying PPROM patients based upon their vaginal microbiome. TABREF285.text: Despite three-fold differences between maternal plasma insulin values (lean 7.1±1.3 uU/mL vs obese 22.9±4.6 uU/mL, P=0.01), maternal CSF insulin levels were similar between the groups (lean 0.61±.05 uU/mL vs obese 0.63±.05 uU/mL, P=0.85). The ratio of maternal plasma:CSF insulin was significantly higher in obese women (lean 11.8±2.0 vs obese 39.0±9.6, P=0.03). Maternal plasma glucose values were similar between the groups (lean 81±2.5 mg/dL vs obese 78.8±8.7 mg/dL, P=0.83) while CSF glucose values were marginally different (lean 48±1.1 mg/dL vs obese 53±1.8 mg/dL, P=0.05). There were no differences in cord insulin and glucose levels between the groups. CONCLUSIONS: We show for the first time that the ratio of maternal plasma:CSF insulin is significantly increased in obese compared to lean pregnant women, suggesting that obesity may be associated with a relative reduction in net delivery of insulin to the CNS. Our findings are consistent with observations in the literature amongst non-pregnant obese individuals and may have implications for increased understanding of the central effects of insulin on weight gain during pregnancy and the puerperium. TABREF286.text: inhibit plasma kallikrein, and also factors XIIa and XIa. Its activity has been shown to be significantly lower in pregnancy and labor than in the nonpregnant state. The purpose of this study was to determine C1INH activity levels in amniotic fluid embolism (AFE). METHODS: C1INH activity levels were measured and compared between 106 cases at the onset of AFE in which 85 cases were nonfatal, 21 cases were fatal, and 88 cases were normal after delivery. Furthermore, a series of C1INH activity levels were measured in one survivor of AFE and one case that died of AFE. Two pregnant women defined as AFE had low C1INH activity levels even before the onset of AFE; however, C1INH activity levels in the survivor significantly recovered after early replacement therapy. CONCLUSIONS: These results demonstrated that low C1INH activity levels are closely associated with the pathogenesis of AFE, which suggests that C1INH activity levels have potential as a prognosis factor of AFE.
