TABREF430.text: In decidua of RM respect to EA patients, the significantly diminished FoxP3 mRNA levels could account for a paucity of Tregs and, together with IL-10 mRNAlower expression, lead to reduction of the immunosuppressive functions. The suppressive ability of regulatory T cells occurs through several mechanisms. Suppression by Tregs primarily requires cell-cell contact whereas Tr1 act mainly by the release of IL-10. Our results allow us to hypothesize that the first suppressive mechanism may fail for the small number of FoxP3 + cells. The decreased IL-10 production could depend, at least in part, by reduced presence or function of Tr1, which exert their immunosuppressive activity mainly through this cytokine. This might alter the decidual immune homeostasis, causing susceptibility to pregnancy loss.The Effects of Advanced Maternal Age on Placental Morphology and Function. Samantha C Lean, Linda Peacock, Jane Boscolo-Ryan, Alexander EP Heazell, Tracey Mills, Rebecca L Jones. Maternal and Fetal Health Research Centre, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Advanced maternal age (AMA; >35 years)is associated with an increased risk of fetal growth restriction (FGR) and stillbirth. The aetiology is unknown; however these pregnancies are closely linked to placental dysfunction. Aberrant placental nutrient transport, hormone production, syncytial nuclear aggregate (SNA) formation and cell turnover are hallmarks of placentas from FGR pregnancies. Whether AMA affects placental development and function has not been investigated. We hypothesised that placentas from AMA pregnancies have altered placental morphology and function that leads to increased risk of poor outcome. METHODS: Placentas were collected from normal singleton pregnancies of 20-30 (control), 35-39 and ≥40 year old women (n=15 per group). Placental morphology was assessed by quantification of SNAs using standard histological techniques. Immunostaining quantified capillary number in terminal villi (CD31) and cell turnover for number of proliferating nuclei (Ki67). Placental nutrient transport was assessed by uptake of 14C-MeAIB and 3H-Taurine via System A and TauT respectively in fresh villous tissue. Secretion of placental hormones (progesterone, PAPP-A, hCG and hPL) was measured in 28 and 36 week maternal serum by ELISA (20-30y n=26, 35-39y n=29, ≥40y n=25). RESULTS: Higher placental uptake via System A and TauT was detected in women ≥40 compared to those aged 20-30 years (linear regression, p>0.05). Production of placental hormones was unaffected by maternal age. The number of SNA's increased in placentas from women ≥35 years compared to controls (p<0.05). Villous Ki67 positive nuclei appeared to decrease with increasing maternal age, but not significantly (Kruskal-Wallis, p=0.204). Number of vessels per villi and number of avascular villi did not differ with age. CONCLUSIONS: These data provide evidence of aberrant placental function and morphology in placentas from AMA pregnancies. Ageing is associated with increased systemic inflammation and oxidative stress factors which have been found to increase system A and TauT activity. Increased SNAs indicates either increased placental pathology or accelerated ageing in placentas from older mothers compared to younger counterparts matched for gestation and outcome. An aged maternal environment may be responsible for these placental effects. Understanding the mechanisms underlying AMA and pregnancy complications may help improve outcome for these women.Seminal Plasma Fructose Assay Revisited. Brian A Levine, Daniel Ryan, Sinem Karipcin, Queenie V Neri, Zev Rosenwaks, Gianpiero D Palermo. The Ronald O. Perelman & Claudia Cohen Center for Reproductive Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: Seminal plasma fructose is the main carbohydrate energy source of spermatozoa and is secreted by the seminal vesicles and the accessory sex glands which are responsive to FSH & LH.In men with severely compromised sperm parameters, fructose may elucidate male genital tract patency and function. In this study we assessed seminal plasma fructose as a biochemical adjuvant to the standard semen analysis when interpreting sperm attributes, specifically in crypto-/azoo-spermia. METHODS: Patients undergoing male infertility screening were included in the study. After liquefaction, semen parameters such as volume, concentration, motility, and morphology were assessed according to WHO parameters (2010). The specimens were centrifuged and the cell-void seminal plasma was assessed for fructose concentration with a commercial kit (Abcam, ab83380, Cambridge, Mass.). The optical density was measured with a computerized microplate reader. The final fructose concentration was obtained from the linear regression of the standard curve. All P values were two-sided with statistical significance evaluated at the 0.05 alpha level. RESULTS: Eighteen patients were enrolled in the study and had a mean seminal volume of 3.8±1.2 mL, concentration of 48.6±26.5 x 10 6 , motility of 48.6±7.6%, normal morphology of 3.4±0.9% and a fructose concentration of 5.1±2.9 mg/mL. When sperm parameters were plotted against fructose concentration, an inverse trend was identified for sperm concentration and morphology. No clear difference was noted for those with oligo-(5.3±3.1 vs. 4.4±2.2 mg/mL), astheno-(5.2±2.8 vs. 4.5±3.8 mg/mL) or terato-spermia (4.8±3.3 vs 5.4±2.5 vs mg/mL). However, a significant difference in fructose level was noted when a threshold sperm concentration of 65x 10 6 was used (3.1±0.7 vs. 5.9±3 mg/mL; P=0.006).When fructose values were adjusted on a per-sperm basis, patients with the most abnormal sperm attributes had a higher value (167±75.4 vs. 625.2±133.9).

TABREF431.text: and Regulation of the TETs in the Human Endometrium during the Menstrual Cycle. Philip C Logan, 1 Anna P Ponnampalm, 1,2 Zoe L Vincent, 1 Murray D Mitchell. 3 1 The Liggins Institute, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; 2 Gravida, National Centre for Growth and Development, Auckland, New Zealand; 3 Centre for Clinical Research, University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia. INTRODUCTION: DNA methylation may have a role in regulating decidualization of human endometrial stromal cells because the three main DNA methyltransferases(DNMTs), DNMT1, 3A, and 3B are dynamically regulated in a time-dependent manner by estradiol, progesterone, and cyclic AMP during decidualization. Recently, the TET hydroxylases of TET1, 2, 3, the mechanism of active DNA demethylation that converts methylated cytosine to hydroxy-methylcytosine (and back to cytosine), have been studied in development and cancer progression. The aim of this study was to characterise the expression of TET1, 2, 3 in the endometrium during the menstrual cycle, to determine the effect of the steroid hormones and cyclic AMP (cAMP) on TET1, 2, 3, during decidualization, and to investigate DNA hydroxymethylation. METHODS: Endometrial tissue biopsies from women of reproductive age with regular menstrual cycles were collected following informed consent. The human endometrial stromal cell-line (HESC) was treated with estradiol, medroxy-progesterone acetate (MPA), and dibutyryl cAMP in a time-course. Expression of TETs was characterised by real-time quantitative PCR.

TABREF432.text: Zaher Merhi, 1 Alex J Polotsky, 2 Andrew P Bradford, 2 Erkan Buyuk, 3 Justin Chosich, 2 Tzu Phang, 2 Sangita Jindal, 3 Nanette Santoro. 2 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, University of Vermont College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA; 2 Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility, University of Colorado, Denver, USA; 3 Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, USA. INTRODUCTION:Obesity is associated with ovarian intrafollicular alterations at multiple cellular levels including steroidogenic and inflammatory pathways. We hypothesize that granulosa cell (GC) dysfunction contributes to abnormal follicular maturation and subsequent corpus luteum dysfunction in obese women, and that overweight and obese women have altered GC gene expression compared to normal weight women. METHODS: 8 reproductive-aged women who underwent controlled ovarian hyperstimulation followed by oocyte retrieval for in vitro fertilization were enrolled. Total RNA was extracted from GCs. For microarray analysis, biotinylated cRNA probes were hybridized to Human Genome U133 Plus 2.0 chips. The chips were washed and stained using the Affymetrix Fluidics Station 400 Microarray analysis. Gene expression data were validated on GCs from biologically similar samples using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Comparisons were made between women with body mass index (BMI)<25 kg/m2 (Group 1; n=4) or ≥25 kg/m2 (Group 2; n=4). RESULTS: Groups 1 and 2 had different BMI (21.4 ±1.4 vs. 30.4±2.7 kg/ m 2 respectively; p=0.02) but did not differ in age (30.5±1.7 vs. 32.7±0.3 years respectively; p=0.3). Comparative analysis of gene expression profiles by supervised clustering between Group 1 vs. Group 2 resulted in the selection of 8 differentially expressed genes: GAS7, SMAD6, FGF-12, PPM1L, IL1RL, ZFPM2, FOXM1, and CDC20. GAS7, CDC20 and FOXM1 were down-regulated while FGF-12, PPM1L, and IL1RL1 were up-regulated in Group 2 when compared to Group 1. As BMI increased, FOXM1 expression significantly decreased (r= 0.61, p=0.049). Validation with RT-PCR confirmed the microarray data. CONCLUSIONS: This study suggests that alterations in GCs are present in overweight and obese women. Adiposity is associated with changes in the expression of genes important for cellular growth, cell cycle progression, inflammation and proto-oncogenic changes. The upregulation of the metabolic regulator gene PPM1L suggests that adiposity induces an abnormal metabolic follicular environment, hence altering folliculogenesis. Future studies will focus on the analysis of protein products from these genes.Effect of Octanoic Acid on Timing of Mouse EmbryoDevelopment and Expression of Viability Genes. Dean E Morbeck, 1 Melissa Paczkowski, 2 Jolene R Fredrickson, 3 Rebecca L Krisher. 2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA; 2 Fertility Research Laboratory, National Foundation for Fertility Research, Lone Tree, CO, USA; 3 Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA. INTRODUCTION:Octanoic acid (OA), a stabilizer added to human serum albumin (HSA), disrupts energy metabolism and induces oxidative damage in several cell types. We have previously reported lot-to-lot variation of OA in IVF-grade HSA and effects on mouse embryos(Leonard  et al., 2013). Studies with other cell types demonstrate effects of OA at concentrations that are currently used for embryo culture; however, the effect of OA at low concentrations that do not overtly affect blastocyst development has not been determined. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of OA on embryo development and gene expression using concentrations of OA that are commonly used for IVF. METHODS: One-cell mouse embryos from superovulated FVB mice mated with CF1 males were cultured in an EmbryoScope (5% O2, Global media) with recombinant albumin (AlbIX) containing 0 (control), 400 uM (OA400), 800 uM (OA800) and 1200 uM OA (OA1200). Variables measured included cell division kinetics, blastocyst development and expression of 8 viability genes after 96h of culture. RESULTS: Although blastocyst development was reduced (p<0.001) by OA1200 compared to control, OA400 and OA800 (39.4 vs 83.3, 71.0 and 71.9%, respectively), lower concentrations of OA affected precompaction embryo development. The length of the second cell cycle increased with increasing concentrations of OA (22.7±1.6, 23.7±2.1, 26.2±3.7* and 27.9±3.7* h; *p<0.001), resulting in a significant delay at the 4-cell (36.0±1.9, 38.2±3.0, 41.0±4.9*, 43.1±6.3* h; *p<0.001) and8-cell stage (47.2±2.6, 49.7±3.8, 52.9±5.3*, 55.9±9.3* h; p<0.001). Only Cox2 expression was affected by treatment, with a 2.8-fold increase for OA400 relative to the control (p=0.028). CONCLUSIONS: Most clinics use HSA at 5-10 mg/ml, which corresponds to 400-800 uM OA. Using OA-free recombinant albumin, we show that clinically relevant concentrations of OA delay development by prolonging early cell cycles. These delays are not always manifest in lower blastocyst development and thus would not be detected by standard quality control assays. Time-lapse data of early cell cycle duration is more sensitive as a quality control measure and provides a model for studying culture-induced alterations at cell-specific stages of preimplantation development.Proteomic Regulation of hsa-miR-30d Over-Expression in HumanEndometrial Epithelial Cells (hEEC). Sara J Mucowski, 1 Christine Marion, 2 Ying Liu, 2 Kristin Bendikson, 1 Frank Z Stanczyk, 1 Louis Dubeau. 2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Keck School of Medicine of USC, Los Angeles, CA, USA; 2 Pathology, Keck School of Medicine of USC, Los Angeles, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION:The determinants of several events associated with ovarian follicular development, including stimulation of primordial follicles, follicular growth, and regression, are largely unknown. We sought to test the hypothesis that olfactory receptors may play a role in these processes by documenting their presence in human ovarian granulosa cells. Indeed, disorders of embryologic neuronal migration can cause reproductive disorders at the level of the hypothalamus, e.g., Kallman's Syndrome, where GnRH and olfactory neurons exhibit migratory failure resulting in infertility and anosmia. Olfactory receptors have been discovered in several tissues outside of the olfactory bulb. Activation of such receptors in prostate cancer cells decreases cellular proliferation. Olfactory receptors in spermatozoa play a role in their chemotaxis. METHODS: Luteinized human granulosa cells were collected from the USC Fertility Clinic after ovarian hyperstimulation for in vitro fertilization. Ovarian tissue was obtained from a teenaged organ donor.

TABREF437.text: the Role of Myometrial Matrix Metalloproteinases and Their Tissue Inhibitors during Gestation and Term Labour. Tina Tu-Thu N Nguyen, 1,2 Oksana Shynlova, 1,3 Stephen J Lye. 1,2,3 1 Lunenfeld-Tanenbaum Research Institute, Mount Sinai Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada; 2 Department of Physiology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada; 3 Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada. INTRODUCTION:We have shown earlier that uterine growth during pregnancy is accompanied by the increase in expression of multiple extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins in uterine smooth muscle, myometrium. We also reported that in vivo mechanical stretch of the uterine wall by the growing fetus(es) can modulate expression of ECM components during gestation. We hypothesize that myometrial ECMdegrading matrix metalloproteinases' (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of MMPs' (TIMPs) expression/activity is modulated during gestation, term labour (TL) and post-partum (PP) involution period. METHODS: Myometrial tissues were collected from normal bilaterally pregnant and unilaterally pregnant rats throughout gestation, TL and PP. Total RNA was extracted from gravid and non-gravid uterine horns and subjected to real-time RT-PCR analysis for MMP1-3, 7-13 and TIMP1-4. Total proteins were extracted and used for zymography, ELISA and western blot analysis. RESULTS: mRNA levels for MMP1, 2, 8-13 were low during most of gestation, slightly elevated one day prior to labour (d22), decreased during labour (d23L) and significantly induced during PP period (p<0.05). Expression of MMP7 was transiently up-regulated on d22, culminated during labour (p<0.001), and decreased PP. TIMP1-4 expressions were unchanged throughout gestation and TL. A similar trend for all MMPs/ TIMPs genes was observed in the gravid uterine horn of unilaterally pregnant rats, however very low expressions were detected in the non-gravid horn. In accordance with gene expression results gelatin zymography demonstrated an increase in MMP2 activity during PP period. Our preliminary analysis of MMP7 and MMP8 protein expression showed elevated levels during early and mid-gestation and a decrease at late gestation, TL and PP. In contrast, MMP11 protein expression was steadily increased throughout gestation and culminated during TL. CONCLUSIONS: Our gene expression data are consistent with MMPs and TIMPs playing a role in the remodeling of myometrial tissue to prepare the uterus for labour contractions and PP involution. Biological mechanical stretch of the uterine wall by the growing fetus can modulate the expression of MMPs and contribute to myometrial remodeling during late pregnancy and labour.Identification and Characterization of Membrane ProgesteroneReceptors in Fetal Membranes: Implications for PPROM and Preterm Birth. Peter Thomas, 1 Yefei Pang, 1 Jing Dong, 1 Serkalem Tadesse, 2 Victoria Snegovskikh, 3 Errol R Norwitz. 4 1 Marine Science Institute, University of Texas at Austin, Port Aransas, TX, USA; 2 Ob/ Gyn, Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA; 3 Ob/Gyn, Brown University, Providence, RI, USA; 4 Ob/Gyn, Tufts University, Boston, MA, USA. INTRODUCTION:Recent studies have shown that progesterone (P 4 ) supplementation can prevent preterm birth (PTB) in some patients at high risk due to a prior PTB or cervical shortening. Since supplementation does not alter circulating P 4 levels and endogenous levels of P 4 in pregnancy far exceed the Kd of the nuclear progesterone receptor (nPR), the mechanism by which P 4 supplementation works is not clear. We have previously shown that P 4 can prevent apoptosis in fetal membranes and may thereby prevent PPROM-related PTB(Luo et al. Reprod Sci 2010;17:532), which accounts for one-third of all preterm deliveries. Here, we investigate the expression and functional characteristics of membrane PRs (mPRs) in fetal membranes. METHODS: Fetal membranes were collected from uncomplicated elective cesarean deliveries at term (n=5). Expression of nPR (PR-A, PR-B), mPR (mPRa, mPRb), and progesterone receptor membrane component 1 (PGRMC1) protein and mRNA were examined by Western blot and RT-qPCR, respectively, using specific antibodies. Cells stably transfected with the various mPRs were used as positive controls. [ 3 H]-P 4 binding analysis was performed using cell membrane preparations from fetal membranes. Saturation and competition experiments as well as Scatchard plot analysis were used to characterize the binding sites. RESULTS: Western blot analysis showed the presence of PR-A (50kD), PR-B (100kD), mPRa

Christine M O'Brien, 1 Jennifer Herrington, 2 Elizabeth Vargis, 3 Naoko Brown, 2 Bibhash C Paria, 2 Jeffrey Reese, 2 Anita Mahadevan-Jansen. 1 1 Biomedical Engineering, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, USA; 2 Pediatrics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TN, USA; 3 Biological Engineering, Utah State University, Logan, UT, USA.

TABREF439.text: PAMPs stimulate TLR2 and TLR4; and viral stimulate TLR3 and TLR7. These studies sought to evaluate the synergistic effects of stimulation by bacterial plus viral PAMPs. METHODS: Day 15 pregnant CD-1 mice were injected intraperitoneal with combinations of LPS (TLR4 agonist) and poly I:C (TLR3 agonist), peptidoglycan (PGN, TLR2 agonist) and poly I:C, or LPS and imiquimod (IMQ, TLR7 agonist), The uteri were harvested at 2, 4, 8 or 18 hrs later. The tissue was placed in RNAlater (for mRNA studies) or snap frozen (for ELISA assays). Total RNA was isolated using Trizol reagent; and genomic DNA was removed using TURBO DNA-free. cDNA was prepared using the RT2 First Strand Kit. QPCR reactions were prepared with RT2 SYBR qPCR Master Mix and analyzed using a Mouse TLR Signaling Pathway Array (. Real time analysis was performed on an ABI Prism 7900HT Sequence Detection System. Data was analyzed using the SABioscience data analysis website. RESULTS: The combination of bacterial and viral PAMPs resulted in a more than additive synergistic TLR response with significantly increased production of several proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines.At 2 hours after injection, LPS alone produced a 259 fold increase in MCP1 mRNA expression vs. LPS plus poly I:C = 463 fold increase. For IP-10, LPS alone = 723 fold increase vs. LPS plus poly I:C = 3,145 fold increase; and for IL6, LPS alone = 1,059 fold increase vs. LPS plus poly I:C = 11,492 fold increase. The combinations of PGN plus poly I:C and LPS plus IMQ also resulted in markedly increased synergistic responses. ELISA assays to quantify protein expression are currently underway. CONCLUSIONS: Concurrent systemic viral and bacterial infections often result in PTD. Our studies have demonstrated a marked synergistic proinflammatory response to viral and bacterial PAMPs within the mouse uterus. This response would enhance intrauterine inflammation and result in PTD. (Funded: March of Dimes Foundation 21-FY07-592 and the MGH VCRB). TABREF440.text: Human Labor Is Accompanied by Enhanced Expression of PAR1, but Not PAR3 in Decidual Cells. A Puri, UA Kayisli, S Tabak, O Guzeloglu-Kayisli, J Shapiro, F Schatz, CJ Lockwood. Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Ohio State University, College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA. INTRODUCTION: During decidualization, progesterone (P4)induces endometrial stromal cells to express tissue factor (TF), the primary mediator of hemostasis via thrombin (TH) generation. During pregnancy, decidual cells (DCs) express elevated TF levels. TH also induces inflammation by binding to protease activated receptors (PARs). Previously, we found that abruption (decidual hemorrhage), a leading cause of preterm birth (PTB) triggers functional P4 withdrawal via TH/ PAR mediated inhibition of decidual cell progesterone receptor (PRA and PRB) levels. Thus, we postulate that TH is an autocrine/paracrine factor that acts via PARs to promote labor-related functional P4 withdrawal. METHODS: Serial decidua basalis sections from gestational-age matched pre-laboring (n=9) vs laboring (n=9) uterus were immunostained for PAR1 or PAR3, or the DC and interstitial trophoblast (IT) markers vimentin and cytokeratin. The results were analyzed by histologic scoring system (HSCORE). RT-PCR measured PAR1 and PAR3 levels in RNA extracts from cultured leukocyte-free term DCs (n=3) treated with E 2 ± medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA). RESULTS: Immunohistochemical staining found that DCs and adjacent ITs express PAR1 and PAR3. DC PAR1 expression is significantly higher in labor (HSCORE Mean ± SEM 113.8 ± 13.7) vs non-laboring specimens (65.8 ±17.3;p<0.05). Increased immunostaining for PAR3 in DCs of labor vs non-laboring specimens was observed but did not attain statistical significance. In contrast with DCs, neither PAR1 nor PAR3 HSCORES differed in ITs from laboring vs non-laboring specimens. In term DC monolayers, PAR1 and PAR3 mRNA expression was significantly decreased in DCs treated with E 2 +MPA (0.46 ± 0.10 and 0.38 ± 0.07, respectively; p<0.006 and p<0.002) vs E 2 alone (1.03 ± 0.04 and 1.03 ± 0.04, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: Previously, we showed that at the maternal-fetal interface at term, DCs are the highest expressors of thrombin generating TF and excess thrombin generated during abruption associated PTB inhibits PRA and PRB in DCs to induce functional P4 withdrawal. The current study reveals that: 1) the PAR1 and 3 thrombin receptors increase in DCs in labor vs non-laboring specimens. 2) progestin decreases PAR1 and 3 expression in cultured term DCs. Taken together, these observations suggest the steady state generation of thrombin acting on DC expressed PAR1 and 3 contribute to labor related functional P4 withdrawal.Na + Leak Channel Non-Selective (NALCN) Contributes to Leak Current in Human MyometrialSmooth Muscle Cells. TABREF442.text: Caspase-3 Activity Isolated to the Nerves of the Human and MousePregnant Cervix Upregulates ECM Remodeling. Caroline Rieser, 1,2 Michael D House, 3 Steve Caritis, 1 Jeyasuria Pancharatnam, 1 Jennifer Conddon. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, MWRI University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; 2 Physician Scientist Training Program, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; 3 Mother Infant Research Institute, Tufts Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA.INTRODUCTION: Proteolytic remodeling of the cervical stromal extracellular matrix (ECM) underlies cervical ripening in both term and preterm labor. Previously we have shown that myometrial caspase-3 (CASP3) plays a role in regulating gestational length via cleavage of myocyte contractile architecture in a non-apoptotic manner. In this study we demonstrate that non-apoptotic CASP3 activation isolated to the peripheral nerves of the pregnant cervical stroma initiates local stromal collagen turnover via proteolytic cleavage. METHODS: Cervical samples isolated from pregnant mice at gestational day 10-19 and pregnant women at 36 weeks gestation were analyzed for CASP3 and anti-apoptotic proteins using Western blot, TUNEL assay, immunohistochemistry (IHC), and electron microscopy (EM).To determine the effect of CASP3 on collagen turnover, we utilized a 3D primary culture model of human cervical stromal cells isolated from pregnant women. CASP3 positive cervical stromal cells introduced to the 3D cultured cervical stromal cell model were assessed for their capacity to initiate local cervical stromal ECM remodeling. RESULTS: Western blot analysis revealed elevated cervical CASP3 levels at mid-gestation which decline towards term. IHC analysis revealed robust active CASP3 isolated to the peripheral nerves in both the human and mouse cervix. EM analysis defined that the peripheral nerve CASP3 activity was limited to the outer membrane of cervical nerve axons. IHC analysis revealed local ECM remodeling surrounding to the nerves containing active CASP3. Analysis of our 3D model confirmed the capacity of non apoptotic CASP3 positive cells to initiate collagen cleavage into the mature stromal matrix. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates a distinct localization and regulation of CASP3 in the murine and human cervix during pregnancy. While remaining non-apoptotic, CASP3 is associated with the disruption of local collagen. Previous studies show upregulation in cervical innervation during gestation. We propose that activation of cervical CASP3 may initiate local collagen remodeling and disruption of the cervical stromal extracellular matrix thereby allowing in growth of nerves into the cervix during gestation.Essential Role for Macrophages in Late Gestation Pregnancy to Prevent Spontaneous Preterm Birth inMice. Rachel E Sheldon, 1 Andrew M Blanks, 2 Anatoly Shmygol, 2 Hugo A van den Berg. 3 1 MOAC Doctoral Training Centre, University of Warwick, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom; 2 Division of Reproductive Health, Warwick Medical School, CSRL, University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom; 3 Systems Biology, University of Warwick, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION:The myometrium undergoes profound changes in global excitability in preparation to parturition. These changes are infl uenced by spatial variations in the excitability of individual cells as well as the strength of their interconnections. Our previous work has shown that spatial heterogeneity is critical to enhancing global excitability of the uterine muscle (J. R. Soc. Interface, Sept. 2013). We now investigate the effects of voltage-dependent gap junctions on the excitability of the myometrial network. METHODS: A mathematical model of a myocyte network was developed. Each node of the network obeys FitzHugh-Nagumo dynamics and neighbours are coupled through resistors representing gap junctions. This model is elaborated here by incorporating gap-junctional conductance as a function of voltage difference between neighbouring cells, and by subsequently introducing spatial heterogeneity in cell connections. TABREF447.text: FSH Receptor in Extra-Gonadal Reproductive Tissues andPlacentae. Julie AW Stilley, 1 Debora E Christensen, 1 Kristin B Dahlem, 1 Ayman Al-Hendy, 3 Patricia A Kirby, 2 Deborah L Segaloff. 1 1 Molecular Biophysics and Physiology, University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine, Iowa City, IA, USA; 2 Pathology, University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine, Iowa City, IA, USA; 3 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Meharry Medical Center, Nashville, TN, USA. INTRODUCTION: Follicle stimulating hormone receptor (FSHR) hastraditionally been thought to act solely on gonadal tissues. However, recent studies report FSHR in extra-gonadal tissues such as bone, suggesting additional actions. We hypothesize that FSHR is present in extra-gonadal reproductive tissues and in placenta and that signaling through placental FSHR is necessary for normal placental and fetal development. METHODS: Human placentae from different stages of gestation and extra-gonadal reproductive tissues were immunostained for FSHR. Mouse placentae and fetuses heterozygous and homozygous for knock-out of the Fshr gene were compared to their wild-type littermates at midgestation. RESULTS: In non-pregnant women, endometrial FSHR localization differed between proliferative and secretory phases. Cervical smooth muscle also expressed FSHR. Myometrial smooth muscle expressed FSHR, but much less than myometrium from pregnant (term) women. In human placentae, FSHR was expressed in endothelial cells of chorionic villi, umbilical vein and artery, and amnion throughout pregnancy. FSHR expression in decidua occurred in distinct patterns throughout pregnancy especially near remodeling maternal blood vessels. In mice, fetuses and placentae lacking the Fshr gene were smaller than wild-type littermates and fewer number than predicted by Mendelian inheritance. CONCLUSIONS: FSHR is expressed in non-gonadal reproductive tissue in women. FSHR in myometrium of pregnant women may play a role in timing of birth. FSHR is expressed in endothelial cells and other layers of the placenta as early as 8 weeks of gestation (earliest time point examined) and throughout pregnancy. Decidual FSHR may play a role in coordinating maternal blood vessel remodeling. Finally, there are functional ramifications of the Fshr fetoplacental gene status on the developing fetus and placenta of mice. Further experiments should be performed to investigate these facets of extra-gonadal actions of FSHR on female reproductive physiology in non-pregnant and pregnant states.

TABREF448.text: Inflammatory Effect of the Cationic Host Defence Peptide LL-37 on Cervical Epithelia. Lorraine Frew, 1 Donald J Davidson, 2 Jane E Norman, 1 Sarah J Stock. 1 1 MRC Centre for Reproductive Health, University of Edinburgh Queen's Medical Research Institute, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; 2 MRC Centre for Inflammation, University of Edinburgh Queen's Medical Research Institute, Edinburgh, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: is an antimicrobial peptide with immunomodulatory functions that may have a role in inflammatory events associated with preterm parturition. We have previously shown that LL-37 is a component of cervicovaginal secretions. The aim of this study was to investigate whether cervicovaginal levels of LL-37 change in association with bacterial vaginosis and to determine the effect of LL-37 on release of cytokines (IL-8 and IL-6) by cervical epithelial cells. METHODS: 130 primiparous women with uncomplicated singleton pregnancies were recruited at 11-14 weeks gestation. Self-collected samples of cervicovaginal secretions were analysed by ELISA for LL-37. Bacterial vaginosis was diagnosed using Nugent's Criteria. Cell lines derived from cervical epithelium (END E6/E7 cells from endocervix; ECT E6/E7 cells from ectocervix) were incubated with LL-37 or controls (media, scrambled LL-37, or D enantiomer LL-37) +/-receptor antagonists. IL-8 and IL-6 were measured in cell culture supernatants by ELISA. RESULTS: LL-37 was detected in 79 of 130 samples (median 0.3 ng/ ml). LL-37 concentration was higher in samples from women with bacterial vaginosis than in women with normal flora (median 0.35 ng/ml IQR 0.2-1 ng/ml, compared to 0.2 ng/ml IQR 0.12-0.45 ng/ml, p<0.01).

INTRODUCTION:There are minimal ultrastructural data available which are specific to the human myometrium and less so to the pregnant state. This study has employed stereological methods to quantify mitochondria in the smooth muscle cells in the human myometrium. There is an increased risk of cesarean section and dysfunctional labor associated with advanced maternal age for which there is no clear mechanism or explanation. METHODS: Myometrial biopsies were collected from 30 women undergoing elective cesarean section with informed consent and institutional ethical approval. Tissue was processed for transmission electron microscopy and analyzed using stereological methods.TheRESULTS:Between January 2009 and December 2011, 12,540 women were screened. We could link outcome data in 6,799 women of whom 137 (2.5%) had a CL ≤30 mm.Overall 5.9% of the women had a spontaneous preterm birth, while delivery rates before 34, 32 and 28 weeks of gestation were,1.6%, 0.90 % and 0.50% respectively.The likelihood ratios of short CL for delivery before 37, 34, 32, 28 weeks of gestation were 5.0 (95% CI 3.1-7.9), 9.2 (95% CI 5.2-16.1), 9.0 (95% CI 4.4-18.4) and 12.3 (95% CI 5.9-25.8) respectively.When using a cut-off of 30 mm, the sensitivity of CL measurement was 7.5% (22/293) for a specifi city of 98.5%.Table 1. Spontaneous preterm births per cervical length category (% of total). CONCLUSIONS: Among low risk pregnant women in The Netherlands, the sensitivity of CL measurement to predict preterm birth is very limited. Women with a short cervix, however, are at increased risk for preterm birth.

TABREF452.text: Undergoing Opioid-Maintenance Therapy. Veronica Maria Pimentel, Camellia Banerjee, Kelley Saia. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Boston University Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA. INTRODUCTION:The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology and the National Institutes of Health recommends initiating opioid maintenance therapy (OMT) to all pregnant women with opioid dependence to decrease the potential detrimental effects of illicit drug use in pregnancy. OMT can be achieved using either methadone (MTD) or buprenorphine (BPN). MTD has the risk of prolonging QTc intervals and leading to torsades de pointes. Women have a slightly higher QTc interval than men at baseline and thus are at a greater risk for arrhythmia. In addition, pregnancy prolongs QTc. Therefore, there remains a question of whether or not MTD maintenance therapy might further prolong QTc intervals in pregnant women and increase their risk of torsades. To date, there have been no studies assessing the QTc interval in pregnant women who are opioid dependent. The objectives of this study is to assess the QTc interval in pregnant women who are opioid-dependent and compare the change in the QTc interval prior to initiation of therapy to that at late pregnancy. METHODS: This study is a retrospective chart review of pregnant women who were started on OMT at Boston University Medical Center Early Pregnancy Dyslipidemia and Hypoadiponectinemia Are Risk Factors for Gestational Diabetes. Vanessa I Ramirez, Evelyn Miller, Theresa L Powell. Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: The incidence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is greater in obese mothers and GDM is associated with a range of adverse outcomes in the mother and the fetus. For example, GDM is linked to fetal overgrowth and children of GDM mothers are more susceptible to develop diabetes, hypertension and obesity. There is a clear need for early identification of women who will develop GDM in order to improve pregnancy outcomes. Adiponectin (ADN) is an insulinsensitizing hormone and is inversely correlated with body mass index (BMI). We have previously found a strong inverse correlation between maternal serum ADN and insulin sensitivity at 26 weeks gestation. This data suggests that low ADN contributes to the development of GDM and may explain the high rate of GDM in obese mothers. We hypothesized that low ADN in early pregnancy is predictive for the development of GDM. METHODS: We enrolled 70 women at 8-12 weeks gestation and measured serum metabolic parameters. At delivery we reviewed clinical records to determine pregnancy and neonatal outcomes. RESULTS: To date, 39 subjects have completed the study with term delivery. Women who were later diagnosed with GDM (n=6) had significantly higher A1C (P<0.02) in first trimester and lower ADN ratio (high molecular weight (HMW)/total) (P<0.05) compared to women who remained healthy during pregnancy (n=33). In women who later developed GDM, there were strong trends for higher triglycerides (TG, P=0.077), VLDL (P=0.074) and lower HMW ADN (P=0.062) in first trimester. Infants of GDM mothers had significantly higher ponderal index (P<0.05) with no change in birth weight compared to healthy mothers. In all subjects (n=70), first trimester maternal TG levels were inversely correlated with ADN (R=-0.361, P<0.01) and positively correlated with maternal waist/hip ratio (R=0.354, P<0.01), but not body mass index (BMI). Maternal A1C was negatively correlated with maternal ADN (R=-0.264, P<0.03) and HDL (R=-0.239, P<0.05). Maternal total ADN levels in early pregnancy were negatively correlated with BMI (R=-0.40), P<0.001), leptin (R=-0.257, P<0.04), and VLDL (R=-0.356, P<0.01) and positively correlated with HDL (R=0.386, P<0.01). CONCLUSIONS: This preliminary data suggests that low maternal ADN and dyslipidemia in first trimester are linked to the development of insulin resistance and GDM which may prove clinically useful for early identification of women at high risk for GDM.Maternal Body Mass Index (BMI) Impacts Fetal-Placental Size atBirth and Umbilical Cord PO 2 Values: Implications for Regulatory Mechanisms. Stephanie Ruttinger, Hilary Brown, Barbra deVrijer, Bryan S Richardson. Depts of Physiology and Ob/Gyn, Children's Health Research Institute, Western University, London, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Our purpose was to examine linkages between maternal BMI, fetal-placental size at birth and oxygenation, with implications for regulatory mechanisms. METHODS: A tertiary centre Perinatal database was used to obtain birth and placental weight, umbilical cord gases/pH, and other information for all patients with validated pre-pregnant BMI values delivering viable, singleton infants between Jan1999 and Dec 2010 (N=29,212). BMI values were divided into: underweight (UW) <18.5, normal weight (NW) 18.5-24.9, overweight (OW) 25-29.9, and obese >30, while birth weights were divided into: small (SGA) <10%, appropriate (AGA) ≥10% and ≤90%, and large for gestational age (LGA) >90%. Significant BMI and birth weight category effects were adjusted for interactive effects and confounding variables, and used the maternal NW and fetal AGA groups as respective reference groups. INTRODUCTION:Stroke and other cerebral vascular events (CVE) are rare in reproductive age women, but are associated with major morbidity and mortality. Because these events are rare, there are few data on the optimal management of these women during subsequent pregnancies. Our purpose was to compare outcomes in women with CVE who did and did not use anticoagulant therapy during pregnancy. METHODS: Ours was a retrospective cohort of women with CVE from 1999-2012. The treatment group included women who received thromboprophylactic or therapeutic anticoagulation in the first pregnancy after CVE (P1); controls did not receive anticoagulant therapy. RESULTS: Fifty women met inclusion criteria; 17 (32%) were not treated. Eleven women (9 treated, 2 untreated) had their CVE during P1. TABREF455.text: CONCLUSIONS: Salivary cortisol levels after a glucose load may represent an alternative screening test in pregnancy for gestational diabetes mellitus and fetal overgrowth associated with maternal glucose intolerance.Foreign HIV Pregnant Women: Results from the Italian NationalProgram on Surveillance on Antiretroviral Treatment (2007-2012). Valentina Sacchi, 1 Marina Ravizza, 1 Antonella De Pirro, 1 Serena Dalzero, 1 Marco Floridia, 2 Anna Maria Marconi. 1 1 Dpt of Obstetrics and Gynecology -San Paolo Hospital Medical School, University of Milano, Milano, Italy; 2 Dpt Therapeutic Research and Medicines Evaluation, ISS, Roma, Italy. INTRODUCTION:Several studies have shown that the use of health services among pregnant women shows differences according to nationality. For HIV women, timely and adequate prenatal care has additional implications, because HAART, elective cesarean delivery and avoidance of breastfeeding reduce the risk of perinatal transmission. Women from migrant populations represent more than 50% of the reported cases of HIV pregnant women in Italy. Aim:To evaluate differences in pregnancy care, according to nationality, in HIV women in Italy. METHODS: Data from the Italian National Program on Surveillance on Antiretroviral Treatment in Pregnancy were used(period 2007-2012). Student T-test and X-square test were used for statistical analysis. RESULTS: Among 759 women, 55% were of foreign nationality, mostly from Sub-Saharan Africa. Foreign women were younger (31±5 vs 35±6 years, p<0.01) and more frequently acquired HIV infection through sexual transmission (88% vs 79%, p<0.01). They had lower rates of preconception counseling and planning of pregnancy (24% vs 42%, p<0.01), more frequent HIV diagnosis in pregnancy (30% vs 12%, p<0.01) and later antenatal booking (first access before 13w, 65% vs 77%, p<0.05). As a consequence, foreign patients had lower rate of HAART assumption in the 1 st trimester (58% vs 70%,p<0.05) and they more often started their treatment in the 2 nd trimester (39% vs 28%,p<0.05). However, the whole rate of women taking HAART in the 2 nd and 3 rd trimester was similar (97.5% vs 97.1% and 99.2% vs 99.5%, p>0.05); as a result, gestational age at delivery was similar (37+3 vs 37+3w). No differences were observed in AIDS events (0%), mode of delivery (cesarean section rate 96% vs 99% p:0.06) and pregnancy outcome. The rate of perinatal HIV transmission was also comparable (0.8% vs 1.6%, p>0.05). Foreign women had infants with lower mean birthweight, although this difference was not significant (2920±494 vs 2840±449gr).CONCLUSIONS:Our data suggest that foreign HIV pregnant women have lower rates of preconception counseling and a later access to prenatal care. Specific interventions, like increasing the rate of HIV testing before pregnancy, promoting pregnancy planning and assuring the access to specific HIV programs, can lead to an additional improvement in health standards.Preoperative Predictors of Cesarean Section Hemorrhage. Sophia A Scarpelli, Lois E Brustman, Barak M Rosenn, Janelle Faroutan, Kimberly Herrera. Obstetrics and Gynecology, St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, New York, USA. INTRODUCTION: Obesity and hypertension(HTN)  have been recognized for decades as common pre-existing medical conditions associated with gestational diabetes (GDM). We hypothesized there are other metabolically related medical conditions that are frequently present in women diagnosed with GDM. The purpose of this study is to identify the type of medical conditions commonly noted in women with GDM and assess the rate of occurrence in our population. METHODS: Women with GDM enrolled in our Diabetes in Pregnancy Program January 2010 and September 2013. Detailed past and present medical and obstetric history was collected prospectively upon entry. Results were compared a control group of consecutive pregnancies without GDM with similar demographics from the same catchment area. Pre-existing medical conditions were defined as a current or recent history requiring medical treatment. Obesity was defined as BMI ≥ 30. Chi square, Fisher exact test and Student's t-test were used for statistical analysis.

TABREF463.text: Effects of Mode of Delivery and Neonatal Birthweight on the Relationship between Diabetes and Adverse Neonatal Outcomes. Yen N Truong, 1 Sima Parmar, 1 Guibo Xing, 2 Cheryl Walker. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, UC Davis Medical Center, Sacramento, CA, USA; 2 Center for Healthcare Policy and Research, UC Davis, USA. INTRODUCTION:Many studies have shown that neonates born to women with diabetes mellitus (DM) in pregnancy have an increased risk of adverse outcomes, partly attributable to larger neonatal birthweight (BW). What remains unclear are the relative effects of DM, mode of delivery, and BW on these neonatal complications. METHODS: This is a retrospective birth cohort study using the California OSHPD PDD-birth linked database of women who had singleton vertex deliveries between 1/1/2006-12/31/2008. Women were divided into four groups: controls without DM, type I DM (DM1), type II DM (DM2), and gestational DM (GDM). Primary outcome was a neonatal composite including respiratory distress syndrome, hypoglycemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and meconium aspiration syndrome for all deliveries; plus shoulder dystocia, brachial plexus injury and clavicle fracture for vaginal deliveries only. Data were stratified by BW and mode of delivery after Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel testing. Logistic regression models were constructed to assess the relationships between DM and outcomes using appropriate confounders and effect modifiers. RESULTS: Regardless of mode of delivery, neonates born to women with DM1, DM2, or GDM had higher risk of composite adverse outcome; this was largely attributable to an increase in neonatal hypoglycemia(OR  42.25, for cesarean deliveries)

TABREF464.text: Correlation of Genetic Risk Factors for Type II Diabetes with Gestational Diabetes in Women fromHawaii. Johann Urschitz, 1 Hyeong Jun Ahn, 2 John J Chen, 2 Janet M Burlingame. 3 1 ABP, U of Hawaii, JABSOM, Honolulu, HI, USA; 2 Biostatistics Core, U of Hawaii, JABSOM, Honolulu, HI, USA; 3 OBGYN, U of Hawaii, JABSOM, Honolulu, HI, USA. INTRODUCTION:GDM is not only associated with a higher incidence of adult obesity and the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) later in life but also with a predisposition for cardiovascular disease and metabolic disorders. Along with high rates of T2DM, GDM is particularly prevalent in certain minority populations: For example, Asian, Native American, Hispanic and African-American women are at higher risk for GDM than non-Hispanic white women. The local prevalence of T2DM in Hawaii is increasing especially among Asian and Pacific Islander (PI). These groups have demonstrated significantly higher rates of impaired glucose tolerance (15.5%) and T2DM (20.4%) compared to the overall U.S. population. The prevalence of GDM in Hawaii is the highest in Filipino women, followed by Chinese, Japanese and Native Hawaiian/ PI women. We therefore chose to investigate 25 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) previously associated with T2DM in our local pregnant population. METHODS: OpenArray technology (Applied Biosystems) was used to screen maternal DNA for SNPs in women with GDM and ethnically matched non-diabetic controls (PI: 71 GDM and 197 controls; Filipinos: 162 GDM and 395 controls). We evaluated Unadjusted odds ratios (OR) by c² tests, the homogeneity of the unadjusted OR among the 2 ethnic groups by Breslow-Day test and used Mantel-Haenszel to calculate the summary of unadjusted OR. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to further adjust for age, BMI, parity and gravida. RESULTS: After adjustment, four SNPs, KCNQ1 (rs2237892), MTNR1B (rs10830963), SLC30A8 (rs13266634), HHEX (rs1111875) were associated with GDM in Filipinos. MTNR1B was also associated with GDM in PI women. CONCLUSIONS: Few of the genetic polymorphisms previously associated with T2DM were also associated with GDM in Filipino and PI women from Hawaii. Of these, only MTNR1B was associated with GDM in both populations, demonstrating a significant diversion from homogeneity of OR among the two ethnicities. These results suggest that GDM is not a simple unmasking of a T2DM predisposition by the metabolic demands of pregnancy; rather it appears that different biological mechanisms are responsible for the respective diseases.Reproductive Outcomes Are Successful after Cervical Cerclage inWomen with Threatened Preterm Birth. Tessa van Kolfschooten, Olivier WH van der Heijden. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Radboud University Medical Center, Nijmegen, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION: Preterm birth (PTB) is a major determinant of neonatal morbidity and mortality. A cervical length less than 25mm is predictive for PTB, and painless cervical dilatation followed by prolaps of the membranes are suggestive for cervical insufficiency. Transvaginal cervical cerclage (TVCC) is a common therapeutic intervention to prevent threatened PTB occurring in the early second trimester of pregnancy. We determined the effectiveness of ultrasound-indicated (UI) and dilatationindicated (DI) TVCC in women with threatened PTB occurring before 26 weeks of pregnancy by evaluating their respective reproductive outcomes.METHODS:We conducted a retrospective observational study at the department of obstetrics and gynecology of the Radboud University Medical Center Nijmegen (Netherlands) between July 2002 and July 2012. RESULTS: 18 patients were included in the UI group and 10 in the DI group. UI cerclage were placed at 22 (range 16-26) weeks and DI cerclage were placed at 21 (range 17-25) weeks. Cerclage to delivery interval was 15 (range 0-23) weeks and 11 (range 1-19) weeks, resp. Mean gestational age at delivery was 37 (range 16-41) weeks and 32 (range 21-38) weeks, resp. While total births prior to 32 weeks of pregnancy were more frequent in the DI group than in the UI group (50% versus 27,8%, resp.), total neonatal survival was high in both groups(95,2% {95% CI 80,7}  and 75% {95%CI 51,5}, resp.). Pregnancy complications such as PPROM < 32 weeks was more frequent in the DI group than in the UI group (80% vs. 44,4% resp.). CONCLUSIONS: Reproductive outcomes in women undergoing TVCC for threatened PTB are successful. However, women with DI cerclage confer less benefit since 50% delivers before 32 weeks of pregnancy. TVCC remains an important therapeutic option for threatened PTB occurring before 26 weeks of pregnancy.Preventing Preterm Birth with Progesterone (The Triple P TreatStudy): A Randomized Controlled Trial. M van Os, 1 J van der Ven, 2 E Schuit, 2 C Verhoeven, 4 M Haak, 5 E Pajkrt, 2 M Sikkema, 6 M Woiski, 7 C de Groot, 1 B Mol. 2 1 Dept of O/G, VUMC, Amsterdam, Netherlands; 2 Dept of O/G, AMC, Amsterdam, Netherlands; 3 Dept of O/G, MMC, Veldhoven, Netherlands; 4 Dept of O/G, LUMC, Leiden, Netherlands; 5 Dept of O/G, ZHT, Almelo, Netherlands; 6 Dept of O/G, UMCN, Nijmegen, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION: To evaluate the effectiveness of vaginal progesterone in preventing adverse neonatal outcome in low-risk pregnant women with a short cervical length (CL) measured between 18-22 weeks of gestation.METHODS:We performed a multicentre randomised controlled trial (Triple P treat trial NTR-2078) in The Netherlands. Women at low risk for preterm birth (PTB) (women with a singleton pregnancy, without a history of PTB <34 weeks of gestation) underwent CL measurement at 18-22 weeks using transvaginal sonography. Women with a repeated CL ≤30 mm were randomly assigned to use 200mg vaginal capsules progesterone or placebo. Primary outcome was composite adverse neonatal outcome defined as RDS, BPD, IVH II B or worse, NEC, proven sepsis or death before discharge. Secondary outcomes included time to delivery, birth rates <32, 34 and 37 weeks of gestation. The required sample size was 1,920 due to unexpected low prevalence of women with a short cervix, the study was stopped after enrollment of 80 women. Analysis was by intention to treat. RESULTS: Between 2009 and 2013, we randomized 80 women. At the moment of writing, we have outcome data on 74 (93%) of randomized women. Adverse neonatal outcome occurred in 2/39 (5.1%) women in the progesterone group and in 3/35 (8.6%) women in the control group (RR 0.55; 95% CI 0.1-3.1). Progesterone use led to a statistically nonsignificant reduction of delivery rates <32 weeks of gestation (3.0% vs. 9.0%; RR 0.28; 95% CI 0.03-2.6) and 34 weeks of gestation (8.0% vs. 12%; RR 0.64; 95% CI 0.15-2.6), while there was no reduction of PTB <37 weeks of gestation (15% vs. 15%; RR 1.02; 95% CI 0.34-3.03).

TABREF465.text: Does Abdominal Circumference <20th Percentile Predict FetalGrowth Restriction? Luciana A Vieira, 1 Daniel W Skupski, 2 Stephanie N Lin, 3 Gary S Eglinton. 2 1 Department ofObstetrics and Gynecology, New York, NY, USA;  2 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, New York Hospital Queens,  New York, NY, USA; 3  Department of Maternal Fetal Medicine, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Fetuses that develop fetal growth restriction (FGR) show a decline in the growth velocity of the abdominal circumference (AC) as pregnancy progresses. Our study was performed to determine if AC<20th percentile (AC<20%) was predictive of FGR later in pregnancy and small for gestational age (SGA) neonates at birth. METHODS: Retrospective cohort study of fetuses identified between 1/1/2010 and 6/30/2013 with AC <20% between 28 and 42 weeks' gestation. AC, estimated fetal weight (EFW) and birth weight (BW) were categorized by percentile based on Doubilet 1997. Fetuses <10th percentile were considered FGR and neonates <10th percentile for BW were considered SGA. Our practice is to follow FGR at term until another indication for delivery occurs (oligohydramnios, abnormal fetal testing, Doppler testing indicating brain sparing or absent diastolic velocity in the umbilical artery, no growth for 2 weeks). RESULTS: There were 1915 patients who received ultrasound between 28 and 42 weeks in the study period and 620 who met criteria.Maternal mean age was 29.5+5.4, median gestational age (GA) at diagnosis of AC<20% was 33 weeks (IQR 30weeks 3days to 37 weeks 3 days) and GA at delivery was 39 weeks 2 days (IQR 38 weeks 2 days to 40 weeks 2 days). Of infants with AC<20%, 208 (33.6%) were SGA at delivery and 138 (23.1%) were diagnosed as FGR on subsequent ultrasound. Only 2 (0.32%) were large for gestational age.CONCLUSIONS:The prediction of FGR in the literature has been limited to the calculation of EFW using equations that combine measurements of head circumference, AC and femur length. Our study documents a high rate of FGR and SGA in infants with AC<20%. Given that the expected rate of FGR and SGA is approximately 10%, following AC<20% during third trimester scanning may be useful in the prediction of FGR and SGA.PPROM inTwins: Gestational Age at Delivery and Maternal and Newborn Outcomes. Gustavo Vilchez, Anushka Chelliah, Eline Brantley, Michael Kruger, Ray Bahado-Singh. Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Wayne State University/Detroit Medical Center, Detroit, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION:There is limited data on the optimal timing of delivery for PROM in twins. We analyzed the impact of gestational age (GA) at delivery on maternal and newborn outcomes in an attempt to answer this question. METHODS: NationalCenter for Health Statistics Natality Data for the US was analyzed between 2004-2008. Qualifying twins with PROM between 32-37 weeks constituted the study group. Different GA categories in PROM group were compared to the term singletons without PROM between 37-40 weeks. Maternal and newborn outcomes were evaluated. OR 95% CI were reported for each GA interval in weeks with term singletons as the reference group. OR were adjusted for widely recognized confounders that affect perinatal outcome. RESULTS: There were a 19,010 twin PPROM cases between 32-37 weeks and 35,080 term non-PROM controls matched for year of birth and state reporting category. As shown in the table, a progressive and significant reduction of major maternal, pregnancy and newborn complications is achieved with advancing gestational age at delivery.Odds Ratios of Pregancy/Newborn Outcomes in PPROM TwinDeliveries by Gestational Age*. (N=54,090) CONCLUSIONS: We used national data , thus reducing bias due to relying exclusively on cases from high-risk centers. Twin PPROM show significant improvement in important maternal, pregnancy and newborn outcome with advancing gestational age. The improvements in newborn outcome did not occur at the expense of increased in maternal risks. The study results suggest the need to review the current clinical standard which calls for elective preterm delivery (34 weeks) in twin PROM cases that are running an uncomplicated pregnancy course.Pregnancy, Labor and Neonatal Outcomes and Optimal Timing for Induction of Labor in Gestational Diabetes.Gustavo Vilchez, 1 Anushka Chelliah, 1 Elaine Brantley, 1 Ray Bahado-Singh, 2 Robert Sokol. 1 1 Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Wayne State University/ Detroit Medical Center, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Oakland University William Beaumont Medical School, USA. INTRODUCTION: Optimal timing for induction of labor (IOL) in Gestational Diabetes (GDM) is undetermined. Risks of prematurity, macrosomia, cesarean section, and post term pregnancy should be considered. The current data is inadequate to make an evidence-based recommendation. We performed a population-based study to identify the optimal gestational age(GA) for IOL. METHODS: The US Natality Database from 2007-2010 was reviewed. Inclusion criteria were:singleton deliveries, IOL, GA at 36-42wks, GDM. Exclusion criteria were:congenital anomalies, pregestational diabetes, hypertensive disorders, previous cesarean, breech presentation, rupture of membranes. Non-GDM deliveries were selected as controls. Variables analyzed were:neonatal outcomes(low apgar score, assisted ventilation, NICU admission, antibiotic/surfactant use, seizures), labor complications(fetal distress, stained meconium, chorioamnionitis), delivery mode, and macrosomia(>4500g). Logistic regression was used to calculate adjusted odds ratios of variables by gestational age using 39wk control as reference. RESULTS: A total of 96,964 cases and 176,079 controls were included. GDM presents increased risks for all adverse outcomes compared to controls. The risk of neonatal complications and cesarean delivery are the lowest at 39wks; the risk of labor complications is the lowest at 38 wks (figure

TABREF468.text: Gestational Age Infant According to Four Different Definitions.Daphne N Voormolen, 1 Sabine Ensing, 2 Ben W Mol, 2 Arie Franx, 1 Inge M Evers, 3 Anita Ravelli. 4 1 Obstetrics andGynaecology, Umiversity Medical  Center Utrecht, Netherlands; 2 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Academic  Medical Center, Netherlands; 3 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Meander  Medical Center, Netherlands; 4 Medical Informatics, Academic Medical  Center, Netherlands.  INTRODUCTION:  In current practice obstetric history is used as an important determinant of risk in a subsequent pregnancy and often influences clinical management. A large for gestational age (LGA) infant is associated with increased risks. Unfortunately antenatal detection is poor,and diagnosis can often only be made after birth. Also a universal definition of LGA is lacking. Our aim was to compare 4 most common definitions of LGA for their prognostic potential to predict recurrent LGA and associated maternal and neonatal outcome in subsequent pregnancy. METHODS: Data were extracted from the Netherlands Perinatal Registry between 1999 and 2007. A linked data set of first and second singleton deliveries between 36 and 43 weeks of gestation without congenital malformations was used. Four common definitions for LGA were applied: birth weight (a)≥90th centile (b)≥95th centile (c)≥4,000 g (d)≥4,500 g. Pregnancy outcome of subsequent pregnancies in women with and without a history of LGA according these four definitions were compared. Odds ratios of maternal and neonatal outcomes were calculated after adjustment for maternal age,interpregnancy interval,ethnicity,socio-economic status and diabetes. RESULTS: A total of 247,825 women were included of which 1.8%-12.3% had a LGA firstborn depending on LGA definition. A significant difference in recurrence risk for LGA was observed with the lowest recurrence risk in the ≥4,500 g definition: 25% (OR 8.6,95% CI 8.0-9.3) and highest for the ≥4,000 g definition: 51.8%(OR 5.3,). Women with a history of LGA had a higher risk of induction of labour in a subsequent pregnancy. The risk varied however from 26.1% (OR 1.6,95% CI 1.5-1.6) to 32.8% (OR 2.8,95% CI 2.7-3.0). The significant risk of birth trauma for the second child was similar for all definitions. There was a not statistically significant tendency to a lower risk for neonatal death of the subsequent child for all definitions. CONCLUSIONS: Women with a LGA first born have an increased risk of recurrent LGA, which is highest when LGA is defined as birth weight ≥4,000 g. Risk for other adverse maternal and neonatal outcome in subsequent pregnancy are not determined by the choice of the definition for LGA.Heterogeneity in the Causality of Perinatal Outcomes onNeighbourhood Level in 15 Municipalities in The Netherlands: A Population Based Study. Amber A Vos, 1 Semiha Denktas, 1 Gouke J Bonsel, 2 Eric AP Steegers. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 2 Public Health, Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands. TABREF469.text: Current Identification and Antenatal Policy for Medical and Non-Medical Risk Factors in the Dutch Obstetric Care System. Amber A Vos, 1 Annemiek Leeman, 1 Adja JM Waelput, 1 Gouke J Bonsel, 2 Eric AP Steegers, 1 Semiha Denktas. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 2 Public Health, Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands.INTRODUCTION: Social factors (e.g. domestic violence) and living in a deprived neighborhood are associated with a higher risk on adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study aims to identify whether non-medical risk factors are addressed in the antenatal risk assessment, to identify the current tools, and to explore the level of satisfaction in the collaboration with non-obstetrical caregivers. METHODS: Cross-sectional study in 39 municipalities in the Netherlands. Caregivers from 157 primary care midwife practices and 43 hospitals were invited to complete a web-based survey. RESULTS: 118 primary care midwives 156 hospital caregivers completed the survey. Medical risk factors were universally screened (100%), whereas non-medical risk screening was highly variable.

TABREF470.text: Intrapartum Course during the First Pregnancy May InfluencePreterm Birth (PTB) Risk in the Second Pregnancy. Luchin F Wong, 1 Jacob Wilkes, 2 Kent Korgenski, 2 Michael W Varner, 1 Tracy A Manuck. 1 1 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Intermountain Healthcare and the University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 Department of Pediatrics, Intermountain Healthcare and the University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: To identify whether intrapartum factors during the 1st delivery at term are associated with PTB in a 2nd viable pregnancy.METHODS:Retrospective case-control cohort of women with their 1st two consecutive pregnancies (G1 & G2) carried to ³ 20wks gestation within a tertiary healthcare system, 2002-2012. Women whose 1st delivery was < 37wks, required a cerclage, had multiple gestation, or fetal anomalies/ aneuploidy were excluded. Those delivering G1 at term and G2 preterm ³ 20.0 & <37.0wks (term-PTB cases) were compared to women with a term birth for G1 and G2 (term-term controls). Data were extracted from computerized point-of-care programs; a portion were manually verified. Data were analyzed by c 2 , Student's t-test, and logistic regression. RESULTS: 38215 women met inclusion criteria. 1735 (4.5%) were term-PTB cases. Cases and controls were similar in race and maternal age. Intrapartum characteristics for G1 were compared (table). Cases delivered G1 at term, but on average 6 days earlier than controls. Cases also delivered G2 earlier (35.5 vs. 39.0 wks, p<0.001) and were more likely to have an interpregnancy interval < 1yr (4.2 vs. 1.2 %, p<0.001). In multivariable models, cesarean delivery (OR 1.9, 95% CI 1.5-2.4) and 2nd stage ³ 4 hrs (OR 1.4, 95% CI 1.1-1.8) were associated with term-PTB sequence. CONCLUSIONS: Prolonged 2nd stage ³ 4hrs and cesarean delivery in the 1st pregnancy at term are associated with an increased risk of PTB in the 2nd pregnancy.CD=cesarean delivery; * among 1501 cases & 31544 controls reaching 2nd stage in G1; ** compared to cesarean for other indications.Intrapartum Cervical Laceration and the Effect on SubsequentPregnancy. TABREF471.text: Risk Factors for Recurrent Placental Abruption. Luchin F Wong, 1 Jacob Wilkes, 2 Kent Korgenski, 2 Michael W Varner, 1 Tracy A Manuck. 1 1 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Intermountain Healthcare and the University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 Department of Pediatrics, Intermountain Healthcare and the University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION:We sought to identify obstetric and social risk factors between a woman's 1st and 2nd pregnancy (P1 & P2) that may be associated with recurrent abruption. METHODS: Retrospective case-control cohort of women with their 1st two consecutive pregnancies carried to ≥20.0wks gestation within a tertiary healthcare system, 2002-2012. Women with multiple gestation, fetal anomalies, or aneuploidy were excluded. Abruption cases were identified by ICD9 codes. Women with abruptions in both P1 and P2 (cases) were compared to those with abruption only in P1 (controls). Data were extracted from computerized point-of-care programs; a portion manually verified. Analysis was by Fisher's exact test, Student's t-test, and logistic regression. RESULTS: Of 40712 women, 453 (1.1%) had an abruption in P1. 18 (4.0%) had a recurrent abruption (cases). Demographics and interpregnancy interval were similar between cases and controls. Obstetric complications and potentially modifiable risk factors were compared between cases and controls(Table). Rates of preterm birth <37 wks for any indication and PPROM in P1 were similar between groups. Likewise, changes in tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use, insurance, and marital status between P1 and P2 were similar between groups. In multivariate analysis, women with interpregnancy interval < 1yr (OR 7.8, 95% CI 1.7-35.5), admission for threatened preterm labor in P1 (OR 6.4, 95% CI 1.4-30.2), tobacco use in P2 (OR 7.3, 95% CI 1.5-35.1), and hypertension in P2 (OR 4.2, 95% CI 1.0-16.8) were at increased risk for recurrent abruption. CONCLUSIONS: Short interpregnancy interval, threatened preterm labor, and tobacco use are significant modifiable risk factors for recurrent abruption. Preconception counseling and prenatal care should be particularly focused on these women.Analysis of Placental Pathology in Infants Admitted to a NeonatalCare Unit. TABREF486.text: Estriol Developmentally Programs Uterine Gene Methylation and Subsequent Adult Expression: A Functional Role for Estriol inPregnancy. Yuping Zhou, Angelina Seffens, Hugh Taylor. OB/GYN, Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Estrogens are critical for development of female reproductive organs & adult function. Estradiol (E2) is predominant estrogen during reproductive years while Estriol (E3) is produced in significant amount only during pregnancy. It is unclear if E3 has any function in pregnancy. Effects of E3 on development of uterus & subsequent adult E2 responsiveness has not previously been investigated. METHODS: 8 pregnant CD-1 mice were treated w/ E3 (200ug/kg/d) or vehicle control via osmotic minipump beginning on day9 of gestation for 7days. At 6weeks, the female offspring (12/group) were oophorectomized & after 2weeks were treated w/ a single IP injection of either 300 ng E2 or vehicle. 6hours after injection the uteri were removed, & RNA, DNA & protein were isolated. A mouse BeadChip WG-8 expression microarray (Illumina) & DNA Methylation 3x720K CpG Island Plus RefSeq Promoter array were performed using purified RNA or DNA. Select gene expression was verified by either quantitative RT-PCR & normalized w/ beta-actin, or Western blotting. RESULTS: E3 is the predominant estrogen produced during pregnancy.Effects of E3 on embryonic gene expression & subsequent adult E2 responsiveness have not previously been investigated. We treated pregnant mice w/ E3 & examined global gene expression, methylation profile, E2 responsiveness in adult female offspring. 611 utero genes demonstrated a permanently altered expression pattern after in utero E3 treatment compared to control group. 12 genes that are putatively associated w/ reproduction or carcinogenesis were validated by quantitative RT-PCR. In addition, over 4000 genes were either hyper-or hypo-methylated by E3 treatment. Most of the altered genes were those involved in development. Moreover in utero E3 treatment increased mRNA expression of 260 E2responsive genes in adult offspring. Interestingly, in utero E3 exposure also enhanced protein expression of a number of DNA/histone modifiers including SUZ12, EZH2, CBP, LSD1 & DNMT1, which regulate global gene transcription efficiency. CONCLUSIONS: Prenatal exposure of mice to E3 permanently changes global gene expression & methylation profiles & estrogen responsiveness of the uterus. A number of genes involved in reproduction & cancer are developmentally programmed by E3. We have identified a novel role for fetal E3 in epigenetic programming of adult gene expression, likely via regulating estrogen receptor signaling pathway & expression of some DNA/histone modifiers.

Charlotte Oyston, 1,2 Joanna L Stanley, 1,2 Mark H Oliver, 1,2 Frank H Bloomfield, 1,2,3 Philip N Baker. 1,2 1 Liggins Institute, University of Auckland, New Zealand; 2 Gravida, National Research Centre for Growth and Development, New Zealand; 3 Pediatrics: Child and Youth Health, University of Auckland, New Zealand. TABREF488.text: NFAT5 as a Novel Biomarker of Hypoxia: Role in Preeclampsia and Intra-Uterine Growth Restriction (IUGR). Macarena Palominos, AnetaDobierzewska, Carlos E Irarrazabal, Marianela Sanchez, Yara Burmeister, Horacio Figueroa, Sebastian Illanes. Laboratory of Reproductive Biology, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Universidad de los Andes, Santiago, Chile.INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia is the major disorder of human pregnancy and is characterized by pregnancy-induced hypertension and proteinuria that affects 5 to 7% of all pregnancies. PE is associated with the increase in placental vascular resistance and oxidative stress. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the development of PE are still not fully understood. Previous studies have demonstrated that placental hypoxia plays a significant role in the pathophisiology of PE. The transcriptional factor NFAT5 is implicated in the regulation of expression of the genes involved in the osmotic stress response. To date, there is no published evidence linking NFAT5 with the development of PE. We hypothesized that in hypoxic placentas (human PE patients or rabbit model of IUGR) the levels of NFAT5 are higher than in controls, indicating that NFAT5 might be involved in the pathogenesis of PE, serving as a biomarker for placenta-originated disorders like PE or IUGR. The objective of this study was to compare the expression of NFAT5 in the in vitro cellular model of hypoxia, human PE and rabbit IUGR placentas. METHODS: The hypoxia was induced in JAR cells (human choriocarcinoma) by oxygen deprivation (1% O 2 ) for 3, 6, 8 and 16 hours.

TABREF499.text: Maternal Health Clinic: An Initiative for Cardiovascular Risk Identification in Women with Pregnancy-Related Complications.Graeme N Smith, Maria Cusimano, Jessica Pudwell, Michelle Roddy, Jane Cho. Obstetrics & Gynecology, Queen's University, Kingston, ON, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Women who develop certain common pregnancy complications have a greater chance of developing cardiovascular disease later in life. However, most healthcare providers do not provide postpartum cardiovascular risk counselling or follow-up. The Maternal Health Clinic was established to address this gap in care. It targets women at increased risk of cardiovascular disease in order to inspire lifestyle changes, encourage long-term follow-up, and initiate primary prevention. Here we summarize results from the first 17 months of completed clinic visits. METHODS: Patients experiencing at least one relevant complication in their index pregnancy were referred to the Maternal Health Clinic through standard postpartum order sheets. Patients underwent a complete assessment including screening history, physical examination, fasting bloodwork, and urinalysis. Lifetime and 30-year cardiovascular disease risk estimates, along with a metabolic syndrome calculation, were determined for each patient. RESULTS: Complications most commonly leading to referral were gestational diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance (32.7%), pre-eclampsia (29.3%), preterm birth (29.3%), and gestational hypertension (19.6%). The clinic analysis group (n=92) was compared to historical cohort groups from the Pre-Eclampsia New Emerging Team study. Patients in the clinic analysis group had significantly increased lifetime and 30year cardiovascular disease risk estimates compared to healthy controls (p<0.0001). Furthermore, 17.4% of the clinic analysis group had metabolic syndrome, compared to 6.78% of healthy controls (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that the Maternal Health Clinic accurately identifies postpartum patients that have underlying cardiovascular risks which make them susceptible to cardiovascular disease. The clinic may serve as an effective primary prevention strategy.Continuous Sutures of the Uterine Myometrium as a Possible RiskFactor for Placenta Accreta in Subsequent Pregnancy. TABREF503.text: Toll-Like Receptor 4 and Associated Inflammatory Pathways AreActivated in the Placenta after Chronic Maternal Intake of a High Fat Diet. Jennifer A Thompson, 1 Styliani Goulopoulou, 1 Maria-Alicia Carrillo-Sepulveda, 1 Adviye Ergul, 1 Miachael P Diamond, 1,2,3 R Clinton Webb. 1 1 Physiology, Georgia Regents University, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Georgia Regents University, USA; 3 Reproductive Endocrinology and Fertility, Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Mechanisms underlying the obstetrical complications and long-term outcomes of maternal obesity remain ill-defined, however placental dysfunction consequent to inflammation has been proposed as a possible contributing factor. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) have recently emerged as important mediators of the chronic inflammation and oxidative stress that accompanies obesity and other metabolic disorders. Recent evidence suggests that saturated fatty acids (FA) and oxidized lipoproteins activate TLRs; and TLRs are expressed in the placenta. Thus, we aim to determine if TLRs mediate placental inflammation under conditions of maternal high fat (HF) diet.

TABREF504.text: Expression of Functional TLRs in Human Uterine Myocytes.Christopher T Veal, 1,2 Tucker Berk, 1 Mark Phillippe. 1 1 Vincent Center for Reproductive Biology, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA; 2 Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Sciences, University of Vermont College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Infection and/or inflammation are commonly associated with preterm delivery (PTD). Research has shown activation of the innate immune response triggers PTD in 24 hours or less in the pregnant mouse. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and other pathogen associated molecular pattern molecules (PAMPS) have been shown to stimulate Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and trigger PTD. LPS, the ligand/agonist for theTLR4 receptor, is found in the membrane capsule of gram-negative bacteria. Previous studies have demonstrated TLR4 expression in whole uterine tissue; however, none of these studies have determined if functional TLR4 receptors are actually present on smooth muscle myocytes. METHODS: This study sought to assess if human smooth muscle myocytes express TLRs and are responsive when stimulated with PAMPs.

TABREF513.text: Preeclampsia-Upregulated Angiogenesis-Associated MicroRNA-20bInhibits Trophoblast Syncytialization and Migration. Wen Wang, Dong-bao Chen. Ob/Gyn, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Mononucleated cytotrophoblasts (CTB) function as placental "stem cells" that differentiate into multinucleated syncytiotrophoblast (STB) via the villous pathway and invasive extravillous trophoblast (EVT) via the extravillous pathway. Shallow EVT invasion into the spiral artery and incomplete spiral artery remodeling are often seen in preeclampsia (PE). MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of noncoding 21-25 nucleotide RNAs that negatively regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally. We have shown that angiogenesis-associated miRNA-20b that targets on EFNB2 and both are upregulated in PE placentas compared to controls. Hypothesis: MiRNA-20b inhibits CTB syncytialization via the villous pathway and EVT migration and invasion via the extravillous pathway. METHODS: MiR-20b precursor was cloned into lentiviral pGIPZ vector, packaged and tittered in 293T cells. The lentiviral vectors were used for overexpressing miR-20b in both human extravillous trophoblast derived HTR-8/SVneo cells and human placenta choriocarcinoma trophoblast derived BeWo cells. BeWo cells were used as the cell model to study CTB syncytialization. Cell fusion was determined by counting the percentage of multinucleated STB-like cells that BeWo cells formed after culture for 2-3 days. Cell migration and invasion of HTR-8/SVneo cells were assessed by transwell migration and matrigel invasion assays. RESULTS: Overexpression of miR-20b suppressed BeWo cell fusion along with EFNB2 downregulation. Overexpression of miR-20b in HTR-8/SVneo cells significantly inhibited cell migration and invasion. CONCLUSIONS: Upregulation of preeclampsia-upregulated angiogenesis-associated miRNA-20b and downregulation of EFNB2 inhibit CTB syncytiolization via the villous pathway and EVT migration and invasion via the extravillous pathway.
