INTRODUCTION: The etiology of preeclampsia (PE) is thought to involve poor placentation during early pregnancy. To explore causality, we obtained surplus chorionic villous samples (CVS, ~11.5 week) as reported before(Founds 2009). Microarray was performed on samples from 4 women that developed PE matched to 8 normal pregnant women. Intriguingly, differentially expressed genes (DEG) down-regulated in PE included putative decidualization (DEC) genes, like PRL, IGFBP-1, and PAEP. Thus, the objective was to test the potential link between PE and aberrant DEC during early pregnancy and pre-DEC of the late secretory endometrium (LSE). METHODS: We employed the Bioconductor software to re-analyze publically available microarray datasets: CVS as described above (GSE12767); menstrual cycle samples from proliferative through LSE (n=24; GSE4888, Talbi 2006; GSE6364, Burney 2007); confluent DEC obtained from early intrauterine pregnancy (IUP; n=7) and non-DEC endometrium (EM) (n=5; E-MTAB-680, Duncan 2011); and in vitro DEC EM temporally exposed to trophoblast-conditioned medium (DEC+TR; n=14; GSE5809, Hess 2007). CVS and DEC datasets were compared by t-test (limma package) to determine down-and up-regulated DEG in CVS-PE and DEC, respectively. Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of Milan -Bicocca, Monza, Monza e Brianza, Italy. INTRODUCTION: Chronic hypertension(CH) complicates 1-5% of pregnancies. METHODS: All pregnant women with CH,managed at our Hospital between 2000-2011,were recruited for this retrospective analysis.262(0.8%) patients were included.UtA Doppler evaluation both < and ≥ 25wks was performed.Group 1 (sPE or SGA pregnancies) was compared with group 2 (uncomplicated cases) for UtA Doppler evaluation, both <25wks(I Dpl) and ≥25wks(II Dpl).UtA mean RI>95th percentile was considered abnormal. RESULTS: sPE was diagnosed in 42(16%) women,whereas 52(19.8%) patients had SGA newborns.Table1 displays sPE and SGA relative risk(RR) in relation to persistently abnormal UtA Doppler evaluation.

back_matter.text: We have shown that maternal LP in pregnancy and lactation impairs OFF associative learning and motivation (1). We hypothesized that learning impairment involves the following mechanisms: 1) impaired learning in the Morris Water Maze (MWM) task; 2) HC neuronal fine structure changes and 3) altered corticosterone (CORT) production. METHODS: We studied male OFF whose mothers ate either control (C) (20% casein) or restricted (R) (10% casein) isocaloric diet in P and L. After weaning all pups ate C diet. At postnatal day (PND) 108 male OFF were tested in the MWM. At PND 110 CORT levels were determined and brains were obtained to measure in CA3: a) Stratum Lucidum (SL) mossy Associated Chemokine Ratios: Is There a Link? Maternal and umbilical cord Vitamin D status may influence risk for development of childhood allergies. Vitamin D has a known immuno-modulatory effect on T cell differentiation, inhibiting Th1 and promoting Th2 response. We aimed to determine whether maternal or cord blood Vitamin D levels are associated with Th2/Th1-associated chemokine ratios that may precede the development of childhood allergies. We hypothesized that vitamin D levels would be directly related to Th2/ Th1 ratios. METHODS: We enrolled 126 women in a randomized controlled trial of prenatal supplementation with EPA-and DHA-rich fish oil or soy oil placebo for prevention of perinatal depression. Maternal blood was drawn at enrollment (12-20 weeks) and after supplementation (34-36 weeks). Umbilical cord blood was collected at delivery. Plasma samples from 117 women and 97 newborns (cord plasma) were analyzed for chemokines and 25-hydroxy vitamin D. Ratios of log-transformed chemokines [Th2 macrophage-derived chemokine, MDC (CCL22)]/ [Th1 interferon-inducible protein-10, IP-10 (CXCL10)] and [Th2 thymus and activation-regulated chemokine, TARC (CCL17)]/ IP-10 (CXCL10)] were modeled outcomes. Multiple linear regression was performed to examine associations between treatment group and vitamin D levels with chemokine ratios, adjusting for covariates. RESULTS: Mean cord blood vitamin D was 22.3 ng/ml. Cord blood vitamin D was significantly correlated with maternal vitamin D levels at enrollment (P<0.0001) and at 34-36 weeks (P<0.0001). We previously found that omega-3 supplementation was significantly associated with reduced umbilical cord MDC/IP10 and TARC/IP10 ratios, after adjusting for gestational age at delivery and mode of delivery. In this expanded analysis, there was no independent association between vitamin D levels and chemokine ratios in maternal or cord blood. Including vitamin D in these models did not alter the originally-observed associations. CONCLUSIONS: Maternal and cord blood vitamin D status was not associated with pro-allergic Th2 to Th1 chemokine ratios.

Gender Differences in Network Structure in Placental Chorionic Vasculature in High Autism Risk Sibs: Insights into Autism Risk Genesis. Carolyn M Salafia, 1,2 Dawn P Misra, 2 Craig Newschaffer, 3 Theresa Girardi. We have hypothesized that, given evidence that angiogenesis drives neurogenesis, that vascular networks may vary in the context of autism, a disorder that includes abnormal neuronal connectivity. We explore placental chorionic network structure in a population of high autism risk newborns. Gender differences persist even in children at high risk due to familial factors. We searched for gender differences in network structure. METHODS: 75 placental chorionic arterial and venous networks (45 male, 29 female) were collected from placental chorionic photographs of Early Autism Risk Longitudinal Investigation (EARLI) high autism risk sibs. 66 variables were extracted from the arterial and venous networks. Data reduction extracted 8 uncorrelated factors each from arterial and venous derived variables, accounting for 80% of total data variance. Univariate analysis of relationship to gender, and adjustment for gestational age (GA), birth and placental weight (BW, PW) considered p<0.05 significant.

([Ca 2+ ] i ) is a key mechanism translating the effects of agonist stimulation of endothelial cells (ECs) into cellular responses. In systemic circulation, the transient receptor potential vanilloid 4 (TRPV4) channels mediate EC Ca 2+ entry in response to diverse physiologic stimuli. The role of TRPV4 channels in regulating uterine vascular tone remains unknown. In this study we (1) defined physiological significance of TRPV4 channels as a Ca 2+ entry pathway in the ECs of uteroplacental arteries, and (2) elucidated their contribution to ACh-induced EC [Ca 2+ ] i responses. METHODS: The diameters, SMC membrane potential (MP, microelectrodes) and [Ca 2+ ] i (fura 2) responses to activation of TRPV4 channels with GSK 1016790A were studied using pressurized arteries from pregnant rats. ACh-and GSK-induced EC [Ca 2+ ] i responses were characterized in small sheets of ECs. The effects of GSK on MP of ECs were tested using perforated patch clamp methodology. RT PCR was performed to quantify mRNA levels of TRPV4 in uterine vasculature. RESULTS: Activation of TRPV4 channels with GSK resulted in NOindependent endothelium-mediated vasodilation. The dilator responses at 10 nM GSK (78 ± 7 %, n = 8) were associated with SMC hyperpolarization (by -22 ± 3 mV) and SMC [Ca 2+ ] i reduction. GSK induced concentrationdependent elevation of EC [Ca 2+ ] i , that was 418 ± 45 nM (n = 4) at 10 nM. HC067047, an inhibitor of TRPV4 channels, abolished GSKinduced responses. TRAM-34, an inhibitor of intermediate conductance Ca 2+ -activated K + (IK Ca ) channels markedly attenuated GSK responses. EC hyperpolarization (-25 ± 6 mV, n = 5) to GSK was reversed by charybdotoxin. ACh-induced elevation of [Ca 2+ ] i in EC sheets was reduced by HC067047 by 76 % (n = 4). TRPV4 expression in uteroplacental radial arteries was two-fold higher compared to that in main uterine artery. CONCLUSIONS: Endothelial TRPV4 channels are essential Ca 2+ entry pathway in ECs of uteroplacental arteries. TRPV4-mediated Ca 2+ entry hyperpolarizes ECs through activation of IK Ca channels resulting in SMC hyperpolarization, [Ca 2+ ] i reduction and vasodilation. Activators of TRPV4 channels may improve EC Ca 2+ signaling and uterine vascular function in complicated pregnancies. Supported by NIH HL088245.

Eileen K Hutton, 1 Mary E Hannah, 2 Susan Ross, 8 Elizabeth V analysis was used to assess the relationship between GCH and recurrence of preeclampsia on subsequent pregnancy. P<0.05 was considered as significant. RESULTS: Of 62 women, seventeen had the development of recurrent preeclampsia (27.4%). Linear regression analysis showed that the absence or presence of GCH was not associated with the recurrence of preeclampsia on subsequent pregnancy (p=0.178). And gestation-specific uric acid z-score as a continuous variable did not show any association with the prediction of preeclampsia on subsequent pregnancy (p=0.215). CONCLUSIONS: Gestation corrected hyperuricemia does not predict the recurrence of preeclampsia on subsequent pregnancy.

back_matter.text: Microsatellite Polymorphism in the Heme Oxygenase -1 Gene Promoter Is Associated with Non-Severe and Late-Onset Pre-Eclampsia. Miira M Klemetti, 1 Tea Kaartokallio, 1 Paivi Lakkisto, 2 Hannele Laivuori. 1 1 Department of Medical Genetics, Haartman Institute, Biomedicum Helsinki, University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland; 2 Department of Clinical Chemistry, Biomedicum Helsinki, University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland. INTRODUCTION: Pre-eclampsia (PE) is a hypertensive pregnancy disorder, characterized by metabolic abnormalities similar to the metabolic syndrome. Prior PE increases cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes (T2DM) risk. Heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) is an anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory stress-response enzyme. During pregnancy, HO-1 seems to be cytoprotective in the placenta, as the over-expression of HO-1 inhibits the production of antiangiogenic factors. HO-1 might also protect the maternal endothelium facilitating adaptation to pregnancy. The GTn short length allele (S, <25 repeats) of the HO-1 gene (HMOX1) is associated with increased HMOX1 expression compared with the long length allele (L, ≥25 repeats). The L allele has been linked to elevated T2DM and CVD risks. We studied whether the long GTn allele of the HMOX1 is associated with PE or its sub-phenotypes. METHODS: We genotyped the GT n repeat polymorphism in 759 PE and 779 control women using DNA fragment analysis. PE was defined according to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists' criteria. PE diagnosed at 34+0 gestational weeks or later was defined as late-onset. Birth weights <-2.0 SD units were classified as small-for-dates (SFD). The statistical methods used were the Mann-Whitney U-test and the Chi square test. RESULTS: There was no association between the long allele of the GT n repeat of the HMOX1 and PE. In subgroup analyzes, the LL genotype was associated with non-severe PE (p=0.037) and the L allele with non-severe (p=0.011), non-recurrent (p=0.046) and late-onset (p=0.019) PE, and with PE without a SFD infant (p=0.030). The LL genotype was associated with PE in women who smoked before (p=0.032) or during (p<0.001) pregnancy and the L allele with PE in women who smoked during pregnancy (p=0.013). CONCLUSIONS: According to one hypothesis, abnormal placentation typically characterizes early-onset PE while maternal metabolic risk factors may be more significant in late-onset PE. The association of the GT n long allele with the late-onset, less severe PE is in agreement with the previous associations of this polymorphism with T2DM and CVD and shared metabolic risk factors. Smoking could protect subjects with the S allele against PE by inhibiting the production of antiangiogenic factors. Pathogenesis of severe gestational complications as preeclampsia, eclampsia, HELLP-Syndrome, abruption of placenta, IUGR is associated with altered angiogenic biomarker levels. Aim of this study is to determine if maternal serum angiogenic biomarker ratio (sFlt-1/PlGF) can predict maternal and/or fetal, neonatal complications during pregnancy.

We prospectively studied 58 women with high-risk pregnancies (previous preeclampsia/eclampsia/HELLP-Syndrom, preexisting hypertension, thrombophilia, antiphospholipid-syndrom). We measured serum levels of sFlt-1 and PlGF by ELISA and calculated sFlt-1/ PLGF-ratio every 4-6 weeks from week 10 until the end of pregnancy. Maternal and fetal/neonatal complications were analyzed subsequently. We also evaluated effects of applied medication (acetylsalicylic acid, low molecular heparin) on gestational biomarker levels. RESULTS: sFlt-1/PlGF ratio was up to ten times higher in women with adverse pregnancy outcome, even without preeclampsia, i.e. early placenta abruption at 24 th week of pregnancy, compared to pregnancies without complications. Two to twelve weeks before clinical manifestation of gestational complications ratio-levels started to rise. Application of acetylsalicylic acid and/or heparin was associated with an immediate and constant strong decrease of the ratio after administration. CONCLUSIONS: Women with high risk to develop severe complications during pregnancy like abruption of placenta or severe preeclampsia showed strong increase of sFlt-1/PIGF ratio up to twelve weeks before clinical manifestation of these events. Protective effects of acetylsalicylic acid can be demonstrated once again by a decrease of sFlt-1/PlGF ratio levels in our study. Further results of this ongoing clinical study will be available in March.

Lipidomic Evaluation in Preeclampsia. Henri A Korkes, 1,2 Nelson Sass, 1,2 Ismael D Cotrim, 1 Leandro G De Oliveira. 1,2 1 Obstetrics, Federal University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; 2 Obstetrics, Maternidade Vila Nova Cachoeirinha, Sao Paulo, Brazil. INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia is a systemic disease affecting about 5% of all pregnant women. The pathophysiology of preeclampsia involves systemic inflammation and antiangiogenic state. Lipid disorders are characterized by chronic inflammation and therefore, can act as precursors for preeclampsia. Additionally, some specific lipids can have different biological roles that may be related to the pathophysiology of preeclampsia. METHODS: Lipidomic analysiswas performed in plasma and placental samples from pregnant women with early-onset preeclampsia and controls (N=10, for each).Lipid extraction was performed using the Bligh-Dyer protocol and lipid profiles were obtained by mass espectrometry (MALDI TOF-TOF). R E S U LT S : P l a s m a s a m p l e s o f p r e e c l a m p s i a r e v e a l e d Glycerophosphoserines-PS as the most prevalent lipid (52.3%), followed by the Glycerophosphoethanolamines-Pet (24.03%), Glycerophosphocholines-PC (9.47%) and 39%) . This lipid profile was diferent from controls (P<0,0001). Placental samples of preeclampsia revealed Glycerophosphoserines-PS as the most prevalent lipid representing (56.28%), followed by the Polyketides-PLK (32.77%), The lipid profile of placental samples was also diferente from controls (P<0,0001). CONCLUSIONS: The identification of specific lipidic profile in plasma and placental samples of preeclamptic women suggest the participation of these molecules in the pathophysiology of preeclampsia.

Friday gestation, were reviewed. Results were compared between pregnancies with hypertensive fetal growth restriction (H-FGR) (preeclampsia and FGR) to normotensive FGR (N-FGR) (FGR without preeclampsia). Neonatal outcome parameters included Apgar score≤7 at 5 min, days of hospitalization and composite neonatal outcome (defined as one or more of early complications (respiratory distress, necrotizing enterocolitis, sepsis, transfusion, ventilation, seizure, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, phototherapy, or death). Placental lesions were classified as lesions related to maternal vascular supply, lesions consistent with fetal thromboocclusive disease and inflammatory lesions, maternal (MIR) and fetal (FIR), inflammatory response. RESULTS: Women in the H-FGR group (n=72) were older, with higher BMI, and higher rate of preterm labor (<34 weeks) than in the N-FGR group (n=270), p<0.001 for all. Composite neonatal outcome was worse in the H-FGR than in the N-FGR group, 50% vs. 15.5%, p<0.001. Higher rate of maternal placental vascular lesions was detected in H-FGR compared with N-FGR, 82% vs. 57.7%, p<0.001. By using a stepwise logistic regression model, maternal BMI (1.13 OR, CI 1.035-1.227, p=0.006) and neonatal birth-weight (0.996 OR, CI 0.995-0.998, p<0.001) were independently associated with worse neonatal outcome. CONCLUSIONS: Worse neonatal outcome and more placental vascular lesions in pregnancy complicated by FGR with preeclampsia vs. FGR without preeclampsia, suggest different pathopysiology in these entities.

Arteries from Pregnant Women. Karolina Kublickiene, 1 Piet Boel, 1 Boel Niklasson, 1 Marius Kublickas, 1 Felix Bohm. 2 1 Dep. of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Karolinska University Hospital, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; 2 Dep. of Cardiology, Karolinska University Hospital, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden. INTRODUCTION: Endothelin-1 (ET-1) is implicated in the development of vascular dysfunction in preeclampsia. Evidence in vitro and in vivo indicates that ET-1 attenuates vasodilatation in humans and in animal models. The mechanisms causing this attenuation and possible ways of alleviating this have not been investigated. METHODS: Human resistance arteries (HRA) were dissected from subcutaneous fat biopsies obtained from pregnant women (n=30) upon caesarean section. HRA were mounted for isometric force recording and contracted with 1mM norepinephrine (NE) or 10nM ET-1 and the relaxations to cumulative additions of Acetylcholine (ACh), sodium nitroprusside (SNP), bradykinin (BK), zaprinast (ZAP) or calcitonin-gene related peptide (CGRP) were compared. The effects of Tempol, ascorbic acid (AA), L-NAME, indomethacin (IN) and CGRP added prior to the ET-1 and/or NE contractions were assesed on ACh-and SNP-relaxations. RESULTS: HRA contracted with similar amplitudes to ET-1 or NE but ACh-relaxations, which relaxed NE-contracted HRA to 100%, were reduced by half after ET-1 induced contractions. Similar results were obtained for BK and ZAP. Inhibiting NO-and Prostagladin (PG)-synthesis by combined addition of L-NAME and IN attenuated ACh relaxations to a similar extent in ET-1 and NA-contracted HRA. The attenuation by ET-1 was not counteracted by AA or Tempol. CGRP relaxed NEprecontracted HRA to 90±5% and ET1-precontracted HRA to 71±5% (n=8). The amplitude of contractions to ET-1 in the presence or absence of 10pM CGRP were similar, but the presence of CGRP increased the maximal relaxations obtained by both ACh and SNP. CONCLUSIONS: CGRP showed the highest resistance against the attenuating effects of ET-1 on HRA-relaxations, which were not due to interference with PG-or NO-release (either directly or through generation of oxygen radicals). CGRP at concentrations devoid of vasodilator activity, increased the endothelium-dependent and -independent relaxations in HRA. This study presents in vitro evidence on the paradigm of "CGRP as the natural antagonist of ET1" and opens up important perspectives for alternative avenues of treating pre-eclampsia.
back_matter.section: F-194 ET-1 Attenuated Endothelium-Dependent and -Independent Relaxations Are Partially Restored by CGRP in Resistance-Sized

back_matter.text: Shathiyah Kulandavelu, Wayne Balkan, Joshua M Hare. University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, Interdisciplinary Stem Cell Institute, Miami, FL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia is characterized by an increased level of S-nitrosylated protein and a decreased concentration of ascorbate (Asc), a compound required for the release of nitric oxide (NO) from nitroyslated proteins. This relationship suggests that reduced NO bioavailability contributes to preeclampsia. Mice lacking S-nitrosglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a denitrosylase that regulates S-nitrosylation, have increased levels of S-nitrosylated proteins and exhibit symptoms of preeclampsia, including hypertension and proteinuria. We investigated if these mice also show abnormal placental vascularization, one of the primary causes of preeclampsia, and whether ascorbate administration can rescue this pathological phenotype. METHODS: Pregnant GSNOR -¤and control mice (N=5-7 mothers) were studied at late pregnancy (day 17.5). Ascorbate was provided in drinking water beginning at day 0.5. Umbilical venous blood velocity waveform and diameter were determined using micro-ultrasound. Flow was calculated from the mean velocity and vessel area. Fetoplacental capillary density was determined from placental sections stained for isolectin. RESULTS: GSNOR -¤mice had fewer (4.5 ± 1 vs. 8.1 ± 0.5 in controls, P<0.01) and smaller (0.74 ± 0.02 g vs. 0.83 ± 0.02 g in controls, P<0.01) pups. Umbilical venous blood flow was lower in GSNOR -¤fetuses (0.22 ± 0.01 ml/min vs. 0.28 ± 0.01 ml/min in controls, P<0.001) at late gestation. Fetoplacental capillary density was reduced by 19% in GSNOR -¤fetuses compared to controls (P<0.001). Ascorbate treatment improved both umbilical venous blood flow (+36% in Asc treated, P<0.001) and fetoplacental capillary density (+10% in Asc treated, P<0.001) in GSNOR -¤fetuses. Ascorbate treatment also improved fetal survival (4.5 ± 1 vs. 7.1 ± 1 pups per litter in Asc treated, P<0.01) whereas it did not affect fetal growth. CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that the tight regulation of S-nitrosylation during pregnancy by GSNOR plays an essential role in promoting placental vascularization and augmenting umbilical venous blood flow in pregnancy. These findings also demonstrate that ascorbate supplementation may serve to prevent or treat preeclampsia. Supported by CIHR and NIH.

cite_spans.text: Medicine, Interdisciplinary Stem Cell Institute, Miami, FL, USA.

back_matter.section: F-195 S-Nitrosglutathione Reductase (GSNOR) Is Essential for Placental Vascularization and Umbilical Venous Blood Flow in Pregnant Mice.

back_matter.text: Paula Williams, 1 Lesia Kurlak, 2 Hiten Mistry, 3 Judith Bulmer, 4 Fiona Broughton Pipkin. 2 1 School of Vet. Med & Sci, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom; 2 OB/GYN, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom; 3 Division of Women's Health, King's College London, United Kingdom; 4 Institute of Cellular Medicine, Newcastle University, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: RAS is one of the earliest hormone systems to recognise pregnancy and has been implicated in placentation 1 . Angiotensin II (AngII) increases NADPH oxidase via its type 1 receptors (AT1R) and is thus linked with generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and oxidative stress, such as seen in PE 2 . AngII via its type 2 receptors (AT2R) balances this. The type 4 receptor (AT4R) may be involved in regulation of placentation and is reduced in PE 1 . The adenosine receptor A2aR is also known to regulate endothelial cell ROS production and enhances AngII's effects; blockade of A2aR protects these cells from acute AngIIinduced oxidative stress. METHODS: After written consent, placental samples were obtained from women undergoing elective surgical termination of pregnancy between 8-10 weeks' (Early TOP; n=8) and 12-14 weeks' gestation (Late TOP; n = 11). Samples were also collected from term NC (n = 11) and PE (n = 10) pregnancies. Protein expression of A2aR, HIF1a, AT1R, AT2R and AT4R was determined by immunohistochemistry; quantified by ImageScope (Aperio, UK).
back_matter.section: F-196 Placental Protein Expression of Adenosine A2a Receptor in Early Pregnancy & Interactions with Placental Renin Angiotensin System (RAS) in Term Normal (NC) and Pre-Eclamptic (PE) Pregnancies.

back_matter.text: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Endometriosis in Pakistani Women. Irfana Liaqat, 1 Nusrat Jahan, 2 Khalid P Loneb, 2 Andrew Pakstis, 3 Hugh S Taylor. 4 1 Department of Zoology, GC University Lahore, Lahore, Pakistan; 2 Department of physiology & cell biology, University of Health Sciences, Lahore, Pakistan; 3 Department of Genetics, Yale University, SOM, New Haven, CT, USA; 4 Department of Ob/Gyn & Rep. Sci., Yale University, SOM, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Endometriosis is common disease that causes pain and infertility. The heritable predisposition towards endometriosis motivates an interest in identify the genes and genomic variants involved in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Both genetic and environmental factors contribute to this disease. Here we investigated in Pakistani women the association of endometriosis and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) in genes previously identified in the development of this disease. METHODS: DNA samples from fifty-two genetically unrelated endometriosis subjects with endometriosis and fifty-two randomly selected controls were analyzed by direct sequencing to determine polymorphisms in 4 genes. These included estrogen receptor alpha (ESR1) (rs2234693 C/T, rs9340799 G/A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)), estrogen receptor beta (ESR2) (rs4986938 G/A SNP), progesterone receptor (PGR) (rs1042838 G/T, rs10895068 G/A SNPs) and interleukin 10 (IL10) (rs1800871 C/T, rs1800872 C/A and rs1800896 G/A SNPs).

cite_spans.text: Department of Ob/Gyn & Rep. Sci., Yale University, SOM, New Haven, CT, USA.

back_matter.text: The allele A at -592, T at -819 and G at -1080 of IL10 and all of the SNPs studied at ESR2 and PGR show strong, statistically significant associations with the disease. However, the genetic variation at ESR1 was distributed similarly among cases and control groups. CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that the functional promoter polymorphism of the interleukin 10 gene, identified by the "ATG" genotype, may contribute to the risk of endometriosis. Genetic variants of ESR2 and PGR gene may also contribute to risk as well as influence the fertility status of patients with endometriosis.

Increased Risk for Susceptibility to Endometriosis. Wan Tinn Teh, 1 Sarah Holdsworth-Carson, 1 Jane Girling, 1 Grant W Montgomery, 2 Peter Rogers. 1 1 Department of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria, Australia; 2 Molecular Epidemiology, Queensland Institure of Medical Research, Australia. INTRODUCTION: Endometriosis is a complex disease with significant genetic predisposition that affects 6-10% of reproductive-aged women. GWAS offer valuable insight into complex diseases that carry genetic risk. Previous GWAS have identified single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) which contribute to endometriosis development. The majority of SNPs are located in non-coding regions of the genome, however, a few are found in close proximity to functional genes. Two such genes are WNT4 and VEZT. We hypothesize that expression of these genes are regulated by the SNPs of interest, and protein expression studies will provide new insights into the molecular pathogenesis of endometriosis. METHODS: Women undergoing laparoscopy at the Royal Woman's Hospital (Melbourne) were recruited for this study. A questionnaire, blood sample and eutopic endometrium were collected. Blood samples were genotyped and subsequently women were categorised as homogeneous for the risk allele (RA), homogeneous for the other allele (OA) or heterogeneous (Het.). Expression of Wnt4 and VEZT were investigated by immunohistochemistry (IHC) and Western blot. RESULTS: Immunoreactive Wnt4 was present in the glandular epithelium and stroma of the endometrium.Expression is mainly cytosolic. Quantitative analysis of the Western blot 39kDa band from RA (n=5), OA (n=26) and Het. (n=14) women did not demonstrate any differential expression of Wnt4 protein. VEZT protein was expressed in the glandular epithelium and was largely restricted to the cytosol. Western blot analysis of the 89kDa band from RA (n=8), OA (n=26) and Het. (n=22) women did not demonstrate any differential expression of VEZT protein. CONCLUSIONS: Neither Wnt4 nor VEZT showed differential expression between women homozygous for risk alleles or other alleles.Further investigation of expression patterns of additional genes are required to develop insights into the functionality of endometriosis risk alleles identified by GWAS.
back_matter.section: Endometrial Protein Expression Studies of Genes Identified by Genome Wide Association Studies (GWAS) That May Confer

back_matter.text: Berith Tingaker, 1 Arne Brodin, 1 Lars Irestedt, 2 Gunvor Ekman-Ordeberg. 1 1 Division of obstetric and gynecology, Dept of Woman and Child Health Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; 2 Division of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care,, Dept of Physiology and Pharmacology Kaolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden. INTRODUCTION: To evaluate the analgesic effect of a new formulation for topical application during insertion of Intra Uterine Device (IUD). METHODS: SHACT is a proprietary 4 % L lidocaine formulation developed by Pharmanest AB. It is applied topically at the portio, in the cervical canal and into the uterus with a proprietary device developed by Pharmanest AB. SHACT is thermogelling and becomes a gel at body temperature, which minimizes the leakage after application. In a first study in women (Phase I) the pharmacokinetic properties of SHACT were investigated. The study showed that the majority of women had measurable levels of Lidocain after 5 minutes supporting a rapid onset of action. No toxicity concerns were observed during the study. A confirmatory efficacy and safety study with SHACT was a randomized, controlled, double-blind trial involving 218 nulliparous women between 18 and 45 years of age. All were planned for insertion of an IUD. RESULTS: Data from the study shows that women receiving SHACT during IUD insertion experienced an analgesic effect with less pain, measured on a visual analogue scale (VAS), compared to patients who received placebo. This effect was statistically significant (p < 0.0001). Overall this study clearly demonstrates significant reduction in pain during insertion of an IUD. The effect size is of clinical importance since on average 3 out of 4 patients will experience an advantage of SHACT compared to placebo. CONCLUSIONS: SHACT has proven to be an effective analgesia, easy to apply and with fast onset of action at IUD insertion. Pharmanest AB can also see significant potential for other clinical use and plans to further explore other indications in clinical trials.
back_matter.section: F-248 A Novel Mucosal Pain Relief Drug Candidate -SHACT -Gives Highly Significant Analgesia at Insertion of Intra Uterine Device (IUD).

back_matter.text: New Delivery Technologies for Intracellular Pathogen Vaccines. Megan D Whitham, 1 Qian Wang, 2 Meagan A Barry, 2 Hotez J Peter, 2 Heffernan J Michael. 2 1 Medicine, Virginia Tech Carilion, Roanoke, VA, USA; 2 Pediatrics, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Protein-based vaccines have great potential to treat cancer and intracellular pathogens, causes of obstetric and gynecological complications (HSV, HPV/CIN, Chlamydia). Proteins generate weak cellular immune responses alone and need adjuvants to boost TH1-type responses. This has spurred exploration of adjuvants able to drive a cellular response and microparticle platforms to enhance delivery to antigenpresenting cells. We investigated the immune profile for a vaccine formed with model protein ovalbumin (OVA) and TLR 7 agonist imiquimod (Imiq). OVA and Imiq were encapsulated in microparticles of poly(lacticco-glycolic) acid (PLGA). We hypothesized that this formulation would enhance the TH1-type response to OVA when compared to microparticles without adjuvant and soluble forms. METHODS: Microparticle formulation: Microparticles were formed by a double emulsion, solvent evaporation method of 2.5 mg OVA, 1.0 mg Imiq and 100 mg PLGA. In vivo immunogenicity: Microparticles in 100 µL were injected c.c. in C57BL/6 mice, boosted on day 14 and sacrificed at 6 weeks. Blood samples were taken on days 0, 14, 28, and 42, pooled, and analyzed for OVA-specific antibodies by ELISA. Collected splenocytes were restimulated with OVA and analyzed for IFN-g production. Statistical analysis of IFN-g production was by ANOVA followed by student's t test. RESULTS: IgG2b antibody titer was greatest for microparticles of PLGA[OVA] + PLGA [Imiq] . INTRODUCTION: Women with a previous pregnancy related disorder are at increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) later in life. We investigated the relation of miscarriage and early preterm birth to the risk of future cardiovascular (CV) events. METHODS: We included 1625 women from the SMART study, a prospective cohort study among patients with clinically manifest atherosclerotic disease or risk factors for atherosclerosis. All women had a history of ≥ 1 pregnancy and had either symptomatic CVD(cerebrovascular disease, coronary artery disease, peripheral arterial disease or abdominal aortic aneurysm, n = 910) or were asymptomatic with a risk factor (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, n = 715). After enrolment, women were followed for the occurrence of (new) CV events. Hazard ratios (HR) for women with and without miscarriage (gestational age (GA) <14 wks, n = 420) and early preterm birth (GA 14-32 wks, n = 165) were estimated. RESULTS: During a mean follow-up of 5.1 years, 65 (5.9%) women without a previous miscarriage and early preterm birth, 24 (5.7%) women with miscarriage and 11 (6.7%) women with early preterm birth, had a (new) CV event. Compared to women without a pregnancy related disorder, those with an early preterm birth did not have an increased risk of CV events (1.16 (95% CI 0.61-2.20) but did have a significant increased risk of CV mortality (HR 2.41 (95% CI 1.01-5.75) (figure 1). For women with a history of miscarriage no relation with recurrent vascular events and mortality was observed.

Vaginal Progesterone, but Not 17OHP-C, Induces Changes in Decidual Macrophages and Regulatory T Cells. Akshata Naik, 1,2 Nakisha Rutledge, 1 Roberto Romero, 2 Sonia Hassan, 1,2 Nardhy Gomez-Lopez. 1,2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Perinatology Research Branch, NICHD/NIH/DHHS, Detroit, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION: The two main strategies for the prevention of preterm birth are the administration of vaginal progesterone (P4) to women with a short cervix or 17 alpha-hydroxyprogesterone caproate (17OHP-C) to women with a history of preterm birth. A recent randomized clinical trial suggested that vaginal P4 was superior to 17OHP-C (Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 2013; 92:215-22) . However, the mechanisms by which these agents prevent preterm delivery remain to be determined. Since progestogens have immunomodulatory functions, we conducted studies to investigate the effects of P4 and 17OHP-C on cells involved in parturition: decidual macrophages and T regulatory cells. METHODS: Pregnant C57BL/6 mice were treated with vaginal P4 (2mg/200mL, n=10) or 17OHP-C (2mg/100mL, n=10) from 13 to 17 days post-coitum (dpc). Replens (200mL, n=10) or castor oil (100mL, n=10) were controls. On 18.5 dpc, mice were euthanized. Thymus, spleen, inguinal and uterine lymph nodes, decidua and peripheral blood were harvested. Extensive immunophenotyping was conducted using flow cytometry for the following cells: CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, CD4+ and CD8+ regulatory T cells (Tregs, CD4+CD25+ FoxP3+/ CD8+CD25+FoxP3+), monocytes/macrophages (CD45+F4/80+), dendritic cells (CD45+CD11c+), neutrophils (CD45+Ly6G+) and NK cells (CD45+CD49b+). Statistical analysis was performed with nonparametric statistics and a p≤0.05 was considered significant. RESULTS: 1) The proportion of decidual macrophages was significantly lower after treatment with vaginal P4 than placebo (p=0.01) or 17OHP-C (p=0.014); 2) treatment with vaginal P4 was associated with a greater number of CD4+ and CD8+ Tregs in lymphatic organs than with 17OHP-C (p<0.05). Interestingly, treatment with 17OHP-C showed reduced proportions of CD8+ Tregs in inguinal lymph nodes compared to treatment with castor oil (p=0.003). CONCLUSIONS: Treatment with vaginal P4 reduces the recruitment of macrophages to decidua, and causes an expansion of CD4+ and CD8+ Tregs in lymphatic organs -17OHP-C did not have any of these effects. This observation suggests that treatment with vaginal P4, but not 17OHP-C, promotes a maternal systemic anti-inflammatory response (as assessed by the number of Tregs in lymphatic organs) and reduces decidual macrophages. These novel findings may provide insight into the mechanism whereby vaginal P4 prevents preterm birth.

Role of Mesenchymal Stem Cells in Human IUGR Placentas. C Novielli, 1 P Razini, 2 C Mando, 1 A Tavelli, 2 GM Anelli, 1 M Belicchi, 2 I Capriata, 1 S Erratico, 3 I Cetin, 1 Y Torrente. 4 1 Biomedical and Clinical Sciences L.Sacco Dept., Università degli Studi di Milano, Italy; 2 Pathophysiology and Transplantation Dept., Italy; 3 Ystem, s.r.l., Milan, Italy; 4 Pathophysiology and Transplantation Dept., Italy. INTRODUCTION: Placental mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) have been investigated in healthy placentas. Here we characterize placental MSC in intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) compared to appropriate for gestational age (AGA) pregnancies. METHODS: Cells were isolated from amnion and chorion of 6 IUGR, 5 term AGA, 1 pre-term AGA human placentas at elective cesarean section. Cell viability and proliferation were assessed every 7 days over a 6-wk culture. Expression of hematopoietic (CD45), hematopoietic stem (CD133,CD34,CD117), endothelial (CD31,CD146,CD90) and mesenchymal (CD105,CD29,CD44,CD73,CD90) markers was evaluated by flow cytometry. To test differentiation potential, cells were cultured in appropriate media inducing differentiation into osteogenic (OS), adipogenic (AD), and chondrogenic (CHD) lineages at 30 days, and myogenic and endothelial lineages at 10 days. RESULTS: Cell viability was high in all samples. Proliferation rate was increased in amnion-derived cells compared to chorion, with no differences among IUGR, term and pre-term AGA. All samples presented a starting heterogeneous population, which progressively lost hematopoietic and endothelial markers and increased mesenchymal markers. This occurred earlier in IUGR than in term and pre-term AGA: at day 7 mesenchymal markers were 1.6-4 fold (amnion) and 2.3-5.8 fold (chorion) higher in IUGR. All cells differentiated into mesodermal-specific (AD,OS,CHD) lineages. However, IUGR cells showed lower endothelial and myogenic (mainly smooth muscle) differentiation potentials. CONCLUSIONS: We observed mesenchymal markers enrichment and multipotent differentiation abilities, confirming successful isolation and selection of MSC from amnion and chorion. In IUGR placentas the MSC population was more resistant and earlier selected, but showed lower myogenic and endothelial differentiation potentials, especially in chorion. Potentially, this may also indicate maternal decidual involvement and needs further investigation. INTRODUCTION: Perinatal brain damage as well as other neurodegenerative diseases that may lead to a hypomyelination of the brain's white matter still don't have an effective treatment. The use of Wharton's Jelly mesenchymal stem cells (WJ-MSC) may be a promising approach to cure such diseases. Especially their soluble factors have shown in vitro and in vivo beneficial effects on neurogenesis and neuroregeneration. Therefore, the objective was to assess the effect of the secretome of WJ-MSC on neuroregeneration in vitro. METHODS: Hippocampal rat neural progenitor cells (NPC) were exposed either to treatment with human WJ-MSC-conditioned medium (CM), to direct co-culture or to indirect co-culture (transwell) with WJ-MSC. After exposure, their astro-and oligodendroglial expression profile was assessed by immunocytochemistry, real-time PCR and flow cytometry. Time points of measurement were after 48h, 96h and 144h. Furthermore, the differences between WJ-MSC harvested from term or pre-term pregnancies were evaluated. RESULTS: The expression of astroglial markers such as glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP, p < 0.01) or oligodendroglial markers like myelin basic protein (MBP, not significant) were increased on NPC after being exposed to the different conditions. Interestingly, WJ-MSC from term pregnancies were able to induce more strongly the expression of glial markers when compared to preterm WJ-MSC whereas preterm WJ-MSC induced stronger neuronal markers. The co-culture had a more prominent effect on the expression of glial markers when compared to the CM. CONCLUSIONS: Paracrine factors of WJ-MSC from term or preterm pregnancies increase the expression of astroglial markers like GFAP and oligodendroglial markers like MBP in NPC. These findings indicate a possible supportive role of transplanted WJ-MSC in the neuroregenerative -notably remyelinating -potential of endogenous NPC.
