back_matter.text: Bayesian Modelling of Murine Lactational Networks In Vivo. N Orsi, T Dasgupta, H McSara, R Savage, J Adebayo, M Cummings, J Gunawardena, S Field. Pathology, Leeds University, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Cytokine-hormone network deregulations underpin many reproductive disorders but our understanding of how these function in vivo remains patchy. We used Bayesian networks to analyse cytokinehormone interactions in vivo using murine lactation as a dynamic, physiological model. METHODS: CD1 mice (8 pups/dam) were sacrificed on lactation days 1, 2, 4, 10, 16, 21 and 24. Two other groups of dams had their litters removed post partum and were sacrificed on days 2 and 4 (each group, n=8). Serum was isolated post cardiac puncture and circulatory estrogen, progesterone (ELISA), prolactin (radioimmunoassay) and twenty-three cytokine (multiplex immunoassay) levels were measured. MetaCore/ hand curation generated seeded networks which were combined with text mining results (Predictionet). Edges causing feedback loops were removed. z-score normalisations were applied to raw data (Matlab) prior to Bayesian network analysis. A machine learning algorithm (MeV) refined the seed network together with experimental data. For each iteration, the Tabu Search algorithm was used to optimise the Bayes score as the scoring metric. Model robustness was assured by high stringency bootstrapping (0.9). Directed acyclic graphs were created in Cytoscape. Validation was performed by constructing variational Bayesian state space models (VBSSMs) in Matlab. In silico perturbation of eotaxin, interleukin (IL)-3, IL-12 (p40), IL-13, monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP)-1 and prolactin was performed by altering their conditional probability bin allocations.

The resultant lactation/abrogated lactation networks were robust and assembled around conserved structural hubs: interferon (IFN)-g, interleukin (IL)-13, MCP-1, macrophage inflammatory protein (MIP)-1a, MIP-1b and regulated upon activation normal T-cell expressed and secreted (RANTES). These relationships were broadly conserved in VBSSMs. In silico perturbation suggested that IL-12 (p40), IL-13 and MCP-1 were primary network drivers. CONCLUSIONS: These findings highlight the merit of Bayesian networks in describing cytokine-hormone interactions (antagonism, synergy, redundancy) and the structural conservation of their networks across physiological scenarios. The fact that in silico lactation nodal perturbations could predict the qualitative network responses induced by abrogating lactation suggests that such Bayesian approaches may find uses in identifying novel pharmacological targets and foresee likely physiological responses to their exogenous manipulation. Recently soluble form of RAGE (sRAGE) has been identified and its levels are correlated with the severity of preeclampsia. However, it remains unknown whether RAGE is associated with recurrent pregnancy losses (RPL). In this study, we examined whether sRAGE was increased in PRL compared with age-matched control women who has no history of pregnancy loss and if it could be a potential biomarker for RPL. We further investigated which anthropometric, metabolic and inflammatory variables were independently correlated with sRAGE in women with idiopathic RPL.

Total 93 women were classified into 2 groups: RPL group (n=63) includes women with 2 or more sequential spontaneous pregnancy losses, and controls were age matched women with a history of at least one live birth and no history of spontaneous abortion (n=30). We measured fasting blood glucose, insulin, PAI-1, homocysteine, ANA, APA, BUN, creatinine, AST, ALT and various inflammatory and metabolic biomarkers, including sVEGF, adiponectin, sRAGE, sICAM-1, sVCAM-1 and sFLT-1. Additionally, various cytokines were measured by Luminex ® . Resistance index of the uterine artery (Ut-RI) was measured by pulsed doppler ultrasonography. We statically analyzed the independent determinants of sRAGE levels by univariate and stepwise multivariate regression analyses were performed. RESULTS: sRAGE levels were significantly higher in RPL group than those of controls (1528.9±704 vs. 1149.9±447 pg/ml, P<0.01). The multivariate analysis revealed that insulin, PAI-1, Ut-RI and ratios of TNFa/IL10 producing T helper cells were significantly associated with sRAGE levels. CONCLUSIONS: The present study suggests that sRAGE may be a novel biomarker for RPL. Activation of RAGE might contribute to RPL by reducing uterine blood flow and subsequent ischemic changes in the feto-placental unit via inflammatory and thrombotic reactions.

Abstract Withdrawn Over 20% of women are obese at conception and set to rise to 50% by 2050. Obese women have a substantially higher risk of developing complications during labour and are at increased risk of emergency caesarean section due to uterine dysfunction and prolonged labour. As contractile associated proteins (CAP's) are essential to spontaneous myometrial contractions, this pilot study investigated the effects of increasing BMI on CAP expression within human term uterine tissue. METHODS: All participants provided written informed consent to participate. BMI was calculated from height and weight measurements provided during 10-12 weeks pregnancy booking. Myometrial biopsies were collected from healthy singleton pregnant women (n=4) at planned caesarean section (term 37 weeks) following delivery and before administration of oxytocin. Myometrial samples were frozen and stored at -80 o C for western blot analysis of the CAPs caveolin-1 (Cav1), connexin 43 (Cx-43) and cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX2). Pearson correlation analysis was used to assess the relationship between BMI and CAP expression at the P<0.05 level. RESULTS: Myometrial expression of Cav-1, Cx-43 & COX-2 all share an inverse relationship with increasing BMI (see Fig.1 ), however significant correlations were only observed with COX-2 (r 2 -0.94, P<0.03) and Cx-43 (r 2 -0.96, P<0.02) respectively.

There is a significant negative correlation between maternal BMI and myometrial expression of Cx-43 and COX-2. Cx-43 is a gap junction protein involved in synchronisation of electrical activity in individual myocytes and COX-2 is responsible for synthesis of prostaglandins that regulate uterine contractility. Decreased expression of these key CAP's may be a potential or contributory mechanism of uterine dystocia in woman with abnormally high BMI. (FOS, JUN) . We suggest that derepression of Cx43 during labor is mediated by change in the expression of AP-1 proteins and the proportion of JUN/FOS heterodimers vs JUN/ JUN homodimers. We hypothesize that PRA/B mediate Cx43 transcription by binding to FOS and JUN proteins at AP-1 sites and that PRA/B have differential affinity for FOS and JUN members which affects their ability to repress Cx43 transcription. METHODS: For in vivo studies, myometrial samples were collected from CD-1 mice throughout gestation, and during labor (n=6), total proteins were extracted, the expression of JUNs, FOSs, P54nrb and PRs was analyzed by western blot. In vitro protein-DNA binding assays were performed to examine the recruitment of PRs to the Cx43 promoter. Co-Immunoprecipitation and Proximity Ligation Assay (PLA) were performed to determine the interactions of PR isoforms with AP-1 transcription factors and co-repressors. RESULTS: The protein expression of PRA, cFOS, FRA-1 and JUNB were significantly up-regulated during active labor as compared to late gestation. In contrast, protein expression of p54 nrb was significantly downregulated. Using the myometrial SHM cell line, we overexpressed different JUN/FOS members and examined the recruitment of PR isoforms to Cx43 promoter. We found that PRB failed to bind to the Cx43 promoter in the presence of cFOS and FRA-1, shows stronger affinity to JUN than to FOS family members and interacts with the transcriptional co-repressor protein p54 nrb . PRA was recruited to the Cx43 promoter in the presence of all AP-1 proteins, showed affinity for both JUN/FOS, and does not interact with p54 nrb . CONCLUSIONS: We speculate that the up-regulation of PRA and FOS proteins increases the probability of PRA-JUN/FOS heterodimer complex formation that, in the absence of p54 nrb , binds to the Cx43 promoter resulting in de-repression of Cx43 gene transcription and labor onset. (FIRS) has been reported to be as a cause of fetal injury that related with cerebral palsy of preterm neonates. Inflammatory cytokines and reactive oxygen species, which are shown to be increased in FIRS, are involved in fetal damage. Preterm birth has been increasing and it is a very significant problem for society to increase these handy-capped children. However, there remain no effective therapies from fetal damage. In this study, it is investigated whether the maternal administration of hydrogen water(HW) may be effective on the mouse model of FIRS. HW has been already reported to have both antioxidant and anti-inflammatory action in the other diseases such as stroke, and encephalopathy. This is the first report on the maternal administration of HW for the FIRS model.

The FIRS model was made to lypopolysaccharide (LPS)i.p. administration 5mg/body into pregnant C3H mice at 15.5d, as previously reported. In control group, same volume of PBS injected. Water or HW was started to be given in free drinking style before 24hours of injected (at 14.5d). Samples were collected 24 hours later of (at 16.5d).Inflammatory cytokines in the embryo brain was investigated by qRT-PCR. Apoptotic cells in fetal brain were measured by TUNEL methods. RESULTS: IL-6 was significantly increased in fetal brain of the FIRS group compared with control groups, but suppressed in HW group (P<0.01).The rates of apoptotic cells in gray matter and white matter of fetal brain were significantly increased in the FIRS group compared with control groups, but suppressed in HW group (P<0.05).
These results suggested that the maternal administration of HW might be effective for the FIRS model.

Design and Biologic Characterization of Novel Prostaglandin F2a (PGF2a) Receptor Modulators -Implications for Preterm Labor. D Olson, 4 X Hou, 1 L Nikolajev, 2 E Goupil, 2 K Leimert, 4 C Bourguet, 3 A Claing, 1 S Laporte, 2 W Lubell, 3 S Chemtob. 1 1 Dept Pharmacol, U Montreal, Canada; 2 Dept Pharmacol, McGill U, Canada; 3 Dept Chem, U Montreal, Canada; 4 Dept Obst & Gynecol, U Alberta, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Preterm birth is a major medical concern, and grows in rate in spite of ameliorations in medical care. Tocolytic agents approved to prolong gestation have at best modest short-term efficacy. The PGF2a receptor (FP) is highly expressed in myometrium and decidua during labor; the absence of FP is associated with failure of labor induction and expulsion of the fetus. PGF2a induces expression of uterine activation proteins and exerts myometrial contractions . Antagonists to FP have been shown to be effective in arresting myometrial contractions ex vivo and in vivo animal models. Allosteric effects on FP may modulate the multiplicity of actions evoked by PGF2a. For example, we have previously reported that the indolizidinone analog PDC113.824 directs FP by potentiating PGF2a-induced PKC-Erk1/2 signaling while inhibiting PGF2a-triggered Rho/ROCK signaling. PDC113.824 inhibits myometrial contractions and in turn delays murine preterm birth induced by PGF2a as well as LPS. METHODS: Studying the structure activity relationships of PDC113.824 to better understand the factors controlling FP activity, we replaced the indolizidin-2-one by different aza-amino acyl proline residues: aza-glycine (termed CAR10.0), aza-propargylglycine (CAR10.1), aza-phenylalanine (CAR10.2), and aza-allylglycine (CAR10.3). RESULTS: In human myometrial cells (h-TERT-C3) CAR10.0 and CAR10.1, but neither CAR10.2 nor CAR10.3 inhibited PGF2a-induced Erk1/2 phosphorylation; whereas only CAR10.0 and CAR10.2 reduced expression of FP and oxytocin receptor, and inhibited PGF2a-elicited myometrial contraction; latter was consistent with their effects on Rho/ ROCK signaling. To determine if ex vivo properties of CAR10.0-10.3 are reproduced in vivo, we tested their efficacy in a model of LPS-induced preterm labor in mice. CAR10.0 and CAR10.2, but not CAR10.1 nor CAR10.3, prolonged gestation by ~28 h in mice treated with LPS, which induces preterm birth within 12 h of its administration. The CAR analogs did not seem to exhibit (gross) adverse effects on fetuses. CONCLUSIONS: Hence, a) the structure of the aza-side chain of the CAR analogs is critical for modulation of FP and inhibition of myometrial contraction; b) CAR10.0 and CAR10.2 provide the essential structural requirements as prototypes for drugs to effectively treat preterm labor.

Discovery of a Selective Interleukin-1 (IL-1) Receptor Antagonist Effective in Preventing Preterm Birth. D Olson, 3 X Hou, 1 K Leimert, 3 C Quiniou, 1 K Beauregard, 2 W Lubell, 2 S Chemtob. 1 1 Dept of Pharmacol, U Montreal, Canada; 2 Dept of Chemistry, U Montreal, Canada; 3 Dept of Obetetrics & Gynecology, U Alberta, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Inflammation plays a dominant role in triggering preterm labor. Numerous inflammatory mediators increase accordingly during labor. Among them, the major pro-inflammatory mediator IL-1 is prominent. Three IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) antagonists are approved for clinical use (e.g., Kineret, Canakinumab and Rilonacept); however, all are large proteins, which act as orthosteric antagonists of IL-1, resulting in inhibition of all associated receptor functions, including immuno-vigilant properties. Alternatively, allosteric modulators of IL-1R would provide pharmacological selectivity and potentially reduce undesired effects. We previously designed small stable peptides based on primary structure of IL-1R, which in turn have the potential of antagonizing the receptor. An all D-amino acid heptapeptide (rytvela) was found to be selective and specifically bound to IL-1R, but was not displaced by Kineret. In IL-1R-containing HEK blue cells, rytvela inhibited IL-1-induced NF-kB activation, and prevented induction of IL-1, IL-8, MMP-1 and iNOS, but had no influence on Erk1/2 phosphorylation and expression of IL-6. Moreover, rytvela inhibited IL-1-induced ear inflammation in a murine model. Collectively, rytvela exhibited negative modulatory allosteric properties with accompanied pharmacologic selectivity.

IL-1-induced expression of cytokines was determined on myometrial cells by quantitative PCR. Also, myometrial contraction ex vivo and preterm labor mouse model in vivo were used to examine the efficacy of rytvela. RESULTS: We proceeded to examine the efficacy of rytvela in myometrial cells. IL-1-induced expression of CCL-1, VEGF, and IL-6 (but not IL-8) in human myometrial cells were all attenuated by rytvela. IL-1-induced increase in PGF2a-triggered myometrial contraction was attenuated by rytvela. Concordantly rytvela significantly prolonged normal gestation by ~15 h. Moreover, rytvela significantly diminished the rate of IL-1-induced preterm birth by prolonging gestation on average by ~24 h. CONCLUSIONS: Altogether, as the first small IL-1R antagonist described to exhibit anti-inflammatory and tocolytic properties, rytvela offers unique promise as a therapeutic candidate to arrest preterm labor. INTRODUCTION: Proteomic analysis has identified differentially expressed proteins in the second and third trimesters associated with recurrent preterm birth. The purpose of this study was to identify cervicalvaginal fluid (CVF) proteins associated with recurrent preterm birth (RPTB) in the first trimester. METHODS: Multiparous women with singletons and history of PTB in all prior pregnancies were enrolled prospectively from 2008-2013 and had CVF collected at regular intervals during prenatal care. Cases (n=5) of women with spontaneous RPTB and first trimester CVF sample were compared with controls (n=5) of women who delivered at term with matching gestational age (GA) of first trimester sample. Proteomic analysis was performed using liquid chromatography tandem mass spectroscopy using established techniques. Proteins were identified by database peptide matching. Protein quantification was performed by spectral counting. Pair-wise comparisons used c 2 and a Z-transformation of average spectral counts. Significance was set at p < 0.01. RESULTS: Case and control groups were similar with regard to demographic measures as described in table. Average GA of sample collection was 12.0 and 11.8, mean GA at delivery was 34.7 and 38.2 weeks, and mean birthweight was 2945g and 3341g in cases and controls respectively. There were 64 candidates at a Z-score p-value of 0.01 or less. Estimated false discovery rate is 19% at that cutoff. High levels of semenogelin and prostatic acid phosphatase were over expressed in RPTB group, indicating possible semen contamination in one of the RPTB samples. Apolipoproteins A, B, and c were also identified in RPTB samples suggesting a small amount of blood contamination in the RPTB pool. Additional informative candidates identified included Heat shock protein 90, Glycodelin, and Coactosin among others. CONCLUSIONS: We were able to identify differentially expressed proteins in the first trimester of CVF from women with RPTB. These candidate biomarkers may serve as the basis for first trimester prediction of RPTB in high-risk patients. INTRODUCTION: Premature birth following preterm labour is a common and critical health issue in fetal-maternal medicine with long-term consequences especially for early preterm neonates. The pathophysiology is poorly understood and the causal factors uncertain, but inflammatory mechanisms are clearly implicated. Bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is a pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) which binds Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) to activate inflammation and induce preterm delivery (PTD) in mice. This project seeks to investigate (1) whether inhibition of the TLR4 signalling pathway using small molecule inhibitors of TLR4 signalling may prevent the parturition cascade caused by LPS-induced inflammation and (2) the consequences of in utero exposure to TL4 inhibitors for the resulting progeny.

The effect of administration of TLR4 inhibitors in preventing LPS-induced PTD was investigated in C57Bl/6 (B6) mice. Pregnant B6 females were treated with LPS or PBS, with or without coadministration of TLR4 inhibitor, on gestational day (GD) 16.5 and were either killed on GD18.5, or allowed to deliver pups. RESULTS: LPS-induced PTD was successfully alleviated using TLR4 inhibitors in B6 mice, preventing fetal loss associated with death in utero and/or early delivery, resulting in on-time birth with normal perinatal characteristics and survival rates in pups. TLR4 inhibitors did not reverse the reduced fetal weight evident in late gestation after LPS administration. However progeny born after exposure to TLR4 inhibitor in late gestation, with or without concurrent LPS administration, showed no substantial adverse effects on growth trajectory (from birth to 20 weeks), body morphometry or health in adulthood. CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that TLR4 is required for the precocious activation of the inflammatory response induced by bacterial LPS and implicates TLR4 as a key trigger for infection-associated preterm labour. Early intervention with TLR4 inhibitors can inhibit progression of the LPS-induced inflammatory cascade and prevent preterm birth without adverse perinatal or postnatal consequences in mice. The TLR pathway warrants further investigation as a potential target for new prevention or treatment options in women with infection-associated, threatened PTD. The timing and progression of normal term labour is associated with the onset of an inflammation-like response in the gestational tissues. The nature of the initiating events in term labour, and how these relate to the pathophysiological inflammatory events of preterm labour, is poorly understood. TLR4 is a receptor for several endogenous damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) released from the fetus and/or gestational tissues in late gestation. In this study we investigated the physiological role for Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) in normal term delivery. METHODS: Mice with a null mutation in the Tlr4 gene (Tlr4-/-mice) and wild-type Balb/c controls were mated with wild-type males and gestation length, duration of labor, and perinatal parameters were recorded. Expression of several inflammatory pathway genes was quantified by qPCR in gestational tissues recovered at day 17.5 in a second cohort of mice. In additional experiments, wild-type mice were administered small TLR4 antagonist or PBS control on gestational day (GD) 16.5-17.5 and the effect on perinatal parameters were recorded. All groups were 8-12 mice. Effects of treatments were considered significant when P<0.05. RESULTS: The time of normal term parturition was delayed by 12 h in <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Tlr4-/-mice compared with wild-type controls. Expression of genes encoding several proinflammatory cytokines and mediators including IL1A, IFNG and COX2 were reduced in the uterus, placenta and fetus of the <em style="msobidi-font-style: normal;">Tlr4-/-mice, compared to wildtype Balb/c mice. Administration of TLR4 antagonist to wild-type mice in late gestation caused a 20 h delay in the time of pup delivery at term, but no adverse effects on pup weight or survival were seen. CONCLUSIONS: These results imply a critical role for TLR4 in initiation or progression of the events of parturition and delivery. DAMPs released from fetal, placental or uterine tissues in late gestation (such as known TLR4 ligands surfactant proteins, hyaluronan or high mobility group protein B1) may have a role in initiating the events of parturition through ligation with TLR4 or other Toll-like receptors. Since TLR4 is also implicated in infection-associated preterm labour, there may be substantial overlap may between the mechanistic pathways responsible for both term and preterm labour.

In Vivo Study of Myometrium Plasticity Early in Pregnancy. Kristy Palomares, Joaquin Santolaya-Forgas, Lissa Francois, David Blitzer, Nicole Dalaya, Jacobo L Santolaya, Ashwin Jadhav, Paul Matta, William MacMillan. Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, Rutgers-Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, USA. INTRODUCTION: Gaining insights into the normal and abnormal adaptation of the myometrium early in pregnancy could have potential for prediction of patients at risk for preterm delivery. Sonographic imaging allows for in vivo assessments of this adaptation. In this study we sought to analyze if the changes in uterine volume between 11-14 weeks gestation in Singleton and di-chorionic Twin pregnancies. METHODS: This was a nested controlled study performed in patients that were followed thought-out pregnancy and delivered at our Center. Pregnancies ending in stillbirth or a newborn with congenital anomalies were excluded. The uterine volume was calculated from the 3 largest sagittal, coronal and transverse diameters of the uterus measured by transabdominal sonography. Correlation between uterine volume and GA at delivery were determined and comparisons between Singletons and Twin pregnancies made using a parametric test and difference in the proportion test. RESULTS: At 11 weeks the mean uterine volume for Singletons was 357 cm3 and for Twins 652 cm3 (p<0.05). At 14 weeks the mean uterine volume in Singletons was 698 cm3 and in Twins 1026 cm3 (p<0.05). In twin pregnancies a significant trend was noted between the uterine volume (cm 3 ) / mean CRL (mm) ratio and the gestational at delivery. A summary of the patients demographics is shown in Table 1 .parameters examined were volume fraction and mean volume per smooth muscle cell of mitochondria in human term myometrium. A standard section is shown in fi gure 1.White arrows indicate mitochondria. RESULTS: The maternal ages ranged from 18-45 years. Comparison of the parameters were performed for women above and below the mean age of 32.7±6.2 years (mean±SD, n=30). We found that the mean (±SD) volume fraction of mitochondria was 0.019±0.015 and the mean volume per cell was 262±234 µm 3 . In the younger group (n=14) mitochondrial volume fraction and volume per cell were 0.023±0.019 and 372±299 µm 3 respectively whereas in older group (n=16) these were 0.014±0.009 and 166±85 µm 3 . The difference in mitochondrial volume per cell was signifi cant (P = 0.026). CONCLUSIONS: These fi ndings outline a clear decrease in mitochondrial volume per cell in the pregnant myometrium of older mothers. This may explain, in part, the clinical problems related to advanced maternal age. The ultrastructure of human pregnant myometrium is not well defi ned in the literature. Dense plaques are aggregates of protein under the cell membrane upon which actin fi laments insert allowing transduction of force to the membrane. The aim of this study was to describe the surface to volume ratio and surface area of human term myometrial smooth muscle cells and the proportion of this area associated with dense plaques. The secondary aim was to study these values in association with maternal age. METHODS: Myometrial biopsies were collected from 30 women undergoing elective caesarean delivery with informed consent and institutional ethical approval. The range of maternal ages was 18-45 years, the mean age (±SD) was 32.7±6.2 years. These were imaged with a transmission electron microscope and analysed using stereological methods. A representative image is shown in fi gure 1.

White arrows indicate dense plaque associated cell membrane. The parameters studied were the surface to volume ratio and surface area of cell membrane and dense plaque associated cell membrane. The correlation between these parameters and maternal age were examined. RESULTS: The mean (±SD) surface to volume ratio was 0.65±0.14 µm -1 , the cell surface area was 8837±4317 µm 2 and we determined 35±9 % of this area was associated with dense plaques. The surface area to volume ratio was positively correlated with maternal age (P=0.045). There were no signifi cant effects of age, parity or BMI on any of the other parameters. CONCLUSIONS: These results provide reliable ultrastructural information for human myometrial cells at term and demonstrate that maternal age may exert an infl uence on myocyte morphology. This smaller surface area per unit volume in myometrium from older women may have functional implications on calcium fl ux and membrane receptor densities.

Sulfasalazine Inhibits NF-kB and IL-1b Induced Cytokines in Cultured Amniocytes but Activates AP-1 and Increases Basal Cytokine Production. Lynne Sykes, 1 Kacie R Thomson, 1 TG Teoh, 2 Phillip R Bennett. 1 1 IRDB, Imperial College London, London, UK, United Kingdom; 2 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, St Mary's Hospital, London, UK, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: NF-kB controls the expression of labour associated and inflammatory response genes and is activated in amnion and myometrium in labour. Since the majority of cases of early preterm labour are associated with infection/infl ammation which places the fetal CNS at risk, targeting immune activation is an attractive therapeutic strategy for its prevention. Although we have shown that cyclopentenone prostaglandins inhibit NF-kB in vitro and in a murine model, these compounds have not been used as drugs. We have therefore explored alternate potential compounds. Sulfasalazine (SASP) has been shown to inhibit NF-kB and reduce pro-infl ammatory cytokine concentrations in studies of fetal membrane explants. We examined the effect of SASP on the transcription factors NF-kB and AP1 in cultured amniocytes and myocytes and its effect on IL-1b induced pro-infl ammatory cytokine synthesis. METHODS: Amnion and myometrium were collected from women at term undergoing pre-labour elective caesarean section. Cells were cultured until confl uent and treated with SASP or medium vehicle control, with or without IL-1b stimulation. NF-kB and AP1 activity was measured by western analysis of p-p65 and p-c-jun respectively. mRNA expression of the pro-infl ammatory cytokines was determined by RT-PCR. RESULTS: SASP (5mM) inhibited IL-1b induced NF-kB in amniocytes (p< 0.0001), but caused a rapid short lived activation of AP-1 (p<0.01). SASP also inhibited IL-1b induced production of IL-6, IL-8 (p<0.0001) and TNF-a (p<0.001) in amniocytes. However, it caused a rapid and transient increase in basal IL-6 (p<0.01), IL-8 and TNF-a (p<0.05) production. SASP also inhibited IL-1b induced NF-kB activity in myocytes (P<0.01), but had no significant effect on AP-1. At longer timepoints SASP was notably cytotoxic to myocytes as determined by the morphology of the cells and trypan blue test. CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, it is unlikely that SASP could be used for the prevention of inflammation induced preterm labour, since the concentration required to inhibit NF-kB also activates AP-1, increases cytokine production, and has cytotoxic effects.

Activation of Human Peripheral Leukocytes at Term and Preterm Delivery. Jun Takeda, 1,2 Brooke Hanson, 1 Xin Fang, 1 David M Olson. 1 1 Obstetrics/Gynecology and Physiology, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; 2 Obstetrics/Gynecology, Juntendo University, Tokyo, Japan.

The events of parturition at term and preterm are similar to those of an inflammatory response. Local uterine and fetal membrane chemotactic factors are released prior to delivery that activates peripheral leukocytes causing them to extravasate into uterine tissues where they stimulate labor processes. Previously we demonstrated that uterine tissue homogenates contained increasing chemotactic activity as gestation progressed from term not in labor (TNL) to term in labor (TL). However, the issue of whether leukocyte responsiveness changes as pregnancy progresses was not addressed. We hypothesized that leukocyte responsiveness to a term chemotactic signal increases as gestation progresses toward the onset of labor at term and preterm. METHODS: Proteins were isolated from fetal membranes collected from patients who delivered spontaneously at term. Blood was drawn by venipuncture from 4 different groups of patients; TL, TNL, threatened preterm labor (contraction alone (TPTL) or with fluid leakage (TPTLL)) and preterm not in labor (PTNL), and leukocytes isolated. Leukocytes and chemotactic extracts were placed into their respective sides of a Boyden chamber. Migrated leukocytes were quantitated using flow cytometry. The expressions of chemokine receptor mRNA abundance (CXCR1, 2, 3, CCR1, 2, 5) in leukocytes were assessed using quantitative RT-PCR. ANOVA and Student's t-test assessed significance. RESULTS: Leukocyte responsiveness increased to term chemotactic signals as labor progressed (TL vs. TNL plus PTNL, p<0.0001). Subanalysis revealed spontaneous TL leukocytes migrated more than leukocytes from induction of labor with oxytocin (p<0.05). TPTL leukocytes migrated more than PTNL leukocytes (p<0.05). Moreover, TPTLL migrated more than TPTL (p<0.02). However, chemokine receptors expression did not change in any group. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first report that human peripheral leukocytes increase their responsiveness to term chemotactic signals as labor progresses. This approach can be used to establish a preterm labor prediction test indicating who to treat to reduce the risk for preterm delivery. Additionally, this approach may identify risk for preterm labor in asymptomatic patients. The lack of change in leukocyte chemokine receptor expression suggests the intriguing possibility of a different type of chemoattractant. Acknowledgements: Juntendo University Faculty of Medicine, CIHR. is an environmental pollutant used as a plasticizer in polyvinyl chloride. Epidemiological studies have identified associations between maternal DEHP exposure and increased risk for preterm birth; however, the biological mechanisms underlying these relationships are unclear. Because cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) dependent prostaglandin (PG) synthesis is integral to the initiation of parturition, we evaluated the effects of mono-ethylhexyl phthalate (MEHP), the active metabolite of DEHP, on prostaglandin E 2 (PGE 2 ) synthesis and COX-2 expression in primary human placental macrophages (PM) and a human macrophage-like cell line, THP-1. METHODS: PM were isolated from placental tissue collected from normal, cesarean section deliveries at the University of Michigan Hospital. Human THP-1 cells were differentiated into macrophage-like cells by culturing with phorbol myristate acetate for 24 h. Cultures were treated for 2, 4, 8, or 24 h with MEHP concentrations ranging from 10-180 µM. PGE 2 concentrations were assessed in culture medium using ELISA, and COX-1 and COX-2 expression was determined by western blot analysis. RESULTS: Treatment of PM with 180 µM MEHP for 24 h significantly increased PGE 2 synthesis by 1.7-fold. This was reproducible when THP-1 cells were used to model PM behavior. Co-treatment of PM and THP-1 cells with the COX-2 selective inhibitor NS-398 resulted in a significant decrease in PGE 2 synthesis of 70% and 57% respectively, compared with MEHP alone, suggesting that MEHP-stimulated PGE 2 synthesis is dependent on increased COX-2 expression. Co-treatment of PMs with the non-selective COX inhibitor indomethacin reduced MEHP-stimulated PGE 2 synthesis by 77%, compared to MEHP alone, confirming COXdependence. Western blot densitometric analysis revealed a significant increase in COX-2 expression of 2-fold in THP-1 cells treated with 180 mM MEHP and no significant changes in COX-1 expression, supporting the role of COX-2 in MEHP-stimulated PGE 2 synthesis. CONCLUSIONS: The results from this study newly demonstrate phthalate-stimulated PGE 2 synthesis in human placental macrophages and warrant future studies into COX-2-dependent PG synthesis as a mechanism of toxicant-associated preterm birth. This work was funded by the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (P42 ES017198). METHODS: Thirty day old C57BL/6 mice were fed normal and vit D deficient diet for 6 wks and vit D levels were measured by RIA. Mice were pair mated and presence of sperm plug was designated as D1 pregnancy. Mice (n=3) from each group were administered LPS (400 ug/kg body wt) on D15 of pregnancy and sacrificed 6h later. Myometrial rings isolated were placed in organ baths containing 5.0 ml Krebs solution bubbled with 95% O2-5%CO2 at 37°C. A resting force of 1.25 g was placed on each strip, and the tissues were allowed to equilibrate for 1 h. Mean force developed per unit time by the strips was determined by measuring the area under the contraction curves in the absence and presence of vit D (10,100 and 1000nM). In 2 nd experiment continuous infusion pumps either with saline or vit D (.25ug/kg body.wt/day/14d) were placed s.c in normal (n=5) and VDD (n=5) mice on D8 and LPS was administered i.p on D17of pregnancy. RESULTS: VDD mice had significantly lower levels of vit D (0.9±0.5ng/ ml) compared to normal mice (6.9±1.5ng/ml). Basal relaxation in myometrium obtained from VDD mice is significantly (P<.05) lesser (18%) than in control mice (26%). In the LPS treated VDD mice, vit D (100nM) caused 36% relaxation which is significantly higher compared to18% in untreated. In normal mice treated with LPS, vit D (100nM) caused 27% relaxation compared to 26% in untreated. Pregnant mice delivered at 18±2h after LPS administration in normal groups with or without vit D pumps and VDD control group. In VDD mice with vit D pumps there was a significant delay (44.2±7.8h; P<.05) in delivery after LPS administration.

Our results suggest that vit D can prevent LPS induced myometrial contractility and delivery in vit D deficient mice and therefore could be a potential therapeutic strategy to prevent infection induced preterm birth. Our earlier studies have reported that rats exposed to Benzo(a)pyrene [B(a)P] an environmental toxin exhibit preterm birth. Epigenetic chromatin modification enzymes PCR array revealed both upregulation and down regulation of various histone deacetylases(HDACs). Objective: Since downregulation of HDACs are reported to enhance the expression of NFkB, we assessed the expression of HDACs and their consequent effects on cytokines and contractile associated factors in uterine myometrium of pregnant Long Evan rats exposed to B(a)P versus vehicle treated controls. METHODS: Timed pregnant Long Evan rats were gavaged 150, 300 and 600ug B(a)P from D14 to D17 of pregnancy and euthanized after delivery. Myometrium isolated was stored at -70°C until analysis. cDNA prepared from myometrium was subjected to real time PCR analysis using specific primers to IL-1 b, IL-6, IL-8,TNF a, receptor activator of NFkB (RANK), prostaglandin F2 a( FP) receptor and Connexin-43. Western analysis was performed using antibodies for HDACs, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 6, Connexin-43, Cox2, pIKBa and IKBa. Data was analyzed using one way ANOVA. RESULTS: Western analysis of lysates obtained from myometrium of B(a)P treated rats showed a significant (P<0.05) decrease in HDAC 1, 3 and 4. HDAC2 and 6 expression did not differ between treatments. Real time PCR analysis showed a significant increase in mRNA expression of IL-1 b, IL-6, IL-8,TNF a, RANK , FP receptor and Connexin-43 (p<.05) in myometrium of rats exposed to B(a)P vs. control. Western analysis showed an increase (P<0.05) in Cox2 expression. The increase in RANK mRNA expression was further complemented by the increase and decrease (P<0.05) in the expression of pIKBa and IKBa respectively which are the key regulators of NFkB pathway. CONCLUSIONS: Conclusions: This data suggests that exposure of rats to B(a)P, an environmental toxin, downregulates HDAC proteins. B(a)P treatment increases pro inflammatory cytokines, NFkB pathway proteins and contractile proteins probably via down regulation of Histone deacetylases. Further research is needed to assess the role of HDAC inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy to prevent inflammation induced preterm birth. Funding: RCMI 5G12 RR003032-27. The molecular mechanisms involved in human uterine quiescence during gestation and induction of labor at term or preterm are not completely known. Preterm delivery is associated with major morbidity and mortality and current efforts to prevent delivery until term are largely ineffective. Identification and semi-quantification of proteomic changes during pregnancy will allow for targeted research into how quiescence is maintained and what changes are associated with induction of labor.

We have recently performed 2D-liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry on myometrial proteins isolated from pregnant patients in labor, pregnant patients not in labor, and pregnant patients in labor pre-term. Relative protein expression levels were compared by spectral counting. We used Ingenuity Computational Pathway Analysis (IPA®) software to elucidate the global implications of differentially expressed proteins in PTL patients. IPA® was applied to identify perturbed molecular pathways and networks in PTL patients. RESULTS: We unambiguously identified 2132 protein groups with the following breakdown: 1869 proteins identified in term laboring tissue samples, 1963 proteins identified in term non-laboring tissue samples, and 2102 proteins identified in preterm laboring samples. We show that 201 of the 2132 proteins show disparate regulation in the PTL state as evidenced by a log 2 relative expression of ± 1 and p ≤ 0.05 as compared to the NL state when measured by semi-quantitative spectral counting. IPA® identified pathways centered around TNFa and mTOR that are disparately regulated during the PTL state.

To our knowledge this is the first large scale proteomic project on human uterine smooth muscle and this initial work has provided a target list for future experiments that can address how changing protein levels are involved in the induction of labor at term and preterm. Supported by NIH [R01 HD053028 (ILOB), 5K99HD067342 (HRB)], NIGMS 8 P20 GM103440-11 (NPC). To evaluate the accuracy of screening for short cervical length (CL) between 18-22 weeks of gestation in low-risk women with a singleton pregnancy, to identify women at risk for spontaneous preterm birth. METHODS: In a nationwide prospective study in The Netherlands, we measured cervical length using transvaginal sonography between 18-22 weeks of gestation in low risk women with a singleton pregnancy. Women with a history of preterm birth <34 weeks of gestation were not included. Short CL was defined as a cervix of ≤30 mm. Primary outcome was spontaneous preterm birth before 37 weeks of gestation. Secondary outcomes were preterm birth before 34, 32 and 28 weeks of gestation. Outcome data of women in our study were obtained from the Dutch Perinatal Registry database using record linkage.

Center: An Opportunity to Prevent the First Cesarean Delivery. Oscar A Viteri, Sean C Blackwell, Hind N Moussa, Baha M Sibai. Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, UT Health University of Texas Medical School at Houston, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Rising primary cesarean delivery (CD) rates contribute to adverse outcomes in future pregnancies. Data reveal increased CD rates in private provider groups compared to academic practice. Our objective is to determine the provider groups within our institution contributing the highest to CD rates and identify the obstetric populations where interventions can potentially occur. METHODS: Retrospective review of CD rates from 2008 to 2013 at a tertiary care facility stratifi ed by the 10category Robson Classifi cation System (RCS) and provider group practices. The RCS examines CD among mutually exclusive obstetrical groups providing a mechanism of audit and feedback. CD rates among vertex, singleton, term ≥ 37 wks, nulliparous gestations (VSTN) and variations among academic versus nonacademic provider groups were analyzed. RESULTS: There were 10301 CD (40.6%) among 25374 deliveries during the study period. The largest contributing categories for CD were prior CD (n=3615, 35%) and VSTN (n=2996, 29%). Signifi cant variations in CD rates among providers occurred in RCS Category 1 (VSTN, spontaneous labor) and RCS Category 2 (VSTN, induced labor).The total CD rate was higher in nonacademic vs academic provider groups (42.7% vs 37%, p<0.001). CD rates in RCS Category 1 (36.7% vs 23%, p<0.001) and RCS Category 2 (40.5% vs 32.7%, p<0001) were also higher in nonacademic provider groups. In RCS Category 5 (singleton, vertex, term ≥ 37 weeks, prior CD), the CD rate among provider groups was similar (range: 87% to 98%). CONCLUSIONS: We found that fi rst and repeat CD accounted for 64% of all CD. Signifi cant differences in primary CD rates in VSTN among provider groups were reported, with two of the nonacademic provider groups having rates over 50%. However, overall repeat CD rates were similar among all groups. Since repeat CD rates depend on the fi rst CD, initial efforts should focus on provider groups diverging from accepted primary CD rates to decrease downstream effects. Umbilical cord cortisol concentrations are a known marker of perinatal stress and have been correlated to factors such as mode of delivery, neonatal sex and delivery analgesics. Stress responses in neonates born to pregnant adolescents have been less well characterized in spite of increased risk of adverse birth outcomes. The aim of this analysis was to identify maternal and fetal determinants of cord cortisol concentrations in a racially diverse group of pregnant adolescents. METHODS: A total of 171 pregnant teens (ages 13-18y) entering prenatal care at 12-30 wks of gestation were enrolled in a larger study of maternal / fetal bone outcomes. Cord cortisol measures were available for a subset of this cohort (n=48). Of these teens, 62.5% were African American, 37.5% were Caucasian, and 27.1% were Hispanic. At up to 3 study visit across gestation, maternal anthropometrics and fetal biometry measures were obtained. Infl ammatory markers (IL-10, IL-6, CRP, TNFa) were assessed in maternal serum at mid-gestation and maternal and cord serum at delivery. Neonatal characteristics were collected at birth. Wilcoxon rank sums and regression were used to assess group differences and statistical determinants of cord cortisol at delivery. RESULTS: Most (n=45, 93.8%) teens delivered vaginally while one teen underwent assisted vaginal delivery and 2 delivered via c-section. All infants but one (gestational age of 35.1 wks) were born full term (›37 wks gestation). The mean cord cortisol concentration was 11.2 ± 6.7 mg/dL (range 3.8 -27.1 mg/dL, n=48). Cord cortisol was positively associated with infant birth weight (R 2 =0.11, p‹0.03) and birth length (R 2 =0.10, p‹0.04) but not maternal race or ethnicity, fetal sex, maternal prepregnancy BMI, gestational weight gain, labor analgesics, labor duration, placental weight, or infl ammatory markers. Cord cortisol was negatively associated with APGAR scores at one minute following delivery (R 2 =0.13, p‹0.02). When fetal size was assessed relative to gestational age, smallfor-gestational age babies (n=5) had signifi cantly lower cord cortisol compared to average size (n=40, p‹0.02) and large-for-gestational age infants (n=3, p‹0.04). Infl ammatory markers did not differ when assessed by average, small and large for gestational age infants. CONCLUSIONS: Infant birth size had a signifi cant positive effect on cord cortisol concentrations at delivery in pregnant teens.

back_matter.text: Effects of Nicotine Treatment on Timing of Birth, Fetal Outcome, Cervical Ripening and Uterine Contractility in Timed Pregnant Rats. Jinying Yang, 1,2,3 Shao-Qing Shi, 1,3 Leili Shi, 3 Huishu Liu, 1,2,3 Dajun Fang, 1,2,3 Robert E Garfi eld. The aims of this study were to examine the effects of nicotine on the length of gestation, fetal outcome and effects on cervical ripening and uterine contractility during pregnancy in rats.

Pregnant rats were treated daily with various doses of nicotine hydrogen tartrate (Sigma, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2 mg/kg/d, s.c.) starting on day 14 of gestation. Delivery times and fetal weights were obtained following birth. Cervical collagen cross-links were assessed daily in vivo by collagen light-induced fluorescence (LIF) and cervical extensibility (gestation day 20) and uterine contractility was measured in vitro. Plasma progesterone (P4) measurements (day 20) were done by chemiluminescence immunoassay. Cytokines were analyzed with ELISA. RESULTS: Delivery is significantly (P=0.002) longer after high dose nicotine treatments (mean ± SEM hours after 8 a.m. on day 22 of gestation = controls 15.8 ± 6.1 vs. nicotine 1 mg: 28.4 ± 4.7; 2 mg: 31.4 ± 5.3). Nicotine does not affect (P>0.05) the plasma levels (ng/ml) of P4 in control vs nicotine treated animals (controls =85.4 ± 7.2 vs nicotine= 87.6 ± 6.4). There are no significant (P>0.05) changes in pup weights (controls= 5.49 ± 0.29 vs 1'mg nicotine = 5.66 ± 0.23, gm ± SEM) and placenta weights (controls 0.39 ± 0.02 vs 1 mg nicotine +0.44 ± 0.03). Cervical LIF and extensibility progressively decrease throughout pregnancy in control rats. Nicotine-treated rats at days 16-20 of gestation show significantly (P<0.001) greater cervical resistance and higher LIF (P<0.001) compared with the control rats (LIF mean photons at day 20 ± SEM; controls= 1941 ± 55 vs nicotine = 2108 ± 39). Nicotine had little effect (P>0.05) on uterine contractility in dose/response studies. Serum cytokine analysis reveals a decrease in inflammatory response in nicotine-treated rats. CONCLUSIONS: Nicotine exposure during pregnancy inhibits cervical ripening without suppression of uterine contractility and thus prolongs gestation without deleterious effects on fetuses. Nicotine possibly acts on the cervix by suppression of a cholinergic anti-inflammatory response to delay delivery. This inflammatory pathway may provide a new target for control of the cervix.

Pregnant CD-1 Mice. SW Yang, 1,2 W Li, 2 O Shynlova, 1,2 S Lye, 1,2 JRG Challis, 1,3 G Reid, 4 GB Gloor, 4 AD Bocking. (2) evaluate the effect of GR-1 on these microbiota. METHODS: Live GR-1 bacteria (10 9 cfu, n=6) or saline (n=6) was given to pregnant CD-1 mice daily from gestational day (GD) 9 to 15 by oral gavage. On GD 16, DNA was extracted from vaginal and cecal tissues and bacterial DNA was amplified by PCR. The V6 region of 16S rRNA gene was sequenced (Ion Torrent). T test was used for comparisons between saline and GR-1 treated mice. q-values <0.1 (false discovery rate adjusted) were considered significant. RESULTS: We detected 65 and 43 bacterial families in the vagina and cecum of saline mice respectively. The most abundant families were Bacillaceae (12.0% of total bacteria), Streptococcaceae (5.7%) and Porphyromonadaceae (5.6%) in the vagina, and Porphyromononadaceae (28%), Lachnospiraceae (21%) and Bacteroidaceae (10%) in the cecum. GR-1 significantly increased the percentage abundances of vaginal bacterial species H. korlensis (from 0.001% in saline to 0.07% in GR-1 group); B.intestinihominis (0.02% to 1.04%); G. bacterium (0.01% to 4.59%) C.clostridioforme (0.01% to 0.06%); B.dorei (0.01% to 0.03%); R.flavefaciens (0.005% to 0.18%); H.bacterium (0.01% to0.06%); C.bacterium (0.013% to 0.21%; Family Clostridiacles); C.bacterium (0.01% to 1.28%; Family Lachnospiraceae); and C. bacterium (0.01% to 0.56%; Family Ruminococcaceae). These species were also present in the cecum of saline mice, however, GR-1 did not change their abundances.There was no change in Lactobacilli abundance in either vaginal or cecal tissues after GR-1 treatment. CONCLUSIONS: Oral probiotics alter the vaginal but not the cecal microbiota in pregnant CD-1 mice and these effects are independent of lactobacilli abundance. These findings provide insights to the potential role of probiotics on the vaginal microbiome and reproductive health.

back_matter.text: Lack of Fetal Masculinization or Feminization during Treatment of Pregnant Rats with Trimegestone (TMG). Jinying Yang, 1,2,3 Shao-Qing Shi, 1,3 Leili Shi, 3 Huishu Liu, 1,2,3 Dajun Fang, 1,2,3 Robert E Garfield. INTRODUCTION: Treatment with synthetic progestins during pregnancy often leads to masculinization of female fetuses or feminization of male fetuses. TMG is a potent progestin (6 X greater than progesterone) that might be used to treat preterm birth as it effectively inhibits preterm birth in animal models. However, the effect of TMG on fetuses is unknown. We examined if TMG would affect the viability of fetuses and alter the sex and fertility of the offspring of pregnant rats treated with TMG. METHODS: Timed-pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats (n= 7/group) were treated with vehicle (benzyl benzoate/caster oil, controls) or TMG (Taizhou Jiakan Chemical Co. Ltd. Zheijiang, China; 1 mg/day s.c.). TMG was tested for purity by Evestra (San Antonio, Texas). TMG-treated pregnant rats were sacrificed on day 22 of gestation, because they do not deliver spontaneously, and the pups (PTMG) were removed from the uterus and placed with surrogate control rats that delivered pups the same day and the normal pups were sacrificed. Thereafter the PTMG were raised by the surrogate rats and sexed and separated after 21 days.To determine if TMG affects breeding and fertility mature female PTMG (MTMG, n=5) at 5 months age were randomly selected and placed with non litter mate MTMG males for 6 days. Pregnant normal control rats were also bred and both MTMG offspring and controls were allowed to deliver fetuses and the pups were weighed. RESULTS: Control rats delivered viable pups on day 22 of gestation (113 pups/7 rats). Similarly PTMG (108 pups/7 rats) were all viable. After 21 days PTMG demonstrated no significant difference (P>0.05) in the sex ratio of male to female pups (53/60) compared to control pups (51/57). All MTMG females became pregnant following breeding with nonlitter mate MTMG males. Similarly male and female MTMG bred with normal control rats delivered viable fetuses. There was no significant differences between the MTMG bred and the control groups for pup weight (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: TMG is a very potent progestin that inhibits birth but does not affect fetal viability, fetal sexual characteristics or function and fertility of mature offspring. TMG may be very useful for treatment of preterm birth.

Rats. Abigail E Dobyns, Ravi Goyal, Lawrence D Longo, Steven M Yellon. Basic Sciences, Pediatrics, Ob/Gyn, Loma Linda Univ School of Medicine, Loma Linda, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: As a critical gatekeeper for birth, prepartum remodeling of the cervix is associated with infiltration by macrophages (Mj), increased proinflammatory mediators, and extracellular matrix degradation. Of the significantly up-or down-expressed genes, this study compared the cervix from prepartum (day 21 postbreeding) and nonpregnant (NP) rats, with or without Mj, to determine if there is 1) differential-regulation of Mj-related molecules in common to both groups, and 2) a prepartum Mj phenotype reflected by functional and canonical pathway analyses. METHODS: Dispersed cervix from term D21 and NP rats were either flash frozen or processed to remove Mj (n=3 rats/group). RNA extraction from June of 2012 to September of 2013. EKGs were performed prior to initiation of therapy for all subjects. EKGs were repeated in the third trimester for those on MTD maintenance. The QTc interval was calculated using Bazett's formula. Data was analyzed using Microsoft Excel. Twosample t-test and paired t-test were calculated. P-values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant. RESULTS: Fifty nine pregnant women were initiated on OMT. Thirty seven women were initiated on MTD while 22 were initiated on BPN. One patient was transitioned from BPN to MTD and thus was included in the analysis of MTD subjects. The mean QTc interval prior to initiation of therapy was 431.0 ms. The dose of MTD late in pregnancy ranged from 50 mg to 135 mg. The mean QTc interval in late pregnancy for those on MTD maintenance was 441.0 ms and it was not statistically different from prior to initiation of therapy. CONCLUSIONS: There appears to be no significant change in QTc intervals from prior to initiation of OMT when the women are using illicit drugs compared to late in pregnancy while on MTD maintenance therapy. Furthermore, the QTc interval at late pregnancy of women on MTD does not seem to differ from those not on MTD as compared to a previously published study of QTc interval in pregnancy. Observational studies indicate that trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) is safe, with a relative low risk for maternal-fetal complications. The aim of this study was to compare maternal-neonatal outcomes between nulliparae and women with a previous CD in spontaneous labor.

back_matter.text: We collected retrospectively all deliveries at our Department from 01/06/2011 to 01/06/2013. The TOLAC rate during the study period was 60%. We compared two groups of patients: term singleton cephalic nulliparae with spontaneous labor (group 1) and term singleton cephalic pregnant with previous CD, no previous vaginal birth and spontaneous labor (group 2). Data on demographic and obstetrics characteristics and perinatal outcomes were recorded. Statistical analysis included Fisher and T test, with P<0.05 considered significant. RESULTS: 1,771 patients were included: 1,549 for group 1 and 222 for group 2. Demographic characteristics were not clinically different. There was a significant difference in oxytocin use (25.8% vs 17.1%; p=0.005), epidural analgesia (23.2% vs 36.9%; p<0.001), spontaneous delivery (84.4% vs 62.2%; p<0.001) and CD (8.5% vs 29.7%, p<0.001). No differences were observed in episiotomy rate (38.4% vs 41.7%, p=0.436), average blood loss at delivery (334.1 ± 233.9 ml vs 390.5 ± 305.7 ml, p=0.008) and operative vaginal delivery (7.1% vs 8.1%, p=0.580). One case of uterine rupture occurred in group 2. Table 1 shows neonatal outcomes: no clinically significant differences were noted. In a University Hospital with a high rate of admission to TOLAC, VBAC is associated with similar perinatal outcomes as delivery of nulliparae in spontaneous labor. However, use of epidural analgesia and rates of CD were higher in the TOLAC group. (20) had abnormal fetal findings. For DM women with abnormal vs normal fetal echoes, there were no significant differences in maternal age(33 ± 5.1 vs 34 ± 5.5 yrs), preconception BMI(32.9 ± 8 vs 32.1 ± 7 kg/m 2 ),Type 2 DM(76% vs 78%),or glucose control(hemoglobin A1C 5.9 ± 0.8 % vs 5.8 ± 0.7%). Neonatal echoes on DOL 1 or 2 demonstrated 9/32(28%) cardiac findings had normalized, 11/32(34%) had hypertrophy, 5/32(16%) had ventricular septal defects, 4/32(12.5%) had patent ductus arteriosus, and 3/32(9.8%) had pulmonary hypertension. In neonates of DM mothers, birth weight was higher in infants with fetal HCM(4312 ± 705 g) compared to those without(3440 ± 788g, P <0.001) yet lower in those fetuses with cardiac dysfunction(3369 ± 948g) as compared to those without(3820 ± 716g, P <0.05). In neonates of DM mothers, leptin was elevated in those with fetal HCM(49.4 ± 35 ng/ml) as compared to those without(20.9 ± 24 ng/ml, P<0.05), whereas neonatal leptin levels were not elevated in those with fetal cardiac dysfunction(27.4 ± 26 ng/ml) as compared to those with normal function(26.8 ± 31 ng/ml). CONCLUSIONS: Elevated neonatal leptin and high birth weight are associated with fetal HCM but not cardiac dysfunction.

We studied a retrospective cohort of 1450 patients who underwent a low-transverse cesarean section from May to November of 2011 at a tertiary care women's hospital. Maternal infectious morbidity was defined as a postoperative fever (temperature greater than 101.3), endometritis, UTI, pyelonephritis, postpartum administration of antibiotics or a wound complication such as seroma, hematoma, cellulitis or need for wound exploration. The postoperative period was defined as the time from cesarean section to the postpartum visit. All patients received preoperative antibiotics and had a low transverse cesarean section. Risk factors significantly associated with maternal infectious morbidity in bivariate analysis were used in the multivariate logistic regression model. A p-value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. RESULTS: Of 1450 patients, 154 (10.6%) had a postoperative course complicated by a maternal infectious morbidity. In multivariate analysis, chorioamnionitis (OR 6.20; 95% CI 2.76-13.92), having the cesarean section performed by the resident teaching service (2.59; 1.67-4.03), and an operative time of greater than one hour (1.54; 1.01-2.34) were significantly associated with postoperative maternal infectious morbidity after adjusting for maternal medical comorbidities, previous cesarean sections, race, BMI and insurance status. CONCLUSIONS: Chorioamnionitis, an operative time greater than one hour and having the cesarean section performed by the resident teaching service are associated with an increase in maternal infectious morbidity following cesarean section. INTRODUCTION: Folate has been associated with a reduced risk of hypertension in non-pregnant patients and yet evidence relating folate to hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HTD) has been conflicting. Our objective was to evaluate the independent association between maternal folate status at <16 weeks gestation and blood pressure across pregnancy. METHODS: This is a secondary analysis of a prospective, observational cohort of 309 women with singleton gestations. Total serum folate was assayed by HPLC-tandem mass spectrometry at <16 weeks. Blood pressure was recorded at each prenatal visit until delivery. Total folate was categorized into tertiles and mean systolic, diastolic and mean arterial blood pressure was aggregated into gestational age epochs (<16 weeks, 16-29.9 weeks, 30-36.9 weeks, and ≥ 37 weeks). ANOVA and logistic regression analysis were used as appropriate. RESULTS: The median gestational age at enrollment was 9.2 weeks (IQR:7.5 -11.3). None of the women were folate deficient (serum total folate concentration <3 ng/mL). There were no significant differences between the mean systolic, mean diastolic, or mean arterial blood pressures across folate tertiles in any gestational age epoch, p>0.05 for all. There were 33 cases (10.7%) of HTD (gestational hypertension n=29, or preeclampsia n=4) in this cohort. There were no significant differences in total folate concentrations between those with or without HTD (total folate:27.96 vs. 27.08, p>0.05).

We did not detect an association between maternal folate status at <16 weeks and blood pressure across gestation. To determine if the odds of shoulder dystocia (SD) increase with maternal body mass index (BMI) in induced/augmented versus spontaneously laboring women.

In a retrospective study of all patients who delivered with SD from 1998 to 2010 at Roosevelt Hospital, controls without SD were matched 2:1 by maternal BMI, age, parity, and diabetic status. Included were cases and controls with available BMI. Conditional logistic regression models, with and without fetal-weight adjustments, estimated odds ratios for SD, comparing induced/augmented to spontaneously laboring patients for the entire population, as well as by BMI categories: healthy weight (BMI 18.5-24.9 kg/m²), overweight (BMI 25-29.9 kg/ m²) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m²). The level of significance was set at 5% (p<0.05). RESULTS: Included in the study 57,259 deliveries; 144 SD cases and 288 controls met study criteria. 107 (74%) SD cases were induced/augmented; 37 (26%) labored spontaneously. 136 (47%) controls were induced/ augmented; 152 (53%) labored spontaneously. The normal BMI category included 79 SD cases and 158 controls; the overweight category, 36 SD cases and 72 controls; the obese category, 29 SD cases and 58 controls. Across all BMI's, induced patients were 2.85 times more likely to have SD than non-induced patients (95% CI, 1.57-6.14; p<0.0006). After stratifying by BMI, induced normal-weight patients were 2.11 times more likely to have SD than spontaneously-laboring normal-weight patients; induced/augmented overweight patients were 4.74 times more likely to have SD than their spontaneously-laboring counterparts; and induced/ augmented obese patients were 5.64 times more likely to have SD than their non-induced cohorts.
Induction/augmentation appears to be associated with an increased SD risk with increasing BMI.

Helicobacter pylori Seropositivity and Gestational Diabetes Mellitus -A Prospective Cohort Study. Simona Cardaropoli, 1,2 Domenica Giuffrida, 2 Alessandro Rolfo, 2 Annalisa Piazzese, 2 Tullia Todros. INTRODUCTION: Admission of women in latent phase of labor is associated with higher cesarean section rates. Uterine electromyography (EMG) has been shown to predict delivery at term and preterm more accurately than other methods used in the clinic. The objective of our study was to determine whether uterine EMG differs between term patients in active vs. latent phase of labor. METHODS: EMG was recorded from the abdominal surface for 30 minutes in 28 patients: 7 in latent phase and 21 in active phase of labor at > 37 weeks of gestation. Latent phase was defined by contractions detected on tocodynamometry (TOCO) and no cervical change within at least four hours. Peak power frequency in "bursts" of uterine EMG activity and total power in bursts were compared in the active vs. latent labor group using the Student's T test (p≤0.05 significant). RESULTS: Peak power frequency in bursts was significantly higher (P=0.05) in active labor (1.39e-010 ± 2.65e-010 Hz) compared with latent labor (3.58e-011 ± 4,38e-011 Hz). Similarly, total power in bursts was significantly higher (P=0.04) in active labor (1.01e-09 ± 1.81e-09 V 2 ) compared with latent labor (2.61e-010 ± 2.78e-010 V 2 ). CONCLUSIONS: Peak power frequency in uterine EMG bursts and total power in bursts are higher during active phase of labor compared to latent phase. Uterine EMG can identify myometrial activation characteristic of active labor and allow clinicians not to admit womenin latent phase labor regardless of the presence of contractions on TOCO.

The Logistic regression models were constructed to assess the relationships between DM and outcomes using appropriate confounders and effect modifiers. RESULTS: Women with diabetes who had cesarean deliveries were statistically significantly less likely to have complications when compared to their non-diabetic counterparts (aOR 0.6 for DM1, 0.83 for DM2, and 0.89 for GDM). When stratified by BW, risk of adverse outcomes decreased significantly once BW exceeded 3000 gm (DM1) or 3500 gm (DM2 and GDM). In women who had vaginal deliveries, the risk of complications was increased among women with DM1 (aOR 1.41) or GDM (aOR 1.05); when stratified by BW, there was no clear pattern of increased risk. Women with DM2 who delivered vaginally had no statistically significant difference in maternal outcomes overall or when stratified by BW.

The risk of adverse maternal outcomes in women with DM varied across strata of delivery mode and BW. Contrary to our hypothesis, there was no clear pattern of risk in women with DM who delivered vaginally and adverse outcomes were inversely proportional to BW in women who had cesarean deliveries. This may be explained by nuances in practice patterns or treatment of DM in pregnancy. INTRODUCTION: ACOG recommends planned preterm cesarean hysterectomy (CH) for women with placenta accreta. This precludes future fertility. We tested whether CH can be avoided without increasing maternal morbidity rates when intra-operative decision for CH is made post-hysterotomy ("delayed") versus pre-hysterotomy ("early"). METHODS: Secondary analysis of a cohort of women with ultrasonographic (US) signs of accreta. Patients were consented for CH, but CH decisions were based on clinical parameters , such as size and complexity of vascularity visible on the exterior anterior uterine wall at the time of surgery. The primary outcome was rate of CH when the decision was made post-hysterotomy ("delayed"). RESULTS: 99 women had suspected accreta (2002) (2003) (2004) (2005) (2006) (2007) (2008) (2009) (2010) (2011) (2012) . Prehysterotomy "early" decision for CH was made among 26.3% women. "Delayed" decision was made for 73.7% women; among these 74% avoided CH. There were no differences in maternal demographics or obstetric characteristics between the "early" and "delayed" CH groups (table 1) . Patients undergoing CH had more blood transfusion, regardless of the timing of the decision. CONCLUSIONS: Decision for CH among women with suspected accreta who wish to retain fertility could be postponed until after delivery, and based on clinical parameters at the time of hysterotomy.

In silico analysis and microarray identified placental specific genes (PSGs) dysregulated in pregnancies complicated by FGR. The expression and localization of PSGs in the placenta in FGR was assessed using RT-PCR and ISH. Putative PSGs were measured in maternal blood at 28 weeks gestation in women with preterm FGR (n=20, birthweight <5 th centile, delivery <34 weeks) and women who developed term FGR (bwt <5 th centile, delivery >37 weeks). Term FGR was studied in 2 stages: 1) 100 low risk women recruited at 28 weeks underwent serial ultrasound and maternal blood sampling and the expression of PSGs in those with term FGR (n=12) was studied across gestation 2) A large prospective study of 600 women compared PSG expression in maternal blood at 28 weeks in women who developed term FGR (n=40) Active management of the third stage (oxytocin, quick cord clamping, controlled cord traction) scored 39%, whereas oxytocin was given in 89% of the cases. For women with >500 ml blood loss, low scores were seen for monitoring vital parameters (14%) and taking blood samples (25%). In managing atony, uterus massage was performed in 33%, bladder catheterization in 58% and uterotonics given in 53%. For women with >1000 ml blood loss, measurement showed very low adherence in oxygen supply (9%) and ordering blood units (11%). The gynecologist was summoned in only 43% of the cases. CONCLUSIONS: This study showed poor adherence to the quality indicators, clearly indicating an implementation problem of the evidence based PPH guideline and skills courses in The Netherlands. The additional video observations proved valuable as it gives a precise and accurate illustration of the factors that affect the quality of PPH-care. With these results a tailor made implementation strategy can be developped with the aim to improve quality of PPH-care. Maternal There is growing evidence that MO during pregnancy and lactation has long-lasting consequences for offspring health (chronic metabolic, endocrine and reproductive disorders). Adverse MO effects on offspring metabolic outcomes are well documented but reproductive consequences are poorly understood. We investigated effects of MO during pregnancy and lactation on testicular and sperm oxidative stress and impact on male fertility. METHODS: Controls (C) ate normal chow (5%-fat) while MO female rats ate a high fat diet (25%-fat) from weaning through pregnancy and lactation. After weaning all rats ate C diet. We determined serum testosterone, malonaldialdehyde (MDA), reactive oxygen species (ROS), superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity on testicular and sperm function at postnatal days (PND) 110, 450 and 650. RESULTS: At all ages testosterone was lower in the MO offspring group. At PND 450 and 650 testicular MDA concentration was higher in MO, ROS was elevated at all ages. The same tendency was observed in SOD and GPx activity. At PND 450 and 650, MO offspring sperm showed higher MDA and lower SOD and GPx activity with reduced sperm concentration, viability and motility. Fertility rate was unaffected at PND 110 but was lower in MO at PND 450 and 650. Figure 1 . Cleaved Srebp2 acts as a transcription factor for genes involved in cholesterol synthesis and uptake from the blood. We hypothesized that IUGR combined with a maternal HFD would adversely program the miR-96 -Insig2 -Srebp2 pathway and increase hepatic cholesterol in neonatal and juvenile rats. METHODS: Female rats were fed either a regular diet or a HFD prior to mating through gestation and weaning. IUGR was induced by uterine artery ligation at E19. Offspring were killed at birth or postnatal day 21. This produced four offspring groups per sex: control, IUGR, HFD, and IUGR-HFD. Hepatic miR-96, Insig2 and Srebp2 protein were quantified using real time RTPCR and Western blot. Hepatic lipids were measured with a colorimetric kit. RESULTS: Compared to sex-matched control, IUGR, and HFD groups, both neonatal and juvenile female IUGR-HFD rats had increased miR-96*, decreased Insig2 protein*, increased cleaved Srebp2 protein*, and increased hepatic cholesterol*. In male rats, IUGR-HFD did not affect levels of miR-96, Insig2, or hepatic cholesterol in either neonatal or juvenile rats, but increased cleaved Srebp2 protein* in juvenile rats. *p<0.05.

We conclude that IUGR combined with mHFD adversely programs the miR-96 -Insig2 -Srebp2 pathway and increases hepatic cholesterol in female, but not male, rats. We speculate that a sex-specific response to in utero nutrient stressors such as IUGR and mHFD may reflect a hepatic sex-specific microRNA stress response. The sex-specific in utero microRNA stress response is an ongoing focus of our group. Ectopic lipid deposition, including visceral obesity and hepatic steatosis, increases mortality in humans. The risk of developing ectopic lipid deposition is modulated by the in utero nutritional environment, such as with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) or a maternal high fat diet (mHFD). In developed countries, IUGR and mHFD often occur together. However, little is known about how IUGR and mHFD combined program increased ectopic lipid deposition. Ectopic lipid deposition is in part regulated by hepatic Pparg2, a transcription factor for lipogenic genes Acetyl CoA Carboxylase (Acc) and Fatty Acid Synthease (Fasn). We hypothesized that IUGR and mHFD combined would increase hepatic protein levels of Pparg2, Acc, and Fasn, hepatic triglycerides (TG), and serum free fatty acids (FFA) at birth, and would be associated with increased visceral adiposity in early adulthood. METHODS: Female rats were fed either a regular diet or a HFD prior to mating through gestation and weaning, and adult offspring continued on the maternal diet. IUGR was induced by uterine artery ligation at E19. Offspring were killed at birth or day of life (DOL) 60. This produced four offspring groups per sex: control, IUGR, HFD, and IUGR-HFD. Hepatic protein levels of Pparg2, Acc, phosphorylated Acc, and Fasn were measured with Western blot, hepatic TG with a colorimetric kit, and serum FFA with mass-spectroscopy. Abdominal MRI images were analyzed with ImageJ software to quantify visceral adipose tissue (VAT). RESULTS: Compared to sex-matched control, IUGR, and HFD groups, neonatal male IUGR-HFD rats had increased nuclear* and cytosolic Pparg2*, Acc*, pAcc*, and Fasn*, hepatic TG*, and serum saturated FFA (oleic*, stearic*, lauric*, eladic*, palmitic*, and palmitiladic*). IUGR-HFD increased hepatic TG*, but did not alter protein levels of Pparg2, Acc, pAcc, and Fasn, or serum FFA in neonatal females. Young adult male IUGR-HFD rats had increased VAT*. *p<0.05. CONCLUSIONS: We conclude that IUGR combined with mHFD increases lipogenic proteins and ectopic lipid deposition in male but not female rats. Pparg2 increases expression of lipogenic genes. However, Pparg2 agonists improve ectopic lipid deposition. We speculate that treatment of IUGR-HFD male rats with Pparg agonists will decrease lipogenic gene expression and ectopic lipid deposition.

Effect of Adiponectin on IL-6 and COX-2 Expression in Term Placental Explants. A Nawathe, 1,2 K Sung Hye, 2 M Savvidou, 1 M Christian, 2 M Johnson, 1,2 V Terzidou. This suggests that APN may play a role in regulating placental function. IL-6 has been implicated in pro-inflammatory placental state like preterm labour and diabetes. There is controversy whether adiponectin upregulates or downregulates IL-6 production while the effect of adiponectin on placental COX2 has not been studied until now. We hypothesized that APN treatment of term placental explants alters the IL-6 and COX-2 expression in placental cultures. METHODS: Placental samples (n = 6) from term, uncomplicated singleton pregnancies were collected within 15 minutes of delivery. 20 mg placental tissue was cultured in 1.5ml of RPMI, 10% FCS and 1% benzylpenicillin at 5% CO2 and 8% O2. RNA was extracted at day 0, 1, 3 and 5 as controls and APN (10microlitre/well) added on day 5. APN treatment was evaluated at two time points, 30 minutes and 6 hours. cDNA was prepared and qPCR performed according to manufacturer's instructions.

There was an increase in IL-6 and COX-2 expression on day 1 of explant culture which was unchanged at day 3 and day 5 of the culture. Treatment with APN had no effect on IL-6 and COX-2 expression at 30 min (p = 0.4) and 6 hours (p=0.35) on day 5 of the placental explant culture.CONCLUSIONS: APN does not alter IL-6 and COX-2 expressions in the term placental explants.

CORT significantly (p<0.05) increased the expression of PDK4 (12.0±5.4 fold), SOCS3 (3.0±1.4 fold), TXNIP (1.8±0.3 fold) and CYP26B1 (2.5±0.6 fold) compared to CON. These genes have roles in cardiac metabolism, thus validating the microarray findings. CONCLUSIONS: CORT differentially regulates pathways important for appropriate nutrient signaling in the heart suggesting peripartum fetal death after chronic exposure to cortisol may be linked to cardiac dysfunction, but by a different mechanism than death secondary to cardiac hypertrophy in adults.

Signal Oxygen deprivation at the time of birth is a major cause of neonatal brain injury, resulting in cerebral palsy and other neurological disabilities. Although a number of biochemical cascades have been implicated, the downstream targets at the level of transcriptional regulation still remain unclear. STAT3 is strongly upregulated following peripheral and central trauma and is thus a possible candidate. The aim of our study is to investigate the regulation and functional role of STAT3 in neonatal HI brain injury. METHODS: HI was induced based on the Rice-Vannucci model, in p7 mice, using 60 min exposure to 8% Oxygen. We used cell-specific conditional knock-out mice (n=6) where STAT3 was deleted in neurons using Synapsin-driven Cre-recombinase in STAT3-flox mutant mice. Littermate controls were homozygous for STAT3-flox but negative for Cre-recombinase (n=5). Pharmacological inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation via Jak-2 was achieved with WP1066 in C57/Bl6 mice (n=8) compared to DMSO (vehicle) -treated controls (n=8). The assessment of outcome was based on size of infarct (Nissl), extent of cell death (TUNEL density), microglial activation (alphaM&X levels) and astroglial activation (GFAP immunoreactivity). RESULTS: At immunohistochemical level, HI resulted in transient upregulation of phosphorylated STAT3 (Y705) in cortical, hippocampal and thalamic neurons, with a peak at 1-2 hours after 60 min insult. Compared to controls, neuron-specific deletion of STAT3 resulted in a significant reduction in infarct size (50-80%), cell death (80-90%), microglial activation (80% alphaM & 70% alphaX counts), and GFAP immunoreactivity (25%) in hippocampus, cortex, striatum, and thalamus following severe, 60 min insult. A more moderate effect was also observed in the subcortical white matter. Pharmacological inhibition of STAT3 activation following severe 60min HI insult resulted in significant reduction of STAT3 phosphorylation (70% in hippocampus and cortex, p<0.05) and also reduced brain damage in all regions (40%). CONCLUSIONS: Since Y705-phosphorylation plays an important role in STAT3 function, the use of direct kinase inhibitors could serve as a candidate target for therapeutic intervention in neonatal brain damage. CONCLUSIONS: The latency of fetal evoked brain activity changes during OGTT. Lower maternal insulin sensitivity is associated with slower fetal brain responses 60 minutes after glucose ingestion. These findings provide first evidence that maternal metabolism has a direct effect on fetal brain activity and suggest that central insulin resistance may be programmed during fetal development.
