In PUA, long-term high altitude hypoxia significantly decreased BK channel opener NS1619-and SK channel opener NS309induced relaxations, which were partially abrogated by ROS inhibitor NAC. Consistently, NAC significantly increased both BK and SK channel current densities in uterine arterial smooth muscle cells in pregnant animals acclimatized to high altitude. In NPUA, NS1619-and NS309induced relaxations were significantly diminished as compared with those in PUA. Treatment of NPUA with 17b-estradiol (E 2 ) and progesterone (P 4 ) for 48 h significantly increased BK b1 subunit and SK3 protein abundance and enhanced NS1619-and NS309-induced relaxations. In nonpregnant sheep acclimatized to long-term high altitude hypoxia, the effects of steroid hormones on NS1619-and NS309-induced relaxations were inhibited, and this hypoxia-mediated inhibition was reversed by NAC. Consistently, steroid hormones treatment had no significant effects on BK channel current density in the absence of NAC, but significantly increased the current density in the presence of NAC.

The present data suggest an important role of ROS in negatively regulating steroid hormone-mediated upregulation of Ca 2+ -activated K + channel activity and adaptation of uterine vascular reactivity in pregnancy, which may contribute to the increased incidence of preeclampsia and fetal intrauterine growth restriction associated with maternal hypoxia. (Supported by NIH grant HD031226).

Studies in the spontaneously hypertensive rats have demonstrated that increased angiotensin II results in an upregulation of NGF expression and sympathetic hyperinnervation in a range of target tissues. There is an increase in circulating noradrenaline concentrations in the IUGR fetus and we hypothesised that NGF would be elevated in the heart of the IUGR fetus due to changes in the renin-angiotensin system. METHODS: IUGR was induced by removing endometrial caruncles (placental implantation sites) in the non-pregnant ewe before mating. Ewes were humanely killed at 55, 90 and 140d gestation, the fetal heart was dissected, weighed and ventricular samples collected. Gene expression was determined relative to the geometric mean of 3 housekeepers using real-time PCR. Data were analysed using a 2 way ANOVA (age and treatment).

There was a decrease in body weight and heart weight in IUGR fetuses at all ages. Cardiac NGF gene expression was higher in the hearts of the IUGR fetuses compared to Controls at 90d gestation. ACE1 gene expression was lower in the IUGR fetuses at 140d gestation, however there was a delay in the rise of ACE2 gene expression at 90d gestation in the IUGR fetuses. There was no effect of IUGR on cardiac gene expression of adrenergic receptor beta 1,but interestingly adrenergic receptor alpha 2 was higher at 55d, 90d and 140d gestation in the IUGR group compared to Controls. CONCLUSIONS: These data show that NGF expression is higher in the heart of the IUGR fetus when sympathetic innervation occurs in the sheep fetus. This may be related to the changes in local angiotensin II expression (to be measured) and result in altered sympathetic innervation of the heart. These effects may be amplified by changes in cardiac expression of AR and underlie an increased vulnerability to cardiovascular disease. We have shown that exposure to maternal overnutrition and obesity in the periconceptional period (PCON) is associated with an increased risk of obesity and a decrease in insulin signalling molecules in the liver of the offspring during adolescence 1,2 . It is not clear whether changes in hepatic insulin signalling are programmed from before birth, or emerge in postnatal life. We hypothesised that PCON would result in decreased abundance of insulin signalling molecules in liver of the fetus and that administration of an insulin sensitising agent, rosiglitazone to the PCON group would ablate these effects. METHODS: Donor ewes were allocated to 1 of 4 groups: 100% metabolisable energy requirements (MER) from 4mos before until 6d after conception and administration of vehicle from 7d before to 7d after conception (C-V); 100% MER and administration of rosiglitazone (C-Rosi); ~180% MER and administration of vehicle (PCON-V); ~180% MER and administration of rosiglitazone (PCON-Rosi). Single embryos were transferred into recipient ewes at embryonic day 6-7. Post mortem was conducted at 141d of gestation (term, 150d) and liver samples collected for determination of the abundance of insulin signalling molecules using Western blot analysis. RESULTS: PCON resulted in decreased IRb and Akt2 abundance in the fetal liver independent of fetal sex and rosiglitazone treatment. The abundance of PI3K-p110b and PI3K-p85 was lower in liver of female fetuses in the PCON-V compared to the C-V group. There was also an increase in the ratio of PI3K-p85:p110b in the PCON-Rosi group compared to the C-Rosi group. CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, there was evidence that PCON resulted in an early programming of a decrease in the abundance of key insulin signalling molecules in the fetal liver. Administration of rosiglitazone in the PCON group did not ablate the impact of PCON on the abundance of insulin signalling molecules within the fetal liver. TNF-a and IL-10 mRNA levels were found in the HI group compared with naïve group. In both the contextual test and tone test of fear conditioning, reductions of freezing time were found in the 15min HI group compared with the naïve group. Interestingly, there is no statistically significant deference between CS and HI groups in the inflammatory cytokines levels and in neurocognitive outcome. CONCLUSIONS: These data demonstrate that perinatal hypoxia leads to neuronal damage and inflammation and that these cellular changes are associated with long-term neurocognitive abnormalities in CD1 mice. It is hoped to use this mouse model to improve long term outcome after perinatal hypoxia.

Insulin The sensitivity of the placenta to maternal insulin in vivo remains controversial. Early pregnancy may be a time of increased placental sensitivity to maternal insulin as insulin receptors are abundant on the syncytiotrophoblast in the first trimester, but are far fewer at term. Thus, we hypothesized that maternal insulin secretory capacity in early pregnancy would be positively associated with placental weight. METHODS: This is a secondary analysis of a cohort of women (n=40) recruited prior to pregnancy. An intravenous glucose tolerance test was administered pregravid and in early (12-14 wk), and late (34-36 wk) pregnancy (Catalano AJOG 1999). Placentas were trimmed, drained of excess blood and weighed. Neonatal fat mass was measured using skinfolds and total body electrical conductivity. Correlations between placental weight at term and 1 st (0-5 min), 2 nd (5-60 min) phase, total insulin secretory capacity before and throughout pregnancy were calculated. RESULTS: Fifteen women developed gestational diabetes (GDM) during pregnancy. We found no difference in the following relationships between GDM and normal glucose tolerant women, thus they were grouped together for subsequent analysis. The 2 nd phase and total insulin secretory capacity prior to (2 nd phase: r=0.344, p=0.024; total: r=0.338, p=0.0262) and in early pregnancy (2 nd phase: r=0.559, p=0.0001; total: r=0.536, p=0.0003), were positively associated with placental weight at term. Insulin secretory response in late pregnancy was not associated with placental weight. First phase insulin response before or during pregnancy was not associated with placental weight. Although neonatal fat mass was strongly correlated with placental weight at term (r=0.449, p=0.0003), maternal insulin secretory response was not related to neonatal fat mass at birth. CONCLUSIONS: Maternal insulin secretory response prior to and in early pregnancy was strongly related to placental weight at birth. Thus, in early pregnancy increased maternal insulin response as seen in obesity and GDM, may be a key influence on placental growth, possibly due to the enhanced presence of insulin receptors on the placental villi early in gestation. Furthermore, these data suggest that fetal adiposity is independent of maternal insulin concentrations per se but rather a function of increased maternal insulin resistance and subsequent nutrient availability for placental transfer. We sought to evaluate whether antibodies to cardiolipin (aCL) and b 2-glycoprotein (ab 2 ) vary during pregnancy in patients with lupus and/or antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL). METHODS: This is a secondary analysis of data collected from the PROMISSE Study, a multicenter, prospective, observational study of pregnancy outcome in women with aPL and/or lupus. Demographic, clinical, and treatment data were recorded at screening. Serological data were collected at screening (<20W), 2 nd trimester (20-23W), 3 rd trimester (32-35W), and 3 months postpartum (3MPP). aPL assays were performed in core labs and only patients who were positive (as determined by core lab) were included in this analysis (n=298). Antibody levels were compared across specific time points by fitting linear mixed effects models to the rank transformed data.

Med. Median levels of aCL IgG and ab2 IgG antibodies were lower at 20-23W (p<0.002) and 32-35W (p<0.0001) than at <20W or 3MPP; these differences were not clinically significant. Of 95 patients with high aCL (aCL IgG/IgM ≥40 units) at screening, 18 decreased. Of 172 subjects with negative or low titers at screening, none converted to high titers during pregnancy or 3MPP. Neither aCL nor ab2 antibody levels were associated with adverse pregnancy outcome after adjusting for LAC status. CONCLUSIONS: Among women with aPL or lupus, aCL and ab 2 antibody level variation is not clinically significant during pregnancy, suggesting that serial aPL antibody assessment is unnecessary.

Maternal Arginine and ADMA in Pregnant Women with Major Depression. Alexander Raw, Marcia Gallaher, Robert W Powers.Obstetrics & Gynecology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Depression is a major health issue, with a twelve month incidence around 8% and a lifetime prevalence of approximately 18%. Women are nearly twice as likely to be affected by depression. In addition, women who are depressed during pregnancy are at elevated risk of several adverse pregnancy outcomes including preterm birth, preeclampsia and postpartum depression. Asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA) is a novel and independent risk factor of cardiovascular disease (CVD) among low-, medium-and high-risk patient populations. Elevated levels of ADMA and lower L-arginine are hypothesized to contribute to depression via adverse vascular effects. The objective of this study was to investigate differences in asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA), symmetric dimethylarginine (SDMA), and L-arginine among pregnant women with major depression. METHODS: Case-control study of 21 depressed pregnant women and 42 matched controls from the PEPP study. Maternal plasma ADMA, SDMA, and L-arginine were quantified, as well as C-reactive protein (CRP), urine excretion of ADMA, SDMA, L-arginine, and Arginase I.
Among individuals with a family history of hypertension, a sibling history of HPDs is associated with an increased risk of CHD events and hypertension in men, but not in women who did not have a HPD.

Maternal Adaptation to Pregnancy: Changes in Circadian Expression of Hepatic Clock Genes in Mouse Gestation. Michaela D Wharfe, Peter J Mark, Caitlin S Wyrwoll, Brendan J Waddell. School of Anatomy, Physiology and Human Biology, The University of Western Australia, Australia. INTRODUCTION: Maternal physiology undergoes major adaptations in pregnancy to ensure growth and development of the fetus and placenta whilst maintaining maternal wellbeing. Under normal conditions, many physiological processes (e.g. glucose homeostasis and oxidative metabolism), oscillate in circadian patterns driven by biological clocks entrained to the light-dark cycle.Clock genes (e.g. Clock, Bmal1, Per1) expressed within the suprachiasmatic nucleus and peripheral tissues (liver, kidney etc.), drive these metabolic processes in a circadian manner. How pregnancy impacts on clock gene expression and how this relates to changes in metabolic processes seen in pregnancy is currently unclear.Here we examined whether circadian expression of hepatic clock genes changes with the onset and progression of gestation. METHODS: Tissues were collected from C57Bl/6J mice (n=6 per group) at diestrus I in non-pregnant animals, or on day 10-11 or day 18-19 of gestation (term = day 19). Collections were performed at 6 circadian time points (0800, 1200, 1600, 2000, 0000, 0400h) throughout each 24 h period. mRNA expression levels for the core canonical clock genes were measured by RT-qPCR. RESULTS: While robust circadian rhythms in mRNA expression were evident for both Bmal1 (P<0.001) and Per1 (P<0.001) at all stages, pregnancy resulted in major changes in both their absolute expression and circadian patterns. Bmal1 expression increased dramatically (all circadian time points) between diestrus and day 10 (up to 14-fold; P<0.05), whereas Per1 increased 2-to 4-fold at 0800h (P<0.001), 2000h (P=0.027) and 0000h (P=0.011). Expression of both genes then fell between days 10 and 18 (Bmal1 by up to 96%; P<0.001; Per1 by up to 89%; P=0.002). Pregnancy also altered the circadian expression patterns of both genes; the amplitude of Bmal1 expression fell from 30-fold at diestrus to 12fold at day 10 before recovering by day 18. In contrast, Per1 amplitude increased from 13-fold at diestrus to 25-fold at day 10 of gestation, but then fell to only 3-fold by day 18. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, our data indicate that pregnancy induces major changes in the core circadian clock machinery of the maternal liver, an effect likely to drive key maternal metabolic adaptations. but subsequent studies did not confirm that association. We sought to determine whether subsequent mode of delivery (VD /CD) or the presence or absence of labor (+/-) prior to obtaining the sample were associated with differential methylation patterns in maternal leukocyte DNA. METHODS: Genome wide methylation profiles of maternal leukocyte DNA were evaluated in 29 women <24 hours prior to delivery of a term infant. Blood was drawn either during active labor (+) defined as painful contractions and dilation > 4 cm or in the absence of labor (-) prior to a scheduled cesarean or induction. Mode of delivery was ascertained by chart review. Bisulfite modified genomic DNA was run on the Infinium HumanMethylation450 BeadChip Kit interrogating 450,000 CpG sites genome wide. Mean methylation at CpG sites were compared using a t-test, with correction for multiple comparisons using the false discovery rate (FDR); sites with a p <0.05 were considered significant. RESULTS: There were 12/29 + labor and 15/29 CD. After FDR correction, methylation patterns did not predict subsequent mode of delivery nor did the presence or absence of labor prior to blood draw alter methylation patterns in maternal leukocyte DNA. CONCLUSIONS: Acute events in parturition, such as the presence of labor, do not alter methylation patterns in maternal leukocytes. Nor does the maternal methylome predict mode of delivery. This can be contrasted with other factors like the presence of pregnancy alone (versus nonpregnant), the trimester of pregnancy, and the presence of preeclampsia at delivery which we have previously shown to impact the methylation pattern in maternal white blood cells. Our work suggests that labor and mode of delivery are not confounders in analysis of maternal leukocyte DNA methylome. Chronic hypoxia during gestation increases uterine vascular tone, which is associated with an increased risk of preeclampsia and fetal intrauterine growth restriction. However, the mechanisms underlying chronic hypoxia-enhanced uterine arterial tone are not fully understood. The present study tested the hypothesis that chronic hypoxia increases reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, inhibiting steroid hormone-mediated ERK signaling pathway and increasing uterine vascular tone in pregnancy. METHODS: Uterine arteries were isolated from nonpregnant (NPUA) and pregnant (PUA) (~140 day gestation) sheep maintained at either sea-level or high altitude (3,820m for 110 days, PaO 2 : 60mmHg). Uterine vascular function was determined in the 4 groups of animals. RESULTS: Long-term high altitude hypoxia increases ROS production in PUA but not NPUA. In pregnant sheep, pressure-induced myogenic tone of the uterine artery was significantly enhanced in hypoxic animals, as compared with the normoxic control. Pretreatment of uterine arteries with a ROS inhibitor, apocynin significantly inhibited vascular tone in hypoxic animals, and abrogated the difference in vascular tone between hypoxic and normoxic groups. In hypoxic animals, an ERK inhibitor, PD098059 had no effect on either pressure-dependent myogenic tone or PKC activator PDBu-induced contractions in the absence of apocynin. However, PD098059 significantly potentiated the vascular tone and PDBuinduced contractions of uterine arteries in the presence of apocynin. In nonpregnant sheep of hypoxic animals, treatment of uterine arteries with 17b-estradiol (E 2 ) and progesterone (P 4 ) for 48 h had no significant effects on pressure-dependent myogenic tone or PDBu-induced contractions in the absence of apocynin, but it significantly attenuated both pressureinduced vascular tone and PDBu-induced contractions in the presence of apocynin.

Our data suggest that the heightened ROS production plays a key role in chronic hypoxia-mediated increase in uterine arterial vascular tone by suppressing steroid hormones/ERK-mediated adaptation of the uterine artery in pregnancy, which may contribute to the adverse pregnancy outcomes caused by high altitude hypoxia. (Supported by NIH grant HD031226).

Chronic Hypoxia Alters the Interaction of PKC and Ca 2+ -Activated K + Channels and Uterine Arterial Reactivity in Pregnancy. DaLiao Xiao, Ronghui Zhu, Lubo Zhang. Center for Perinatal Biology, Dept of Basic Sciences, Loma Linda University School of Medicine, Loma Linda, CA, USA.

Our previous studies have demonstrated that chronic hypoxia-mediated increase in uterine arterial contractility is associated with enhanced PKC activity and reduced Ca 2+ -activated K + channel (K-channel) activity in pregnancy. However, the interaction between PKC activation and K-channel activity remains unknown. The present study tested the hypothesis that chronic hypoxia alters the interaction of PKC and K-channels, resulting in maladaption of uterine vascular reactivity in pregnancy. METHODS: Uterine arteries were isolated from nonpregnant (NPUA) and pregnant (PUA) (~140 day gestation) sheep maintained at either sealevel or high altitude (3,820m for 110 days, PaO 2 : 60mmHg). Contractions of uterine arteries were determined. RESULTS: In uterine arteries of normoxic pregnant sheep, selective inhibition of large-conductance K-channels (BK) significantly enhanced PKC activator PDBu-induced contractions. In contrast, inhibition of small-conductance K-channels (SK) had no significant effect on PDBumediated contractions. This BK channel inhibition-mediated potentiation of PDBu-induced contractions was abrogated in uterine arteries of pregnant animals acclimatized to long-term high altitude hypoxia. In normoxic PUA, activation of both BK with NS1619 or SK with NS309 produced concentration-dependent relaxations, which were not altered by the addition of PDBu. However, in uterine arteries treated with chronic hypoxia (10.5% O 2 for 48 h), both NS1619-and NS309-induced relaxations were significantly attenuated by PDBu. In uterine arteries of nonpregnant sheep, BK inhibition significantly enhanced PDBu-induced contractions in both normoxic and hypoxic animals.

The results indicated that activation of BK suppressed PKC-mediated uterine arterial contractions in normoxic animals, and hypoxia significantly attenuates the effect of BK on PKC-mediated contractions in pregnant, but not in nonpregnant animals. In addition, activation of PKC had no effect on BK-or SK-mediated relaxations in normoxic animals, but attenuated the relaxation in hypoxic animals. These findings suggest that in normal physiologic condition BK downregulates PKC activity and vascular contractility, which is selectively attenuated by hypoxia in pregnant animals. In addition, hypoxia-enhanced PKC downregulates BK and SK activities and relaxations of uterine arteries in pregnancy.(Supported by NIH grant HD031226).

Claudia J Bautista, 1 Sara Montano, 1 Peter W Nathanielsz, 2 Elena Zambrano. 1 1 Reproductive Biology, Instituto Nacional de Ciencias Medicas y Nutricion SZ, Mexico City, DF, Mexico; 2 Center for Pregnancy and Newborn Research, University of Texas Health Sciences Center, San Antonio, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Milk long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (LC-PUFA) arachidonic acid (AA) and DHA are produced 60% in maternal liver and 30% in mammary gland via desaturases (D5D and D6D) and elongase (Elovl 2 and 5) enzymes and constitute the major source of theses essential nutrients for the neonate. Arachidonic acid (AA) and DHA are essential LC-PUFA for normal development especially of the brain. METHODS: Female rats were fed control diet (C= 5% fat) or obesogenic (MO= 25% fat) during growth (21-120 days), pregnancy and lactation. At lactation day (LD) 20, milk was obtained and LD 21 liver and mammary gland obtained at necropsy, weighed and fatty acid profile measured by gas chromatography. Liver and mammary gland D5D and D6D and Elovl 2 and 5 were analyzed by immunohistochemistry, serum leptin and insulin serum by RIA, triglycerides and glucose (enzymatic method). Mean ± SE, t-student, * p <0.05, n = 5. RESULTS: Mothers were similar in body and liver weight, but mammary gland weight and serum leptin, insulin, triglycerides and glucose were higher in MO vs C. Fat (%) was higher in MO liver, mammary gland and milk (Fig 1A) . Liver AA was lower in MO vs C (Fig 1B) while mammary gland AA and DHA were similar between groups. Milk DHA was lower in MO vs C. Desaturases were higher and elongases were lower in liver and mammary gland from MO vs C.
back_matter.section: S-147 Maternal Obesity (MO) in the Rat Increases Fat and Decreases Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA) in Milk at Lactation Day (LD) 21.

back_matter.text: Chen. Dept Ob/Gyn, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Enhanced endothelial nitric oxide (NO) production via eNOS activation regulates vascular smooth muscle function contributes significantly to the dilatory effects of estrogens in the vasculature. However, whether smooth muscle regulates endothelial function is less studied. Endogenous hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S) is primarily synthesized from L-cysteine by cystathionine b-synthase (CBS) and cystathionine g-lyase (CSE), which also dilates the vasculature. Hypothesis: Endothelial and smooth muscle derived H 2 S mediates estrogen activation of eNOS in endothelial cells. METHODS: Primary ovine uterine artery endothelial cells (UAEC) and uterine artery smooth muscle cells (UASMC) were cultured in MCDB 131 with 10% FBS. After starvation in phenol red-free M199 with 1% charcoal-striped FBS, UAEC were treated with 10 nM estradiol-17b (E2) or H 2 S donors for 5 min with or without specific CBS and CSE inhibitors for analyzing eNOS activation by immunoblotting and UAEC and UASMC were cultured for measuring H 2 S production by a novel H2S-specific fluorescence probe. UAEC were cultured in the bottom and UASMC were co-cultured on the membrane (pore size 1.0 mm) of transwell inserts to study endothelium-smooth muscle interaction in regulating endothelial eNOS activation in the presence and absence of CBS and CSE inhibitors. RESULTS: E2 and H 2 S donors stimulated rapid eNOS activation in UAEC and H 2 S production in both UAEC and UASMC. Pretreatment with either CBS or CSE or both inhibitors attenuated E2-, but not H 2 S donor-stimulated eNOS activation in UAEC. Co-culture with UASMC alone stimulated eNOS activation in UAEC, which was blocked by the presence of specific CBS and CSE inhibitors. CONCLUSIONS: Endothelial and smooth muscle cell production of H 2 S functions upstream of eNOS activation in response to estrogen stimulation, implicating a novel role of H 2 S in mediating endothelium-smooth muscle cross-talk. (NIH HL70562 & HL98746) .
back_matter.section: S-148 Endothelium and Smooth Muscle Cross-Talk: Smooth Muscle and Endothelium-Derived Hydrogen Sulfide Mediates eNOS Activation by Estrogen. Honghai Zhang, Tomas J Lechuga, Amy Lee, Dongbao

back_matter.text: Zollner, 1 Hung-Yen Ke, 2 Suren R Sooranna, 1 Kenneth T MacLeod, 2 Mark R Johnson. 1 1 Academic Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Imperial College, Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, London, United Kingdom; 2 National Heart and Lung Institute, Imperial Centre for Translational Medicine, London, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: The sodium potassium pump plays an important role in the modulation of heart failure. We aimed to study the myocardial expression level of the sodium potassium pump (ATPase1a1 and ATPase1b1) in guinea pig cardiac myocytes in a model of cardiac pressure overload induced by transverse aortic constriction (TAC) in male and female GP. METHODS: GP subjected to TAC, male (n=15) and female (n=14). GP subjected to sham surgery, male (n=13) and female (n=5); Total RNA was extracted from left ventricles tissues using the RNeasy kit from Qiagen and the mRNA converted to cDNA. Copy numbers of ATPase-1a1, ATPase1b1 and GAPDH were measured by qPCR using a Rotor-Gene TM (Corbett Research, Australia). The results are presented as a ratio of GAPDH (mean ± SEM). For western blotting protein samples were denatured at 75 0 C, separated by electrophoresis and transferred onto a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hertfordshire, UK). The membranes were incubated in 5% milk solution, washed with tris-buffered saline and tween 20 (TBS-T) and incubated with specific primary antibodies overnight at 4 0 C. Following this incubated with secondary antibody for 1 hour at room temperature. Western Blotting Luminol Reagent (sc-2048 Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., USA) was used to expose protein bands, which were expressed as a ratio of GAPDH. RESULTS: Aortic constriction increased ATP1a1 in both the female and male groups at 150 days following TAC. ATP1a1 was raised in the females from 25461 ± 15205 to 10213011 ± 10153573 and in males from 5.22 ± 2.14 to 18.67 ± 14.66. Interestingly, in the male group, there was a greater increase in ATP1a1 expression at 60 days following TAC than at 150 days (p<0.05 in all cases). Western blotting confirmed increased protein expression at cellular level. ATPase1b1 expression increased in the females from 14.56 ± 7.86 to 105.68 ± 48.81 and in males from 14.09 ± 5.85 to 45.91 ± 34.43. CONCLUSIONS: We demonstrate in this guinea pig model of heart failure that the sodium potassium pump is up-regulated. We also note gender differences. Currently the belief is that the sodium potassium pump functions inadequately during heart failure stage. Extension of this work will study the sodium potassium pump in heart disease during pregnancy. . Several normal chromosomes were present in 6 copies and 11 specific clonal chromosome rearrangements were present (fig 1) . In comparison, the composite karyotype of 3A-subE cells was 69~81, XXX[cp20] with several normal chromosomes present in 4 copies and 15 specific clonal rearrangements. A single population of SWAN-71 cells was observed with a DNA index of 5N. Both cell lines showed a high percent of cells in S phase (37-40%); however, SWAN -71 cells showed a higher proliferation rate. Ingenuity Pathway Analysis revealed that the most statistically significant difference in canonical pathways was inhibition of p53 signaling in SWAN-71 versus 3A-subE cells (p = 1.48E-07). CONCLUSIONS: Although SWAN-71 cells have been reported to retain similar features as primary first trimester trophoblast cells, extended growth in culture appears to have favored the appearance of aneuploid clones with genetic alterations in cell-cycle regulatory pathways. Thus, these findings emphasize the need to monitor for genetic instability in hTERT-immortalized cells and also the need for caution in the use of these cells to study normal trophoblast biology.
back_matter.section: S-149 The Expression of the Sodium Potassium ATPases in Cardiac Myocytes in a Guinea Pig Model of Transaortic Constriction. Julia

back_matter.text: Inflammatory and Angiogenic Changes in the Placenta. Clare M Reynolds, Clint Gray, Claudia Harrison, Mark H Vickers. Liggins Institute, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand. INTRODUCTION: Maternal high-fat and/or salt intake is associated with developmental programming of hypertension and cardiovascular disease in adult offspring. There is significant evidence that inadequacies in placental nutrient transport may be responsible. We speculate that diet-induced inflammation may have detrimental effects on placental function leading to alterations in key nutrient transporters and angiogenic factors. The present study examined the effects of a maternal high-fat and/or salt diet on markers of placental nutrient transport, inflammation and angiogenesis. METHODS: Virgin Sprague-Dawley rats were assigned to a) control (CD; 10% kcal from fat), b) high salt (HS; 4% salt, 10% kcal from fat), c) high fat (HF; 45% kcal from fat) or d) high-fat high-salt (HFS; 4% salt, 45% kcal from fat) 21 days prior to time-mating and throughout gestation. At embryonic day 18, placenta and fetuses were weighed, sexed and collected for molecular analysis. RESULTS: Maternal HS, HF and HFS consumption decreased weight of placenta derived from male offspring compared to CD; however weight of placenta derived from female offspring was only reduced with maternal HF diet. This was associated with increased expression of LPL and GLUT4 in placenta derived from male offspring indicating increased fetal exposure to free fatty acids and glucose. Maternal HS, HF and HFS dietary intake increased expression of pro-inflammatory mediators IL-1b, TNFa and CD68 in placenta derived from male offspring. Furthermore DLK1, VEGF, VEGFR1 and VEGFR2 expression was increased indicating altered angiogenic potential in placenta derived from male offspring. CONCLUSIONS: Our results suggest that placental inflammatory profile results in detrimental alterations in nutrient transport and placental angiogenesis which, in part, may contribute to the developmental origins of cardiovascular disease. We have studied singleton chorionic arterial and venous networks. Monochorionic twins have identical genetic makeup and so should share some of the genetic influence on angiogenesis and vascular networks. We explored the relationship of features of arterial and venous networks, and anastomosis type/number, in monochorionic twins delivered without laser ablation/modification of the vasculature. METHODS: 49 pairs of monochorionic twin placentas were injected post partum with colored dyes, and the larger and the smaller twins' (LT, ST) arterial and venous networks were traced according to a standard protocol. A total of 66 variables were extracted from LT and ST arterial and venous networks. Data reductions for variables related to the LT and ST arterial and venous networks were performed separately yielding 6,6,6, and 7 factors for the 4 networks, respectively. Regression adjusted birthweight discordance (BWD= larger-smaller/larger) for gestational age (GA), then added anastomoses type/number. Next the 4 factor sets were added separately, and point estimates of effect and significance compared. RESULTS: Extracted himfactors accounted for 83-87% of total data variance. Four of the 6 LT arterial network factors were correlated strongly with at least one ST arterial factor (p<0.001), 4 of 6 LT venous factors were more weakly associated with at least one ST venous factor (p<0.01). In regression with BWD and GA, only the presence/number of arterio-arterial (AA) anastomoses was positively correlated with BWD. Addition of LT or ST arterial factors or ST venous factors did not alter association with BWD, but inclusion of LT venous factors showed 4 of 6 factors associated with BWD with loss of correlation of type/number of AA anastomoses. LT venous factors were uncorrelated with AA presence/number. CONCLUSIONS: The LT venous network structure has the strongest correlation with BWD in unlasered monochorionic twins, by default with mild twin transfusion. Anastomoses may influence network structure, possibly preferntially in venous drainage networks. How LT venous structure alters the association of AA anastomoses with BWD remains to be determined. Although the placental volume growth pattern is known to be sigmoid, there does not exist a validated mathematical model that predicts placental volume growth over time. We developed a mathematical model that predicts placental volume growth at any gestational day. METHODS: We estimated the three parameters in the logistic growth model; the growth rate, the placental volume carrying capacity, and the 11-14 week placental volume (initial condition), from two placental volume data sets. We applied the placental volume measurements to algebraically determine the initial condition and the carrying capacity. By using the fact that the inflection point occurs at approximately 22 weeks, we calculated the growth rate by setting the second derivative of the placental volume model equal to zero and algebraically solving. We restricted parameter estimation to early measurements and then compared late gestation predicted to actual placental volumes.

back_matter.text: The model generated realistic placental volume growth curves demonstrating initial rapid growth followed by a slower limiting growth.The model predictions tracked actual data well and demonstrated good agreement across gestational time points.

The developed model has clinical potential for classifying healthy versus at risk pregnancies through identification of placental growth patterns that deviate away from model predictions. Exosomes are nanoparticle (40-100 nm) membrane vesicles that are released following the exocytotic fusion of multi-vesicular bodies with the cell membrane. The significance of exosomal signaling in diverse aspects of physiology and pathophysiology has only recently been recognized. Recently, we demonstrated that exosomes are released from first trimester placental mesenchymal stem cells (pMSC) and increased endothelial cell migration and vascular tube formation. The molecular mechanisms that mediate exosome effects are not well defined, therefore the aim of this study was to further elucidate potential interactions and pathways activated by exosomal proteins isolated from pMSC exposed to low oxygen tensions. METHODS: pMSC were isolated from placental villi (8-12 weeks of gestation, n=6) and cultured under an atmosphere of 1%, 3% or 8% O 2 . Cell-conditioned media were collected and exosomes (exo-pMSC) isolated by differential and buoyant density centrifugation using a sucrose continuous gradient. The presence of spherical vesicles was established using electron microscope and the expression of exosomes markers by Western Blot. Proteins captured with exosomes (exosomal proteins) and identified by LC-MS/MS on 5600 Triple TOF mass spectrometer (AB Sciex) were analysed using the Mascot and Protein Pilot search engines against the Swissprot-swissprot database with the species set as human (scores greater than 30). False discovery rate (FDR) was estimated using a reversed sequence database. Proteins identified were submitted to bioinformatic pathway analysis (Ingenuity Pathway Analysis [IPA]). RESULTS: Exo-pMSC were identified as nanovesicles with a typical cupshape and diameters around of 100 nm and positive for exosome markers: CD63, CD9 and CD81. MS analysis identified over 400 different proteins involved in cytoskeleton organization, development, immunomodulatory, and cell-to-cell communication. The IPA revealed oxygen-dependent changes in protein content and signaling pathways. CONCLUSIONS: pMSC-derived exosomes promote vasculogenesis and participate in vascular formation in the human placenta, the exosomal protein contents could potentially be used as molecular targets for futures studies. and toxicity studies in humans, but has not been applied to endocrine studies. We aimed to characterize and validate placental explants from both humans and mice for sex steroid studies. Mouse placental explants were evaluated in addition to humans, since mice are a common model in reproductive and developmental research. METHODS: Human and mouse placentas were collected by caesarean section, dissected and plated in Ham's F12 medium, then cultured for up to 96h. Explant viability and sex steroids were measured in media. Expression and activities of the placental steroidogenic (3b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, aromatase), clearance (UDPglucuronosyltransferase (UGT), sulfotransferase (SULT)), and regeneration enzymes (b-glucuronidase (b-G), arylsulfatase C (ASC)) were determined in explants. RESULTS: Human and mouse explants were viable for up to 96h, but progesterone, estrone, and estradiol secretion decreased. Steroidogenic enzyme expression and activities were stable in mouse explants and similar to freshly isolated tissue. In contrast, steroidogenic enzymes in human explants were significantly lower than in fresh tissue (P<0.01). The ratio of UGT:b-G activities in human explants shifted towards less steroid elimination, SULT was detected in human but not mouse explants, and neither demonstrated ASC activity. CONCLUSIONS: In mice, steroidogenesis in culture remains accurate to the in vivo situation and may be useful for endocrine studies and associated fields, e.g., endocrine disruption. Human placental explant cultures are not useful for studying steroidogenesis, but are useful for studying short term metabolic clearance and transfer (<48h). Despite these discrete uses, neither mouse nor human placental explants are appropriate for studying sex steroid endocrinology in totality due to culture effects on endocrine pathways.

Circulating Angiogenic Cells. Andrea Schanz, 1 Alexandra P Hess, 1 Margerete Lukosz, 2 Dunja M Baston-Bust, 1 Christian Heiss. 2 1 OBGYN/ UniKid, Heinrich-Heine-University, Medical Faculty, Düsseldorf, Germany; 2 Cardiology, Pulmonology, and Vascular Medicine, Heinrich-Heine-University, Medical Faculty, Düsseldorf, Germany. INTRODUCTION: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) has long been associated with the initiation and maintenance of pregnancy, but to date its role in angiogenesis and recruitment of vascular active cells is not fully understood. In this study, the role of hCG and its receptor in various human endothelial cells, such as lymphatic, uterine microvascular, umbilical vain, and circulating angiogenic cells was examined.
back_matter.section: S-159 HCG Stimulates Angiogenic Signals in Lymphatic Endothelial and

back_matter.text: Immunohistochemistry and immunoblot analysis were used to detect the LH/hCG receptor. HCG induced angiogenic molecules, such as HIF-1a via ELISA and downstream molecules, such as CXCL12 and CXCR4 via realtime PCR were determined. Functionally, the chemotactic properties of hCG were studied using Boyden chambers. RESULTS: The LH/hCG receptor was detected in lymphatic, uterine microvascular, umbilical vain, and circulating angiogenic cells. Furthermore, hCG induced key angiogenic molecules, i.e. HIF-1a, CXCL12, and CXCR4 and led to a dose dependent migration of cells that was specifically inhibited by LH/hCG antibodies. CONCLUSIONS: The findings point to the importance of hCG as one of the first angiogenic molecules produced by the conceptus. HCG itself alters endothelial motility and recruitment, but is also involved in indirect mechanisms, like oxygen independent HIF induction, which might be crucial for vascular modifications and adaption in early placental formation, implantation, the development of an ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome or tumor growth. INTRODUCTION: Impaired spiral artery remodeling is a major pathology of the human pregnancy-specific hypertensive disorder preeclampsia (PE). Corin is a cardiac protease important for regulating blood pressure. Placental corin deficiency perturbs mouse spiral artery remodeling, resulting in hypertension during pregnancy. However, whether placental corin expression is developmentally regulated and affected by preeclampsia during human pregnancy is not well-understood. Hypothesis: Human placental corin expression is developmentally regulated and downregulated in preeclampsia. METHODS: Normal placentas were collected from the first (5-11 wks, n=9) and second (14 -17 wks, n=8) trimester pregnancies of elective terminations and the third trimester at delivery (38 -39 wks, n=7). Placentas were also collected from C-sections of term severe preeclampsia with small for gestational age (PE-SGA, n=3) or appropriate gestational age (PE-AGA, n=6), severe preeclampsia with gestational diabetes mellitus (PE-GDM, n=4) and GDM (n=5) controls, as well as earlyonset (prior to 34 wks) PE with SGA (pre-SGA, n=3), AGA (n=6), and gestational age matched preterm controls (n=7). Total RNA samples were extracted for measuring corin mRNA expression by real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) and quantified by DCT algorithm using L-19 as the reference. RESULTS: Placental levels of corin mRNA increases with gestational age and are significantly greater in the third compared to the first and second trimesters (p<0.01). Placental corin mRNA levels in pre-PE-SGA did not differ from that of pre-AGA. However, the levels are significantly lower in the PE-SGA and PE-GDM compared to normotensive controls (p<0.05). No difference was found between the GDM and normotensive placentas. CONCLUSIONS: Human placental corin mRNA expression increases during pregnancy and is downregulated in some types of preeclampsia, suggesting a role of corin in placental development and the pathogenesis of preeclampsia (NIH HL70562 & HL98746).

Signaling Pathways Implicated in Oncostatin M-Induced Matrix Metalloproteinase-2 and -9, and Invasion Activity, in HTR8/SVneo Cell Line. Hyun Sun Ko, 1 Sae Kyung Choi, 1 Hee Kyung Kang, 1 Ho Shik Kim, 2 In Yang Park, 1 Jong Chul Shin. Our previous studies have shown that OSM promotes trophoblast invasion activity via the increased enzyme activity of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-2 and -9. Here, we further investigate OSM-induced intracellular signaling mechanisms associated with these events in the immortalized human trophoblast cell line, HTR8/SVneo. METHODS: The activation of signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT)3 and extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERK)1/2 induced by OSM were examined by western blot. To investigate the involvement of the STAT3 and ERK signaling pathway on OSM-induced MMP-2 and-9 expression, we pretreated HTR8/SVneo cells with STAT3 inhibitor (stattic) or ERK1/2 inhibitor (U0126), prior to OSM treatment. In addition, the effects of STAT3 and ERK siRNA transfection on OSMinduced MMP-2 and -9 expressions were investigated by Western blot. The invasion activities of HTR8SVneo cells by OSM were measured by matrigel invasion assays, according to the STAT3 or ERK inhibition. RESULTS: OSM induced STAT3 and ERK1/2 phosphorylation, and it was blocked by the inhibitors, respectively. OSM-induced MMP-2 and -9 protein expressions were significantly suppressed by STAT3 inhibition with stattic and STAT3 silencing, respectively (p< 0.05, both), while ERK1/2 inhibitor, U0126, and ERK silencing significantly suppressed OSM-induced MMP-2 protein expression, only (p< 0.05). The increased invasion activity by OSM was significantly suppressed by STAT3 or ERK1/2 inhibition (p< 0.01 and p< 0.05, respectively), which was more pronounced by STAT3 inhibition. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated that both of STAT3 and ERK signaling are related with the OSM-induced invasion activity via upregulating expression of MMP-2 and MMP-9 in trophoblast cells. The activation and upregulation of STAT3 appears to be critical for the OSMmediated increase in invasiveness of HTR8/SVneo cells.

First Trimester Placental Volume Analysis in Fetal Growth Disorders. T Stampalija, 1 V Maggi, 2 D Casati, 2 D Di Martino, 2 C Mastroianni, 2 E Rosti, 2 S Zullino, 2 V Signorelli, 2 E Ferrazzi. The functional integrity and normal development of placenta are crucial for fetal expression of its genetical predisposition to grow. The aim of the study was to evaluate first trimester placental volume (PV) in: 1) small for gestational age newborn (SGA) define as birthweight <10 th pc; 2) growth restricted newborn (IUGR) define as birthweight <5 th pc; 3) IUGR with hypertensive disorder (IUGR-HD); and 4) controls.

In this cross-sectional study, at 11+0-13+6 wks, PV was calculated by VOCAL (4D View, GE). Mean uterine artery pulsatility index (Ut-PI), PAPP-A and b-HCG were recorded. Placental quotient (PQ) was obtained by the formula: PV(cm 3 )/crown rump length(cm). One-way ANOVA with Bonferroni post-hoc analysis was used. Values are expressed as means±SD. RESULTS: There were no differences in demographic maternal data. The PQ was lower in all groups of fetal growth disorder compared to controls, and the difference was highest for IUGR-HD (Figure) . Ut-PI was significantly higher in IUGR-HD (2.40±0.20) compared to all other groups (controls 1.52±0.43, p<0.0001; SGA 1.55±0.060, p=0.001; IUGR 1.63±0.56, p=0.003; respectively). There were no differences in Ut-PI between controls, SGA, and IUGR (all p>0.05). PQ correlated significantly to PAPP-A MoM, b-HCG MoM, and birthweight (Spearman's Rho 0.24, p=0.001; 0.23, p=0.002; and 0.29, p<0.0001; respectively), but no to Ut-PI (-0.11, p=04) .

Fetal restriction associated to maternal complications is associated to important placental volume deprivation and high vascular resistance in uterine arteries as soon as first trimester. The fact that the PV does not correlate with Ut-PI suggests that the low PV is not necessarily determined only by the placental vascular impairment due to insufficient trophoblastic invasion, but could reflect the morphometric characteristic of the constitutionally small fetus.

Siglec-6 Phosphorylation at Intracellular Tyrosine Residues Leads to the Recruitment of SHP-2 Phosphatase. Adrianne L Stefanski, 1,2 Michael D Renecle, 1 Kristen K Rumer, 1 Virginia D Winn. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Colorado-AMC, Aurora, CO, USA; 2 Graduate Program in Reproductive Sciences, University of Colorado-AMC, Aurora, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Siglec-6 is a sialic-acid binding transmembrane receptor expressed on cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts of the human placenta. Interestingly, placental expression of Siglec-6 is unique to humans. Siglec-6 is overexpressed in the placentas of pre-eclamptic pregnancies. However, the function of Siglec-6 in the human placenta is currently unknown. Many structurally similar Siglecs become phosphorylated on intracellular tyrosine residues, recruit SH-2 phosphatases, and initiate downstream inhibitory signaling cascades. However, it is currently unknown if Siglec-6 becomes tyrosine phosphorylated and signals in this manner. We sought to test the hypothesis that Siglec-6 can become tyrosine phosphorylated and recruit SHP-2 via intracellular signaling. METHODS: Site-directed mutagenesis was used to mutate residues thought to be important for Siglec-6-dependent signal transduction. Specifically, both intracellular tyrosine residues were mutated alone (Y413F, Y433F) or in combination (YFYF), and an intracellular truncation was created (ICtrunc). HTR-8/SVneo cells were transfected with Siglec-6, Siglec-6 mutants, or empty vector (pCDH). Cells were treated with or without pervanadate and cell lysates were (co)-immunoprecipitated (IP) using an anti-Siglec-6 antibody. (co)-IP lysates were analyzed by Western blotting with anti-Siglec-6, anti-phosphotyrosine (4G10), and anti-SHP-2 antibodies. RESULTS: Following pervanadate treatment, Siglec-6 becomes phosphorylated on both intracellular tyrosine residues (Y413, Y433). Pervandate-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of Siglec-6 was abrogated by mutation of both intracellular tyrosine residues (Y413, Y433). Phosphorylation of Siglec-6 recruited the downstream phosphatase SHP-2. CONCLUSIONS: Placental Siglec-6 has signaling potential via intracellular tyrosine phosphorylation and the SHP-2 pathway. Siglec-6, which is increased in PE, may contribute to signaling that impacts trophoblast function and contributes to PE pathogenesis. (Ecs) and functions as a negative feedback regulator of angiogenesis. Vasohibin-2 (VASH2) is a homologue of VASH1 and functions to promote angiogenesis. To date, few studies have investigated the role of Vasohibins in placental angiogenesis. In the present study we aimed to: i) investigate the spatial expression of VASH1 and VASH2 in human placenta; and ii) evaluate the functional role of VASH2 in murine placental development. METHODS: Human placental tissue was collected from normal pregnancies (n=4) and used for immunohistochemistry analysis. Timedmated vasohibin2 -/transgenic (Vash2null, n=19) and C57BL6 (wild-type, n=30) mice were euthanized on 12.5 (n=5/6), 16.5 (n=6/5) and 18.5 (n=9/5) eGA (estimate Gestational Age). We performed immunohistchemisry for CD31 antibody ,endothelial cell marker, and calculated the fetal vascular area covered with CD31 staining. We used quantitative RT-PCR (qRT-PCR) to analyze placental expression of Glial-cell missing 1 (Gcm1, a placenta-specific transcriptional factor), differentiation-inducing factor for trophoblasts and syncytin B, a key regulator for trophoblastic fusion, regulated by Gcm1. The statistical significance of differences between groups was evaluated with Student's t-test .The ethics permission for these studies were obtained from the ethics committee of Tohoku University. RESULTS: In human placenta, VASH1 was expressed in fetal vascular ECs, and VASH2 was expressed in trophoblast cells. Placental weight in the Vash2null mice was significantly less than the control group at 18.5 eGA (72 ± 3 mg vs. 82 ± 3 mg, p<0.001).The fetal vascular area in the labyrinth layer in Vash2null placenta was significantly smaller than controls at 18.5 dpc (29 ± 5 % vs. 36 ± 6 %, p<0.01). The placental expression of Gcm1 was unchanged between groups. Interestingly, syncytin B expression in Vash2null placental tissue was significantly suppressed by 50% compared with controls. CONCLUSIONS: In the present study, we have demonstrated differential expression of VASH1 and 2 in human placenta. Furthermore, we propose that VASH2 might play important role in murine placental morphogenesis through regulation of syncytin B expression.

Identification of Candidate Genes in Human Placenta Involved in the Development of Childhood Allergy. Astrud R Tuck, Annette Osei-Kumah, Zarqa Saif, Vicki L Clifton. Robinson Institute, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia. INTRODUCTION: The prevalence of childhood allergic disease has increased dramatically in developed countries. Modern environmental changes are hypothesised to be causing deviations in fetal programming, in which the placenta plays a central role, increasing the susceptibility and prevalence of disease throughout life. We hypothesised that susceptibility to childhood allergy is determined by changes in placental function that programs immune function in the fetus in a sex-specific manner. In this study we aimed to identify candidate genes and pathways in human placental tissue that may contribute to the development of childhood allergy. METHODS: Human placental tissue was obtained after delivery from women giving informed consent at the Lyell McEwin Hospital, Adelaide, and global gene expression was examined via microarray analysis. Placentae from pregnancies that gave rise to children with allergy by 4 years of age (n=45) were compared to placentae from children with no allergy (n=17), and sex-specific differences were also examined. Differentially expressed genes and pathways associated with allergy were identified using Ingenuity Pathway Analysis software. Immune genes with a fold-change greater than 1.5 were validated by qPCR. Statistical analysis was performed on males and females separately with significance set at P<0.05. RESULTS: Microarray analysis identified placental gene changes in dermatological and respiratory disease networks of male offspring, and immunological disease and immune cell trafficking networks of female offspring who developed an allergy. Specifically, qPCR validation showed increased expression of interleukin 13 receptor alpha 1 (IL13RA1) and decreased expression of toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7) and matrix metalloproteinase 9 (MMP9) (P<0.05). These immune genes were also expressed in a sex-specific manner. Cytokine growth factor kit ligand (KITL) and its receptor, kit, were not associated with allergy but expression was shown to be higher and more variable in female placentae compared to male placentae (P<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: This study has identified genes known to be involved in inflammation that appear to be differentially regulated in male and female placentae, suggesting sex-specific roles in fetal development. The roles of each gene in placental function and fetal development are unknown, and may have sex-specific roles in the programming of fetal immune function and contribution of allergy susceptibility. To verify whether fetuses classified as adequate for gestational age (AGA) at birth and who showing a declined intrauterine growth curve, have an increased risk of adverse perinatal outcome. METHODS: A group of singleton pregnancies (n=509) were prospectively evaluated: 1st trimester dating, excluding small for gestational age (SGA) and large for gestational age (LGA) fetuses, fetuses affected by intrauterine growth retardation, fetal malformations and preterm birth. Fetal growth parameters were evaluated by US routinary biometry in the mid trimester (22-24 weeks) and in the imminence of delivery (37-41 weeks). Each parameter of abdominal circumference (AC) was converted to Multiples of Median (MoM) according to the Local Reference Curve and a coefficient of variation was calculated between the two measurements (Delta MoM), to identify fetuses who showed a decreased intrauterine growth trend (Delta MoM<0 -cases) and fetuses who maintain or improve their intrauterine growth trend (Delta MoM ≥ 0 -controls). Neonatal outcome measures were: birth weight, Apgar
