We conducted an analysis of delivery-related hospital discharges using 1998-2009 annual data from the Nationwide Inpatient Sample, the largest publicly available all-payer inpatient care database in the US. PA and clinical outcomes were identified using International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification diagnosis codes. The cost of inpatient care was estimated from hospital charges. Logistic regression was used to calculate adjusted odds ratios (AOR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) representing the association between PA and each adverse outcome. Generalized linear modeling was used to estimate the excess direct medical costs incurred by PA-affected pregnancies. RESULTS: There were 197,421 diagnoses of PA during the study period, representing a national prevalence of 354 per 100,000 delivery-related discharges. PA was associated with an increased risk of preterm labor (AOR=1.67; 95% CI=1.61-1.74), early onset delivery (AOR=2.32; 95% CI=2.24-2.41), poor fetal growth (AOR=1.49; 95% CI=1.40-1.60), stillbirth (AOR=7.81; 95% CI=7.38-8.26), prolonged hospital stay (AOR=1.29; 95% CI=1.22-1.37), and hysterectomy (AOR=13.69; 95% CI=12. 30-15.25 ). An inpatient discharge with a PA diagnosis costs, on average, $1,226 more than one without PA, translating into over $99 million in additional healthcare costs from 2001-2009. CONCLUSIONS: PA is associated with an increased odds of adverse maternal-fetal outcomes, and a significant increase in the cost of inpatient care. Since the major risk factor for PA is a previous cesarean section, interventions that effectively lower the primary cesarean section rate have the potential to reduce maternal-fetal morbidity and mortality, and realize substantial cost savings. and smoking effects on umbilical vascular dynamics, we measured catecholamine levels in umbilical cord tissues and correlated effects on catecholamines with METH use, tobacco smoking and clinical obstetric outcomes. METHODS: Umbilical cords (54) were collected prospectively at birth, washed of blood then immediately stored frozen at -80 °C. Cords were thawed and whole lysates prepared, protein normalized and catecholamine levels quantified with ELISA. Results were compared to pregnancy demographics, clinical outcomes, METH and smoking status. RESULTS: Catecholamine levels in umbilical tissues (arterial and vein endothelia) were not associated with maternal age, gravidity, parity, gestational age, neonatal or placental weight. Neither smoking nor METH affected dopamine or epinephrine. However, smoking (2-fold) and METH (4-fold) decreased norepinephrine levels in mono-drug mothers and had synergism (60-fold reduction, P = 0.025) in mothers who both smoked tobacco and used METH.

Cesarean section was associated with significantly lower epinephrine levels (P< 0.001) compared to vaginal delivery regardless of drug use. Hypertension during pregnancy was associated with significantly lower cord norepinephrine (P < 0.001) of ~150 fold in all samples tested with no further detectable effects from drug ingestion. However, in normotensive pregnancies; each drug significantly decreased norepinephrine levels (2-fold smoking and 3.5-fold METH) with a 40-fold decrease in norepinephrine for METH/smoking together, regardless of delivery method. CONCLUSIONS: Exposure of METH and tobacco, alone and together, alters catecholamine levels in the umbilical vessels of normotensive mothers and may interfere with catecholamine signaling in parturition.

Complex Regulation of RNA Splicing in the Syncytiotrophoblast. Debra Goldman-Wohl, 1 Caryn Greenfield, 1 Iris Eisenberg-Loebl, 1 Galia Skarzinski, 2 Ronit Haimov-Kochman, 1 Tal Imbar, 1 Ilana Ariel, 2 Simcha Yagel. We established a fluorescent in situ hybridization system that enables detection of snRNA (small nuclear RNA) in the placenta. Based on this methodology we demonstrated reduced U2 and U6 snRNA in the syncytiotrophoblast throughout the course of pregnancy suggesting that while the placenta has evolved a large surface area for transport function a method evolved to control protein production in the massive number of syncytial nuclei. Using this RNA in situ system and qRTPCR we also showed reduced snRNA in primary trophoblasts and trophoblast cell lines cultured under fusion conditions. We have now extended our observations to placental pathologies where protein expression may be dysregulated, as well as to proteins of the spliceosome complex. METHODS: RNA in situ hybridization of U2 and U6 snRNA was performed on placental sections of pathologies including: molar pregnancies (n3), choriocarcinoma (n1) preeclampsia (n4) and trisomy 21 (n5) and normal controls. Analysis of proteins associated with splicing and the spliceosome complex of normal placental sections was performed using the Human Protein Atlas database. RESULTS: As in normal placenta, snRNA was reduced in syncytiotrophoblast of molar pregnancies, preeclampsia and choriocarcinoma. Inconsistent results were obtained in placenta of trisomy 21 (3/5 reduced). Proteins associated with splicing were generally not downregulated in the syncytium although RBFOX2 was downregulated. CONCLUSIONS: Transcriptional downregulation, as detected by reduced snRNA in syncytiotrophoblast of placental pathologies, suggests that this mechanism is not defective in the protein dysregulation associated with these pathologies. However, in a subset of trisomy 21 the altered protein levels may be associated with altered transcriptional downregulation. Interestingly, RBFOX2, a protein involved with alternate splicing and epithelial to mesenchymal transition and interaction with estrogen receptor 1 transcription factor is downregulated in the syncytium. Thus the enigmatic reduced snRNA of the syncytium is preserved in most placental pathologies whereas most associated splicing proteins investigated are not downregulated in normal placental syncytium. Chorionic villi (CV) are essential for the transport of oxygen and metabolites in the maternal-fetal interface. Studies from our group demonstrated the upregulation of Ang II in the CV of preeclamptic (PE) women. We determined whether preeclampsia alters the expression of apelin or apelin receptor (APJ) in CV and whether Ang II reduces apelin release from the placental CV explants obtained from normotensive pregnant (NP) women and PE women at the time of delivery (36-38 wks of gestation). METHODS: Apelin levels were determined by radioimmunoassay (RIA). APJ mRNA was determined by the real time RT-PCR. CV were incubated for 0, 2 and 16 hours (hrs) in DMEM/F12 media with or without Ang II (1 nM and 1 µM), and for 2 hrs with Ang II plus losartan (1mM) under controlled O 2 and CO 2 . RESULTS: Apelin levels were reduced in CV of PE vs NP (PRE: 15117 ± 883.1 vs. NP: 19424 ± 1309 pg/g of tissue, p<0.01). The levels of APJ mRNA in CV were not different in PE vs NP. The unstimulated release of apelin was significantly reduced in the conditioned media from PE vs NP villi at 2 hrs (PE: 181.1 ± 31 vs. NP: 309.5 ± 51.4 pg/ml, p<0.05). There was a significant increase in apelin release from both NP (267.8 ± 34.8 vs.

baseline: 118.4 ± 27.3 pg/ml, p<0.01) and PE (293.5 ± 25.8 vs. baseline: 122.6 ± 24.8 pg/ml, p<0.01) CV at 16 hrs. Ang II inhibited the release of apelin from CV of the NP at 2 hrs (p<0.05). At 16 hrs, Ang II inhibited the release of apelin from both NP (2 fold) and PE (1.8 fold) villi (p<0.05). AT1R antagonist losartan increased apelin release from CV of NP and PE (p<0.05). APJ was predominantly localized to syncytiotrophoblasts and fetal vascular cells of CV -areas associated with AT1R localization. CONCLUSIONS: The levels of immunoreactive apelin were reduced in the placenta of PE. Our data showing a negative influence of Ang II on apelin release from CV suggest an opposing interaction between these peptides in the human placental tissue. Reduced apelin activity would remove its counter-regulatory actions on Ang II-induced endothelial dysfunction, increased vascular resistance, and inflammation -abnormalities which precede and sustain preeclampsia.

Pang, Yanhong Yu. Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Nanfang Hospital, Southern Medical University, China. INTRODUCTION: Trophoblast invasion into the maternal endometrium plays a crucial role in human pregnancy. Dysregulation of the finely controlled process of trophoblast invasion can lead to a wide spectrum of pregnancy abnormalities. Various studies have demonstrated that invasion process is facilitated by the activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs). However, the relationship between the expression of these invasion-associated proteinases and the abnormal trophoblast invasion-related diseases has not been elucidated so far.
back_matter.section: S-178 Dysregulated Expression of Matrix Metalloproteinases and Their Inhibitors May Participate in the Pathogenesis of the Abnormal Trophoblast Invasion-Related Pregnancy Diseases. Jiayu Zhu, Zhanjun

back_matter.text: The study group consisted of placental bed biopsy tissues obtained from complete hydatidiform mole (N=6), normal vaginal deliveries (N=15), normal ceaseran deliveries (N=15), preeclampsia (N=24) and fetal grown restriction (N=10). We evaluated the expressions of MMP-2, -8, -9, -11, -19, -15 (MT2-MMP), -16 (MT3-MMP), -24 (MT5-MMP), TIMP-1 and -3 by applying western blot and immunohistochemistry methods. RESULTS: In the five groups, we detected protein levels of eight MMPs and two TIMPs. Comparing to the normal pregnancies, MMP-2, -8, -9, -11, -19, MT2-MMP and MT-5-MMP were strongly expressed in hydatidiform mole tissues (p<0.05), while the expression of MMP-2, -8, -9 were down-regulated in villous tissues of pre-eclampsia and FGR cases (p<0.05). TIMP-1, -3 was increased in pre-elcampsia (p<0.05). Whereas MMP-11 was only down-regulated in pre-elcampsia (p<0.05). TIMP-3 was found only increased in FGR (p<0.05). No significant difference was found between normal vaginal deliveries and cesarean deliveries. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study reporting alterations in MMPs and TIMPs that are related with varying degrees of local trophoblast invasion. We speculate that the change of invasion-associated proteinases expression will affect placental development and may thus contribute to the development of abnormal trophoblast invasion-related diseases of pregnancy such as complete hydatidiform mole, pre-eclampsia and FGR. Placental CRH expression increases in the third trimester resulting in an exponential rise of maternal CRH levels towards term. The increase is predictive of the time of labour suggesting that it is associated with the mechanism that determines gestational length. We have explored the possibility that epigenetic DNA methylation is involved in the gestational programming of CRH gene activity in trophoblast cells.

Cytotrophoblasts from term placentas (n=3) were cultured for 72 h until spontaneous syncytialisation with or without stimulation with 8-BrcAMP. CRH mRNA and peptide levels were measured with qRT-PCR and RIA, respectively. Methylation of the 9 CpG sites in the CRH proximal promoter was determined by bisulfite sequencing, and promoter binding of pol-II, TBP and phospho-(p)CREB was measured by chromatin immunoprecipitation. RESULTS: CRH mRNA abundance increased 60-fold by 72 h relative to fresh cells and was further stimulated to 900-fold by 8-BrcAMP. CRH peptide cumulative output had similar kinetics. All CpG sites were partially methylated (17-70% of alleles) including CpG-2 located in the cAMP-response element (CRE), which is inactive when methylated. Methylation frequency was unaltered during culture and by 8-BrcAMP (Fisher's exact). Promoter binding of pol-II increased ~10-fold by 8-BrcAMP and the bound DNA had a characteristic high CpG methylation pattern. Phospho-CREB bound to the CRE region increasingly during culture and in response to 8-BrcAMP, but to a separate population of alleles with a distinct methylation pattern. TBP binding increased during syncytialisation, but not in response to 8-BrcAMP. TBP-bound alleles were enriched in methylation patterns recognizing pol-II and pCREB. CONCLUSIONS: DNA methylation determines the transcriptionally active (pol-II-binding) population of CRH gene copies in the trophoblast. The pCREB-CRE interaction at the promoter is not involved in CRH gene regulation in native trophoblast chromatin. Chromatin opens up during syncytial differentiation allowing TBP binding to the CRH promoter, followed by pol-II-dependent transcription upon cAMP stimulation. We propose that conditions that influence gestational length abrogate DNA methylation in early pregnancy and program CRH expression epigenetically by altering the number of transcriptionally active alleles. Coffee is one of the most widely consumed beverages in the world. Coffee consumption is associated with a significant decreased risk of CVD preeclampsia, however the mechanism is unknown. Caffeine is the most studied compound in coffee. Caffeine acutely activates 5'-adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (PKA) and acts as an adenosine receptor blocker. Asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA) is an endogenous inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase and metabolized primarily by the enzyme DDAH1. ADMA is an independent risk factor of CVD, and significantly elevated in hypercholesterolemia and preeclampsia. Recent data indicates activation of the PKA pathway increases DDAH expression and decreases ADMA. High circulating levels of circulating soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt1) are associated with preeclampsia and its related complications. Circulating sFlt1 is largely derived from the placenta and drops dramatically after delivery. Our aim is to evaluate novel upstream pathways that regulate sFlt1 production.

We screened a library of natural compounds (N=502) in primary cytotrophoblasts and placental villous cultures and characterized molecules that had biological activity in the nanomolar range. sFlt1 production was assayed by ELISA. Immunoblot analysis, co-immunoprecipitation and RT-PCR were employed in characterizing sFlt1, HIF-1a, and Hsp27 proteins and RNA. The reduced uterine perfusion pressure (RUPP) rats were used as animal models of pregnancy induced hypertension. RESULTS: 38 natural compounds showed inhibition of sFlt1 production >75% at nanomolar doses in primary cytotrophoblasts and villous explants. Three of these drugs were cardiac glycosides, including Ouabain, Gitoxigenin and Digitoxin. Ouabain inhibited sFlt1 protein synthesis and mRNA expression in human placental cytotrophoblast and explant cultures from normal and preeclamptic patients in a dose and time dependent manner. In vivo, ouabain administration in RUPP rats resulted in a decrease in placental sFlt1 expression and mean arterial pressure with no change in pup or placental weight. Ouabain inhibited hypoxia inducible factor 1 (HIF-1a) protein expression but not HIF-1ß through a non-ubiquitin dependent pathway and that this repression of HIF-1a was dependent on Heat shock protein 27 (Hsp 27) phosphorylation. CONCLUSIONS: Collectively we showed that ouabain inhibits placental sFlt1 production through a HIF-1a/ HSP27 dependent pathway. Further studies are needed to confi rm these fi ndings and explore the usefulness of ouabain and related compounds as potential therapies for human preeclampsia.

Is Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy Associated with Preeclampsia ? Yael Raz, Michael Kupferminc, Joseph Lessing, Eli Rimon. Obstetrics and Gynecology, lis Maternal Hospital, Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center,Tel Aviv university, Tel Aviv, Israel. INTRODUCTION: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is characterized by pruritus, elevated transaminases and elevated total bile acid (TBA) occurs in the third trimester.Recently, we observed several cases where women presented with ICP followed by preeclamsia toxemia (PET) few weeks later. The aim of this study was to investigate whether ICP is associated with PET. METHODS: Between 2008 and 2012, 63 women (41 singleton and 23 twin pregnancies) were diagnosed with ICP, based on clinical presentation , elevated liver enzymes and elevated TBA (>10 µmol/ml).Severity of ICP was defi ned based on TBA level: severe (>40 µmol/ml), moderate (20-40 µmol/ml) and mild (10-20 µmol/ml) . The data on the incidence of PET in general population was obtained from a recent study in our institution (Laskov et al. 2013) . Mild and severe PET were found in 1.8% and 0.8% in singleton and 4 % and 1.7% in twin pregnancies, respectively.Similar data was presented by Day and Sibai et al. (AJOG 2005) . RESULTS: In singletons, the overall incidence of PET was higher than expected in the general population (7.8% vs. 2.6) mostly due to higher incidence of severe PET (4.8 %). In twin pregnancies the incidence of PET was 34.5 % (mild=13.5%, severe 21%), higher than in the general population. Importantly, we also found a correlation between ICP severity and PET incidence (fi gure1, 2).Interestingly, among 20 consequent women presented at 30-37 weeks of gestational age with PET, based on signifi cant proteinuria (1-4 grams/ 24hours) and elevated liver enzymes, no women had elevated TBA. CONCLUSIONS: The incidence of severe PET was higher in ICP patients in both singleton and twin pregnancies. Furthermore we observed a correlation between ICP severity and PET. These fi ndings are novel and suggest that ICP might be a risk factor for PET.

The Women with previous pregnancy complications and thrombophilia are widely treated by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) in future pregnancy. The aim of the study was to investigate the outcome of this group of women.

The study group included 417 consequent women with thrombophilia and previous placenta-mediated pregnancy complications who were treated with LMWH and delivered in the Tel Aviv medical center between 2007-2010. For each woman in the study group we randomly matched a woman from our computerized registry with normal pregnancy who delivered at the same gestational age and during the same years. The primary outcome was defi ned as the incidence of preeclamsia toxemia, severe intrauterine growth restriction (birth weight < percentile 5), intrauterine fetal death or placental abruption. The secondary outcome included obstetric and neonatal outcome.

The women in the study group were older (33.1±4.4 vs. 31.4±4.3, p<0.05), had more pregnancies (3.6±1.9 vs. 2.7±1.5, p< 0.05) and more pregnancy loss (1.4±1.5 vs. 0.53±0.9, p<0.05). There were no significant differences in other demographic parameters. In our institution the current practice is to induce labor at 38-39 weeks in womenwith previous pregnancy complications and thrombophilia treated by LMWH .Therefore, 54.8% of the deliveries in the study group were induced compared to 21.1% in the control group (p<0.05). The cesarean section (CS) rate was similar in both groups (33.3% vs. 29.4%, p>0.05) as well as the rate of elective CS (20.1% VS 17%. P>0.05) and non elective CS (13.2% VS 12.4 %. P>0.05). Importantly, the incidence of placentamediated complications was similar in the study and control groups (5% vs. 4.5%, p>0.05). Neonatal outcome was also similar in both groups. A multivariate analysis revealed that the primary outcome was not affected by demographic parameters, the onset of labor or mode of delivery. CONCLUSIONS: Several studies have shown that women with previous placenta-mediated pregnancy complications and thrombophilia are at higher risk for recurrent complications in future pregnancy. Therefore, the similar rate of complications in the study and control groups supports the current policy that combines LMWH treatment and induction of labor at weeks 38-39 in this group of women in order to prevent reccurent pregnancy complications . Pre-eclampsia is an important gestational complication, which appears in 3-5% of all pregnancies and has a significant impact on maternal and infant health. Its pathophysiology is still not clarified but the placenta plays an important role in this disease. The current study deals with the influence of lipid mediators on the maternal circulation and placental function in pregnancy. The focus lies on certain members of the family of nonprostanoid eicosanoids, namely EETs (epoxyeicosatrienoic acids) and HETEs (hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids), which are mainly cytochrome P450 metabolites of the arachidonic acid pathway and have already been shown to play an important role in cardiovascular disease. The hypothesis of the study is that altered regulation of EET and HETE metabolites is associated with pre-eclampsia. The aim is to elucidate altered levels of EET and HETE metabolites in human placental tissues and blood of pre-eclamptic compared to healthy women. METHODS: Pre-eclamptic women were identified according to definitions of the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. Placental and plasma samples were collected at matched gestations from 20 preeclamptic and 20 healthy pregnant women. A liquid chromatographymass spectrometry (LCMS) method was developed and is being used to measure mediator concentrations in aforementioned tissues and plasma. RESULTS: An LCMS method was developed, which quantifies up to 40 lipids including EETs and HETEs with high sensitivity and specificity. Preliminary analysis of human plasma samples reveals detectable lipid concentrations including those of EETs and HETEs within the nanomolar to picomolar ranges. Quality controls showed reproducibility of the method (n=9). Work is currently underway to determine whether EET and HETE metabolite levels differ between pre-eclamptic and healthy pregnant women. CONCLUSIONS: A method has been developed, validated and established for quantification of lipid levels. Further work aims to apply this method to a range of clinical samples in order to show the role of nonprostanoid eicosanoids in pre-eclampsia. Elaboration of our earlier findings, showing altered HETE levels in placental tissue, may enable novel possibilities of diagnosis or treatment. We hypothesize that abnormal angiogenic profile predicts severity of preeclampsia and illustrates differences in phenotype of normal pregnancies. METHODS: Plasma sFlt1 and placental growth factor (PlGF) concentrations were measured at a routine outpatient visit at 23-25 weeks' gestation in 1981 pregnant women, 214 with preeclampsia and 1767 with normal, uncomplicated pregnancy. High angiogenic profile was determined by sFlt1/PlGF ratio > median for preeclamptic pregnancies. A Z-score of birthweight was calculated, adjusting for gestational age at delivery. Preeclampsia was diagnosed by ACOG criteria. RESULTS: High second trimester sFlt1/PlGF ratio > 18.9 predicted significant growth restriction in both preterm (<37 weeks EGA) and term preeclampsia 2-3 months prior to clinical diagnosis (Z-score b= -0.3, p=0.0003). Similarly, high ratio predicted lower gestational age at delivery in all subjects with preeclampsia (b= -0.5, p=0.0001). In contrast, low second trimester sFlt1/PlGF ratio in preterm preeclampsia was associated with higher birthweight, corrected for gestational age, even in preterm deliveries. In subjects with term preeclampsia and low ratio, birthweight was similar to full-term uncomplicated deliveries. There were no differences in age or BMI between preeclamptic subjects with high ratio versus low ratio. In full-term, uncomplicated pregnancies, a high second trimester ratio predicted lower birth weight (Z-score b= -0.1, p=0.0001). Normal subjects with high ratio also had similar age and BMI as those with low ratio. CONCLUSIONS: High sFlt1/PlGF in the second trimester effectively identifies women at risk for growth restriction in both preeclamptic and normal pregnancies. This ratio may be a simple, effective method to identify patients with more severe disease and potential for worse neonatal outcomes. In this study we examined whether retrograde shear rate and endothelial function are related in healthy and formerly preeclamptic (PE) women and whether this relationship is altered by exercise training. METHODS: Formerly PE-women (32±4 years, n=20) and controls (32±4 years, n=20), all 6-12 months post-partum, performed a 12-week supervised aerobic exercise training. We measured brachial artery shear rate (SR) and endothelial function by flow-mediated dilation (FMD, echo-Doppler). We quantified resting autonomic activity using power spectral analysis and calculated low-frequency/high-frequency(LF/HF)-ratio. RESULTS: Antegrade SR was not different between groups, whilst retrograde SR was significantly higher and FMD% lower in PE-women compared to controls (both P<0.05). Retrograde shear correlated strongly with FMD% in PE-women and controls (P<0.05). LF/HF-ratio was strongly and inversely correlated with brachial artery retrograde SR and FMD% (both P<0.05) in PE-women and controls. Exercise training reduced retrograde shear, improved FMD%, and reduced LF/HF-ratios similarly in both groups (all P<0.05). Training-induced changes in retrograde SR correlated with changes in FMD and LF/HF-ratio. CONCLUSIONS: A higher brachial artery retrograde SR is related to elevation in sympathetic nerve tone and lower brachial artery endothelial function, in both controls and formerly PE-women. Exercise training improves retrograde SR, whilst the magnitude of this change correlated strongly with improvements in FMD and reductions in sympathetic dominance. Therefore, the impact of PE and exercise training on endothelial health may, at least partly, be related to retrograde shear rate.

Excess We hypothesized that TLR-4 activation in first trimester decidual cells (FTDCs) by endogenous ligands is involved in development of PE by triggering sFlt1 impaired endovascular trophoblast invasion. METHODS: Serial decidua basalis sections from PE (n=7), chorioamnionitis (CAM; n=8), and gestational age-matched control (CONT; n=8) specimens were immunostained for TLR-4, or DC and interstitial trophoblast (IT) markers vimentin and cytokeratin and analyzed by HSCORE. Cultured FTDCs were primed with 10 -8 M estradiol + 10 -7 M medroxyprogesterone acetate for 7 days and then switched to a defined medium containing 20µg/ml FN or 5 µg/ml of LPS or 1 ng/ml TNFa or 5x10 -6 M TAK-242 (a TLR-4 antagonist) or their combinations. ELISA measured sFlt level. Cell proliferation was assessed on cultured human endometrial endothelial cells (HEECs) treated with the conditioned medium supernatant (CMS) from FTDC ± 1 ng/ ml VEGF for 24 h. RESULTS: : In immunostained decidual sections, TLR-4 HSCORE in all groups are higher in DCs than ITs (p<0.001). TLR-4 immunoreactivity is higher in DCs (p<0.001) from PE vs CONT or PE vs CAM specimens. In contrast to PE, TLR-4 immunoreactivity in DCs of CAM is lower than CONT specimens (p<0.02). In cultured FTDC, sFlt1 levels are increased 25-fold by FN+LPS+TNFavs control (pg/mL/mg protein: 2.8±0.2 vs.0.1±0.04, p<0.001) or vs FN, LPS or TNFa alone. This inductive effect is blocked by a TLR-4 antagonist. VEGF induced HEEC proliferation (Mean ± SEM 0.708 ± 0.04) is blocked by CMS from FN+LPS+TNFatreated FTDC (0.614 ± 0.09, p<0.03).

DCs. Such sFLT1 overexpression may impede endovascular trophoblast invasion of spiral arteries and lead to PE. is a hypertensive disease of pregnancy, complicating 2-8% of pregnancies. It is associated with significant maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. Recurrence risk of PE is higher in women with severe, early disease. Decidual vasculopathy (DV) is a term for spiral artery lesions found in a proportion of patients with PE. DV has been related to worse outcome in PE. The aim of this study is to test the hypothesis that DV is associated with a higher recurrence rate of placenta syndrome (PE, PIH, IUGR) in future pregnancies.
back_matter.section: CONCLUSIONS: Activation of TLR-4 in FTDCs by its endogenous ligand FN with TNFa synergistically increases sFlt1 expression in

back_matter.text: The study was conducted via survey in patients with a history of PE with (n=41, PE+DV) or without DV (n=49, PE-DV) during the years 1995-2010 and with available placental analysis. Recurrence risk was calculated comparing the percentage of multiparous women with recurrent PE or PIH in cases with DV in the index pregnancy to those without the lesions. Remaining parameters were calculated comparing all pregnancies of the PE+DV group (n=150) to those in the PE-DV group (n=167). RESULTS: Mean follow-up time was 9 years and 9 months for PE+DV cases and 9 years and 5 months for the PE-DV group (p=0,648). Risk of recurrent PE or PIH and of IUGR was high in both PE+DV and PE-DV groups but the difference between the groups was not significant. PE+DV group had more preterm births (<34 weeks gestational age), and lower birth weight and birth weight centile, compared to the PE-DV group.

Women with a history of DV associated PE have an increased risk of preterm birth, and lower mean birth weight and birth weight centile, without increased recurrence of hypertensive disease or IUGR. Possibly, DV lesions cause chronic damage to the placental bed vessels, thus specifically increasing overall risk of neonatal morbidity. This results in the release of free oxygen radicals and oxidative DNA damage, which promote apoptosis. We have previously shown that oxidative DNA damage is significantly increased in placental tissues from women with PE vs normotensive controls in vivo & can be induced under conditions of hypoxia/reperfusion in vitro. Whether this is true also in fetal membranes is not known. This is importance since PPROM/ preterm birth is more common in women with PE. We hypothesize that this may be due to increased oxidative DNA damage & apoptosis in the fetal membranes of women with PE leading to gradual weakening of the membranes and PPROM/preterm birth. CONCLUSIONS: These data show that fetal membranes from PE pregnancies have more DNA damage and apoptosis in vivo than those from gestational age-matched controls. In contrast, expression of the BER proteins (OGG1 & APE1) is low at baseline and unchanged in women with PE, suggesting that fetal membranes may have limited capacity to repair DNA damage. These data support the theory that PE is associated with increased oxidative DNA damage & apoptosis in the placenta/fetal membranes.

E Tavassoli, 1 A Rolfo, 2 R Attini, 1 P Gaglioti, 1 AM Nuzzo, 2 T Todros, 1 GB B Piccoli. 3 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology 2U, OIRM S.Anna Hospital, Turin, Italy; 2 Surgical Sciences, University of Turin, Turin, Italy; 3 SS Nephrology, S. Luigi Gonzaga, Orbassano, Italy. INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia and CKD, affecting 3-5% of all pregnancies, are both characterized by hypertension and proteinuria, leading to a difficult or impossible clinical differential diagnosis in pregnancy. The issue is important considering both the different pregnancy outcomes and the need for a different follow-up after delivery. Two retrospective studies by our group suggested a role of s-Flt-1/PlGF ratio and of the analysis of utero-placental Doppler flows in this challenging differential diagnosis: the sFlt-1/PlGF ratio was significantly increased in PE relative to CKD and controls; normal utero-placental Doppler wave forms suggested CKD, altered wave forms PE. The aim of the present study was to test prospectively and conjunctly these two hypotheses on a large, homogeneously treated, population. METHODS: s-Flt-1 and PlGF levels were determined by specific and commercially available ELYCSIS assay (Roche) using an immunoanalyzer Cobas 601/2. We analyzed 59 singleton pregnancies (18 PE, 28 CKD and 13 patients with other hypertensive disorders), 18 twin pregnancies and a case of superimposed PE. When more serum samples were available, we selected the first sample available after 24 weeks of gestational age. Doppler velocimetry was performed by the same group of skilled operators, by standard methods, in 55 cases. We considered as pathological a RI≥0.58 and referred to gestational-age adjusted reference tables for PI (Todros et al, Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand, 1996) . RESULTS: s-Flt-1/PlGF ratio was statistically different in the three groups: PE (median 334.77 (range: 45.4-2454.94)), CKD (median 7.46 (range: 1.43-270.74)) and "other" (median 57.89 (range: 1.46-800.24)) (p<0.001). Patients with altered flows had higher s-Flt-1/PlGF ratio (381.6 (9.5-921) vs 10.
