In addition, we collected the uterus and placenta from the mice and stained them using an anti-cluster of differentiation antibodies to examine immune cell distribution. RESULTS: Blood pressure was significantly increased on the 12th day. Fetal weight was significantly decreased in the CD40L-transfected mice In the splenic cells, Th1 was dominant compared with Th2 and Th18. In the normal placenta, FOXP3 was found; however, FOXP3 was not found in the PE model mouse. CONCLUSIONS: It is thought that CD40L plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of PE through the immune system activation since the CD40-CD40L interaction is important for the cellular immune system. Our PE model mouse might supply a good solution to investigate the pathogenesis of PE.

Human placenta was obtained from 12 preeclamptic and 12 healthy women who underwent cesarean section. After RNA isolation from these placentas, quantitative RT-PCR was performed for measuring mRNA expressions of Wnt genes. Wnt expressions in normal 6 placentas of each term were also measured by quantitative RT-PCR. HTR-8/SV neo trophoblast cells were cultured in each condition with hypoxia(1% O 2 ), H 2 O 2 addition(5-800mM), thrombin addition(2U/ml), and TNFa addition(10ng/ml) and the influence of these conditions on Wnt signaling was analysed by quantitative RT-PCR and Western blotting. RESULTS: Of 11 Wnt genes, Wnt5a mRNA expression alone was down -regulated in preeclamptic placenta as compared to normal(Mann-Whitney, p=0.002). Wnt2 mRNA expression tended to decrease and Axin2, the downstream of Wnt2 signaling, significantly decreased in preeclamptic placenta (Mann-Whitney, p=0.04).over the last 20 years, with significant modifications since 2006/7. The aim of this study was to determine changes in maternal and fetal/neonatal outcomes in women with hypertensive pregnancy disorders following different management.

We compared maternal and fetal/neonatal complications in pregnancies with associated hypertensive diseases during two different time periods 1992-2006 (n=752), and 2007-2011 (n=1109) . Changes in the management of hypertension therapy, supplementation of preventive acetylsalicylic acid and the administration of glycocorticoids were examined. Statistical analysis was carried out by comparing the "first" traditional management group to the "second" one from 2007-2011 using t-tests. Data was obtained from the archives of the medical university in Graz (Austria) and the digital databases PIA® and MEDOCS®. RESULTS: The first line antihypertensive treatment option shifted from b-blockers in 1992-2006 towards a-Methyl-DOPA and CA-Antagonists in 2007-11. Preventive agents like acetylsalicylic acid were not prescribed during the first period but in 9,3% after 2007. The application of magnesium-sulfate therapy in women with severe preeclampsia rose from 8% to 14% between the 2 time periods. Caesarean section rate was significantly lower in the first compared to the second study period (49,6% vs 61,6%, p< 0.001). Severe maternal complications dropped from 2% to 0,5% (p<0.007), fetal complications from 51,6% to 16,2% (p<0.001).In women with previous preeclampsia the recurrence risk dropped from 22% to 12% (p> 0.05) between the two study periods.

The development of prophylaxis and appropriate management and therapy of hypertensive diseases in pregnancies during the last 20 years lead to a significant improvement in maternal and fetal/ neonatal outcome.
Angiotensin II Sensitivity after Preeclampsia in Human and Rat.

A history of preeclampsia is associated with an increased risk of developing cardiovascular and renal diseases later in life. Whether this is due to preeclampsia itself or common risk factors is unknown. Persistently impaired angiotensin II (angII) sensitivity might be involved since ang II sensitivity is increased during preeclampsia. Aim: To study the postpartum angII sensitivity after preeclampsia in healthy women and rat. METHODS: Human: eighteen healthy formerly pregnant women (fHP-women) and 18 healthy formerly early-onset preeclamptic women (fPE-women) were studied 1-10 years postpartum. After a week of standardized sodium diet (aim: 200mmol/24h), baseline blood pressure (BP) and BP-response to graded infusion of angII (0.3, 1.0, and 3.0ng/ kg/min for 1hour) were measured. Rat: never pregnant (NP), formerly healthy pregnant (fHP), and formerly experimental preeclamptic Wistar rats (fPE; low dose LPS infusion on day 14 of pregnancy) were studied 9-10 weeks postpartum. BP and proteinuria upon chronic angII infusion (200ng/kg/min by osmotic minipump) were measured. RESULTS: Baseline mean arterial pressure (MAP) was similar between fHP-and fPE-women (85 ± 8 vs 86 ± 9; p=0.71). A trend towards an increased MAP response in fPE-women as compared to fHP-women (6.3 ± 3.7 vs 3.6 ± 5.1; p=0.074) after 1.0ng/kg/min angII was found. In rats, a trend towards an increased response from baseline of systolic BP (69.4% vs 53.8%; p=0.068) and a significantly increased proteinuria vs baseline (883.2% vs 395%; p=0.036) was observed after three weeks of angII infusion in fPE-rats as compared to fNP-rats.

Healthy fPE-women show persistent increased BP response to angII infusion. The fact that fPE-rats also exhibit increased BP and proteinuria upon angII infusion compared to fHP and NP-rats, suggests that the increased angII sensitivity found in fPE-women is at least partly induced by the preeclamptic event itself and could contribute to increased renal risk in fPE-women. Characteristic inflammatory patterns were identified by comparisons of means or medians between both study groups and by linear models and hierarchical clustering.

We found raised levels of several plasma acute-phase proteins (including CRP, fibrinogen and IL6) in women with previous preeclampsia, when compared to controls with a history of only normal pregnancies, as well as significant changes in the response to influenza vaccination and in the cytokine responses to CD2/CD28 and LPS induced TLR4 stimulation. Further analysis revealed correlations between various key cytokines and circulating inflammatory markers and identified characteristic inflammatory patterns related to preeclampsia on heatmap cluster analysis. CONCLUSIONS: Mapping of the maternal inflammatory response postpartum reveals an underlying pro-inflammatory phenotype associated with previous preeclampsia. in HELLP rats (n=7; p=0.0004). Preproendothelin mRNA expression was significantly increased in placentas (p=0.02), livers (p=0.05) and the posterior cortex (p=0.03) from HELLP rats compared to NP rats. ET-1 secretion from endothelial cells (HUVEC) exposed to serum from women with HELLP was significantly increased (p=0.002) as was sVCAM (p=0.04). ET-1 secretion from HUVECs exposed to serum from HELLP rats (p=0.04) when compared to serum from NP women or rats. CONCLUSIONS: These data support the hypothesis that hypertension in both women and animals with HELLP is accompanied by activation of the ET-1 system. The increase in sVCAM coincides with the platelet dysfunction that occurs in HELLP syndrome. Future studies include examining placental ET-1 function in women with this devastating disease. Recently, podocyte injury and podocyte shedding has emerged as an important pathophysiological process of renal barrier dysfunction in preeclampsia (PE). In humans, loss of podocytes in glomerulosclerosis is a typical end-stage renal pathology. However, clinically renal barrier dysfunction is reversible in the majority of PE patients after delivery as evidenced by disappearance of proteinuria along with maternal blood pressure returning to normotensive levels. This phenomenon suggests that renal barrier must experience a unique recovery process after delivery. However, podocyte biology in PE is largely unknown. The purpose of the present study was to study the differentiation potential of shed podocytes from PE. METHODS: Shed podocytes were extracted from urine specimen from women with PE (n=8) and cultured up to 2 months in vitro. Presence or absence of Ki67 expression was used as marker of proliferation or differentiation. Expression and distribution of nephrin and podoplanin was used as markers of podocyte functional protein regeneration. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed to examine ultrastructure of shed podocytes. In addition, expression of VEGF and CuZnSOD was also determined as functional recovery of differentiated podocytes.

Our results showed that with short-term (<2wks) culture, shed cells expressed Ki67 but lacked of nephrin and podoplanin. In contrast, after prolong culture (>6wks), podocytes expressed nephrin and podoplanin, but Ki67 was undetectable. Shed podocytes exhibited cell-cell contact and foot processes were present in podocytes evaluated by TEM. VEGF and CuZnSOD expression were found to be co-localized with nephrin at the foot process area. CONCLUSIONS: Our study demonstrated that shed podocytes from PE have the ability to differentiate into mature podocytes, suggesting that podocytes self-renewal may contribute to renal barrier functional recovery after delivery in PE. Currently, there is debate as to whether these sub-types refl ect the same pathophysiology, but with different severities, or different pathologies based on defective placentation and increased maternal susceptibility respectively. Here, we test between these possibilities by examining molecular markers of ER stress signalling pathways. METHODS: Placentas were collected from 24 PE pregnancies (26-38 wk) and 8 normotensive controls (39-40 wk), delivered by nonlaboured, caesarean section for clinical reasons. In addition, 7 ~18 wk, and 7 spontaneously delivered preterm control (~30 wk) placentas were obtained. All were collected with informed patient consent and local ethical approval. Levels and phosphorylation of proteins/kinases in ER stress, MAPK stress, and AKT survival/growth signalling pathways were analysed by Western blot, along with heat shock proteins. RESULTS: There were signifi cant negative correlations (p<0.05) between the ER stress markers P-eIF2a, ATF6, P-IRE1, XBP-1 & GRP78, and P-p38 and gestational age at delivery (Fig. A) , but not for other stress kinases/proteins. ER stress markers were increased only in PE placentas <32 wk, whereas there were no differences between PE placentas >34 wk and second trimester and term controls (Fig. B) . P-eIF2a was increased in the pre-term placentas compared to normal term controls. Finally, AKT protein was lower in <32 wk compared to >34 wk PE placentas, which showed no difference to term controls (Fig. A & B) .

The clear distinction in activation of ER stress response pathways demonstrates that deficient placentation may contribute to the aetiology of early-onset PE, but not the late-onset subtype. Supported by Welcome Trust (084804/2/08/Z). is a pregnancy-specific syndrome characterized by maternal hypertension and increased peripheral vascular resistance. Levels of endothelin-1 (ET-1), a potent vasoconstrictor, are increased in the plasma of preeclamptic women; placental tissue beds from women with PE express higher levels of ET-1 compared to controls. Blood pressure dysregulation, however, occurs primarily in resistance arteries. Expression of ET-1 is less well studied in these vessels. We hypothesized that ET-1 expression and production is elevated in omental vessels from women with PE and elevation of ET-1 expression is induced by lysophosphatic acid (LPA), which is increased in plasma of preeclamptic women. METHODS: RNAs were isolated from omental vessels obtained from women with PE (n=7) and women with normal pregnancies (n=11). Primary endothelial cells (HUVEC) and omental arteries explants from normal pregnancies were exposed to LPA with or without a PI3 kinase inhibitor (LY294002) in culture medium for 24 hours. ET-1 expression levels were measured using quantitative real time RT-PCR.

The ET-1 mRNA expression level was significantly elevated in omental vessels obtained from women with PE compared to women with normal pregnancies. Furthermore, increased ET-1 production was localized to endothelium with immunochemistry. LPA was able to induce ET-1 mRNA expression in both vessel explants and HUVEC. Using PI3 Kinase inhibitor, we demonstrated that PI3 Kinase signaling functioned downstream of the LPA receptor to induce ET-1 expression by LPA. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, our studies reveal that ET-1 gene expression and production is elevated in omental vessels from women with PE. In women with PE, LPA plays a key role in elevated ET-1 expression in omental vessels via downstream PI3 kinase signaling. LPA represents a potential important target for therapeutic intervention.

Maternal Here we re-assessed the utility of Ddx4-Cre;Rosa26 tomato/+ reporter mice for identification and isolation mitotically active germ cells (OSCs) from adult mouse ovaries. METHODS: Ddx4-Cre mice were crossed with Rosa26 tomato/+ mice to drive tomato red expression in cells in which the Ddx4 promoter has been/ is activated. Ovaries were collected from recombined offspring at postnatal day 8 (PD8) and PD60. Each fraction of cells after crude dispersion of the ovaries (as per Liu and colleagues), or after dispersion coupled with an additional OSC purification step (Nature Protocols 2013 8:966-88) not performed by Liu and colleagues, was assessed by analysis of primitive germline markers and oocyte-specific markers. Additionally, colony formation and bromodeoxyuridine incorporation assays were performed to assess mitotic capacity of isolated germ cells. RESULTS: Crude dispersion generated cell fractions containing reporterpositive immature oocytes, which are incapable of proliferation and thus likely represent the mitotically inactive reporter-positive cells studied by Liu and colleagues. Dispersed ovaries further subjected to FACS, based on tomato red expression (reporter-positive) and externalized Ddx4 protein expression (ecDdx4-positive; characteristic of OSCs and not oocytes) revealed extensive 'leakiness' of the reporter in non-germline cells.However, a small fraction of reporter-positive cells were also positive for ecDdx4 expression. These cells expressed primitive germ cell markers but not oocyte markers, and could be established and expanded in culture, exactly as reported for adult mouse ovary-derived OSCs (Nature Protocols 2013 8:966-88). CONCLUSIONS: Crude dispersion of ovaries collected from Ddx4driven reporter mice alone (PNAS 2012 109:12580-5) is not a reliable approach to identify OSCs, whereas FACS-based sorting of the same ovarian dispersates generates purified fractions of OSCs that can be expanded ex vivo (Support: NIH R37-AG012279).

Delays before a Referral for Infertility and "Lost Time": Interviews of Couples. L Pastore, 1 L Karns, 1 K Ventura, 1 M Clark. 2 1 OB/GYN, Univ of Virginia, USA; 2 School of Nursing, Univ of Virginia, USA. INTRODUCTION: 6.7 million women in the US have impaired fecundity. About 10% of infertile/subfertile women are diagnosed with diminished ovarian reserve (DOR), of which < 5% will become pregnant spontaneously. This diagnosis is generally a surprise to women because they have regular menses. We examined interview data from women diagnosed with DOR and their husbands regarding their experience with the medical system, primarily in terms of delay in referral to a specialist. METHODS: Seven women with DOR (subset of participants of a genetic testing study, ages 30-41 at diagnosis) from the US and the male partners of six of these women were separately interviewed about the experience of being given this diagnosis. The interviews followed phenomenologic theory. DOR was defined as elevated FSH and/or low AMH and/or low antral follicle count, with regular menses, and age < 42 years. RESULTS: Women commented that multiple primary care providers were seen before an REI referral. Husbands expressed frustration about the time spent prior to an infertility diagnosis, despite annual check-ups.Husbands talked about having asked their primary doctors over time about the lack of conception before a referral was made. Some men were accepting and others frustrated about the changing scientific knowledge over time, while the wives only expressed frustration. CONCLUSIONS: "Lost time" was a recurrent theme in these couples. These interviews add depth to existing knowledge about medical system delays for fertility treatment, and are enriched by the inclusion of the husband's experience. INTRODUCTION: Establishment of endometrial receptivity is vital for successful embryo implantation. Endometrial receptivity is marked by dramatic changes in the luminal epithelium and the stroma. Protein convertase 5/6 (PC6) is up-regulated in the human endometrium specifically at the time of epithelial receptivity. PC6 is a serine protease of the PC family that plays an important role in converting precursor proteins into their active forms by specific cleavage. Platelet derived growth factor A (PDGFA) requires PC cleavage for activation and the active form is secreted as a dimer (~30kDa). PDGFA is necessary for blood vessel development and actin cytoskeleton organisation; it is also involved in the communication between the mother and embryo. This study identified an important role of PC6 in cleaving PDGFA during endometrial receptivity. METHODS: PC6 was specifically knocked down in an endometrial epithelial cell line, HEC1A, by stable transfection with siRNA specific to human PC6 (PC6-siRNA) or scrambled sequence (control). PC6-siRNA cells are significantly less receptive than control. Western blot analysis with antibodies specific to the active and precursor of PDGFA examined the regulation of PDGFA by PC6. Immunohistochemical analysis determined the localisation of active PDGFA in the endometrium of non-receptive and receptive phases. PDGFAA ELISA detected PDGFAA levels in the uterine fluid. RESULTS: Western blot analysis showed an accumulation of the PDGFA precursor but a reduction of the active form in PC6-siRNA cells than control. Immunohistochemical analysis showed different localisation of PDGFA in the human endometrium in different phases. During the nonreceptive phase, PDGFA was localised to the basement of the glandular and luminal epithelium. In the receptive phase, PDGFA was present in the apical surface of the luminal and glandular epithelium. Active PDGFAA was elevated in the uterine fluid during receptivity.

These results suggest that PC6 regulates the cleavage/ activation of PDGFA in the endometrial epithelial cells and that PDGFA localises to the apical surface of the epithelium during endometrial receptivity. Compromised PC6 action would reduce the conversion of pro-PDGFA into its active form affecting downstream signalling important for endometrial receptivity. INTRODUCTION: Progesterone (P) is known to induce insulin-like growth factor binding protein-1 (IGFBP-1) production and decidualization in the primate endometrium. Here we provide evidence that IGFBP-1 is also strongly upregulated in the endometrium following induction of menstruation by P withdrawal in artificially cycling macaques and in the premenstrual/menstrual stage human endometrium. METHODS: Artificial cycles were induced in ovariectomized rhesus macaques by sequential treatment with subcutaneous implants of estradiol (E) for 14 days and E plus P for 14 days. P was then withdrawn to induce menstruation. Uteri (n=3) were obtained after 24-36 hrs (premenstrual), 2-3 days (menstrual), 5-6 days (early-proliferative) and 14 days (lateproliferative) after P withdrawal. In another set of animals, P was added after 14 days of E and tissue was sampled 7 (mid-secretory) and 14 (latesecretory) days later. Human endometrial samples were obtained from proliferative, mid-secretory, and premenstrual/menstrual phases of the cycle. In situ hybridization (ISH) and immunohistochemistry (IHC) were performed in full-thickness endometrial sections to evaluate IGFBP-1 mRNA and protein localization, and IHC for CD45 was performed for identification of leukocytes. RESULTS: IGFBP-1 signals were not detectable by ISH or IHC in the proliferative and secretory phase endometrium in macaques. However, there was a dramatic increase in both mRNA and protein levels in the pre/ menstrual phase endometrium following P withdrawal. The signals were primarily evident in the stromal cells of the upper endometrial zones in a gradient, with highest expression in cells closest to the luminal epithelium.

Co-localization (IHC) of IGFBP-1 and CD45 showed IGFBP-1 expression primarily in endometrial stromal cells, not in infiltrating leukocytes. Similar results were obtained in the human specimens. CONCLUSIONS: Our results suggest, for the first time, that P is not essential for induction of IGFBP-1 in P-primed secretory phase endometrium in primates. Furthermore, the results of this study and findings in earlier work, suggest that the influx of leukocytes into the secretory phase endometrium -induced by P withdrawal or other mechanisms, such as blastocyst implantation -and the resulting inflammatory signals produced by these cells may serve as the key stimuli for IGFBP-1 production and induction of decidualization.
Utilizing

We performed a retrospective chart review of 305 patients seen at our fertility clinic between July 2013 and September 2013. The number of CGG repeats on allele 1 and allele 2 on the FMR1 gene as well as serum AMH levels were collected. The cohort was stratified based on age (≤35, 35<x≤38, 38<x≤40, >40), and then further stratified based on the number of CGG repeats (<29, 29/30, >30). Based on previous studies, repeats of 29 and 30 were considered a normal repeat pattern. AMH values of patients with repeats less than 29 and greater than 30 were tested for clinical significance compared to the normal repeat range. This was done for allele 1, allele 2, and the average of both alleles. RESULTS: Allele 1 and allele 2 repeats less than 29 in the 35<x≤38 age group yielded higher AMH levels than the normal repeat pattern (p=.05 and p=.02, respectively). Allele 2 repeats greater than 30 demonstrated lower AMH levels in the age group of 38<x≤40 (p=.01). In the age group of x>40, allele 2 repeats less than 29 displayed higher AMH levels (p=.01).In the age group of 38<x≤40, the average of both alleles greater than 30 showed lower AMH levels (p=.02).
The number of CGG repeats on allele 1, allele 2 and the average of both alleles of the FMR1 gene can act as good predictors of AMH levels in women at certain ages.

Quantitative PCR and in situ hybridization were used to assess Mrgprg expression in decidual (days 4-9 of pregnancy) and deciduomal (day 7 of psuedopregnancy) tissues. In addition, other organs of the female reproductive tract and major non-reproductive organs were collected for mRNA isolation and qPCR analysis. The expression of vasodilatory genes associated with the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) was also evaluated. Human endometrial stromal cells were induced to undergo decidualization in vitro. RESULTS: Mrgprg expression was restricted to the gravid endometrium and could not be detected in any of the other reproductive or nonreproductive organs tested. Within the uterus, Mrgprg expression remained spatially confined to the stromal compartment and temporally restricted to early gestation. Further, Mrgprg was up-regulated in response to the implanting embryo. Components of the RAS were also shown to be expressed at the maternal-embryo interface. Presumably through paracrine secretions, the embryo initiated a 6.4-and 7-fold increase in the expression of renin and Mrgprg, respectively, based on microarray analysis. Prolyl-endopeptidase was abundantly expressed in the decidualizing endometrium, but was not regulated by the embryo. In vitro decidualization of human endometrial stromal cells resulted in upregulation of MRGPRF, the most closely related member of the human MRG superfamily to murine Mrgprg. CONCLUSIONS: Due to the restricted expression pattern of Mrgprg to the gravid decidualizing stromal compartment, we propose that this gene is functionally important for early pregnancy. Given that other members of the MRG family are known to play a role in vasodilation, it is hypothesized that MRGPRG mediates the provasodilatory actions of ANG-(1-7). That human MRGPRF was found to be regulated during in vitro decidualization suggests that this presumptive provasodilatory pathway may also function in humans. Ongoing studies in our laboratory are centered on evaluating MRGPRG protein expression and establishing a functional role for Mrgprg during early gestation. Supported by NIH ES012070 and OD010488. , an inhibitor of fatty acid (FA) beta-oxidation, and Glucosamine (GlcN), an inhibitor of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) and in turn glucose utilization, have been shown to inhibit decidualization and subsequent embryo implantation.Simultaneous intrauterine delivery of RAN and GlcN followed by optic artery dye injection to stain the implantation sites confi rms this effect. METHODS: On day 1.5 of gestation, 33 ng RAN and 250 ng GlcN were injected into one uterine fat pad of pregnant female ICR mice 8-9 weeks. One uterine fat pad of control mice was injected with 5 uL of ethanol.On day 5.5 of gestation, the optic artery was injected with 100 uL 1% Evans blue dye in order to stain the implantation sites.Mice were then sacrifi ced and the uteri were dissected out.Number of implantation sites were noted in both the control and experimental horns. RESULTS: Blue dye staining of embryo implantation sites demonstrated signifi cantly fewer numbers when the uterine fat pad was injected with RAN and GlcN-number of implantation sites ranged from 3-4, compared to 7-9 in the non-injected horn.Control mice showed a similar number of implantation sites in the horn injected with ethanol when compared to the non-injected horn.

Previously our lab has shown that blockade of the PPP inhibits ESC decidualization.FA beta-oxidation is also critical for embryo implantation and we have investigated that beta-oxidation is required for ESC decidualization as well.Inhibition of both of these processes with a cocktail of RAN and GlcN at lower concentrations has demonstrated inhibition of ESC decidualization and in turn decreased litter size using a pellet method.The blue dye injection method described here improves upon this treatment by demonstrating that implantation is prevented by these compounds.This work could have important implications in discovery of novel pathways to target for design of future non-hormonal contraceptives. Many of the signaling molecules involved in the dialog between the oocyte and the somatic compartment of the ovarian follicle belong to the transforming growth factor-b (TGFb) superfamily. Among other regulatory mechanisms, TGFb signaling is attenuated by its binding to the soluble form of vasorin/ATIA (Vasn), a type I membrane protein.

In addition, Vasn was found to be a hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)-1 target, which is expressed in the mitochondria and protects cells from TNFa and hypoxia-induced apoptosis. Since the ovarian preovulatory follicle is scarcely vascularized and hypoxic conditions control its proper function, Vasn may also be involved in protecting ovarian cells from possible hypoxic damage in addition to its role in regulating TGFb activity. Importantly, Vasn knock out (KO) in mice caused impaired fertility in males due to increased testicular apoptosis and brought about infertility in females. Our main goal is to explore the role of Vasn in ovarian physiology and unveil its effects on female fertility.
We used qPCR analysis and in-situ hybridization to identify Vasn mRNA expression pattern in mice ovaries in vivo, and in mice and rats follicle culture system in vitro.

We initially found by qPCR that Vasn mRNA is expressed in the mouse ovary at different ages at post natal days: 5, 10, 15, 20 and 26.In addition, qPCR and in-situ hybridization revealed that Vasn mRNA is found in granulosa cells at different stages of folliculogenesis, in primary, secondary, antral and pre-ovulatory follicles. We also showed that Vasn's expression is up-regulated in the ovarian granulosa cells in response to luteinizing hormone (LH) (p<0.05) , indicating a possible role in ovulation. We used isolated intact rat follicle cultures to further demonstrate that the LH-induced elevation of Vasn is sensitive to EGFR and MEK1 inhibitors, suggesting a mediatory role of these signaling molecules in its regulation.Finally, preliminary results also indicate down regulation of Vasn mRNA in aged mice ovaries (10 months old). CONCLUSIONS: These initial results support the hypothesis that Vasn plays a role in ovulation. Our future experiments will use Vasn KO mice for the identification of the specific role of this gene in ovarian physiology.

We conducted an observational-cohort-study on normoresponders patients aged between 25-45 years referred to Assisted-Reproductive Unit -University of Padua -in order to evaluate the ovarian response effects (both qualitative and quantitative) after LDA administration. In detail we aim to assess if LDA administration could improve ovarian response, reducing the gonadotropin administration, and if its administration could increase the number of follicles greater than 16mm at pick-up, the number and quality of oocytes retrieved, the number and quality of embryos, the chance to achieve a pregnancy and to carry it on. RESULTS: 106 LDA-treated patients (Group-A) and 100 not-treated ones (Group-B) were homogeneous for age and BMI. The Group-A, respect Group-B, showed higher gonadotropin request, higher number of ovarian follicles at pick-up, more follicles bigger than 16 mm in diameter and higher number of oocytes retrieved (despite higher number of immature and at germinal vesicle stage oocytes) but lower quality of obtained embryos. The comparison between 2 Groups in term of oocytes retrieved/ number of follicles, mature oocytes/retrieved oocytes, fertilized oocytes/ mature oocytes and good embryos quality/mature oocytes showed a ratio strongly advantageous for Group-B. For every considered outcome, we found a dose-related effect. CONCLUSIONS: It is mandatory to define what patients could benefit of LDA administration and the adequate timing to administer it since the empirical administration could negatively affect both the oocytes and embryos quality during IVF cycles. Advanced maternal age is consistently associated with increased risk of congenital heart disease even after excluding cases of chromosomal abnormality. We observed a similar risk in an Nkx2-5 +/mouse model of congenital heart disease. Surprisingly, the biological basis of the risk resides with the mother rather than the oocyte. To characterize the mechanism, we explore here the genetic basis of the maternal age effect. Hypothesis: The maternal-age associated risk for congenital heart disease is a quantitative trait influenced by genetic polymorphisms in the mother.

We compared the effect of maternal age on the incidence of specific congenital heart defects in the Nkx2-5 +/offspring of mothers that were F1 hybrids of the inbred strains C57BL/6 and FVB/N or A/J (i.e., C57 X FVB or C57 X A/J). The effect of maternal age on defect incidence was quantified by multiple logistic regression analysis of >1600 pups in each cross. The mothers ranged in age from 48 to 516 days . Genetic effects were determined ANCOVA, using maternal hybrid strain background as a covariate.

The effect of maternal age varied between the C57 X FVB and C57 X A/J crosses by defect and temporal patterns. While the incremental effect of maternal aging on the risk of atrial septal defects was similar in the two crosses, the onset of risk appeared sooner in the C57 X A/J cross (P < 0.001). In contrast, the C57 X A/J cross had a lower maternal agerelated risk for ventricular septal defects than C57 X FVB (P = 0.012). CONCLUSIONS: Genetic polymorphisms in the mother affect the onset and severity of the maternal age-related risk of congenital heart disease in her offspring. Complex interactions between maternal genes, environment and the physiology of aging affect embryonic cardiac development.Investigation of the biological pathways may help to identify individuals at risk and to develop novel preventive strategies. Influenza infection in pregnancy is associated with increased morbidity and mortality and risk of prematurity. Immunization during pregnancy reduces the likelihood of prematurity. We aimed to characterize T-cell functional and phenotypic changes in response to vaccination in pregnancy. METHODS: Healthy pregnant patients (n=15) and non-pregnant controls (n=14) were recruited prior to influenza vaccination. PBMC were isolated before, 1 month, and 2 months after vaccination. ELISpot assays for IL-10, IL-4, IFN-g and Granzyme-B were undertaken to determine functional responses to influenza A and other common recall antigens. Flow cytometry was performed for T-cell, NK cell and DC surface phenotype. Statistical analysis used Graphpad 5.0; significance defined as p<0.05. RESULTS: T-cell maturation in pregnant patients post vaccination show a shift towards greater central memory (CD4: p=0.0043, CD8: p=0.0022), reduced naïve (CD4: p=0.0015, CD8: p=0.0050) and terminally differentiated effector memory CD8 (p=0.0026) subtypes. Activation marker expression (CD38, HLA-DR) was unchanged. Mean fluorescence intensity of PD-L1 on CD4 (p=0.0043) and CD8 (p=0.0247) T-cells were reduced. CD95 expression on CD8 T-cells was increased (p=0.0367). Treg (CD4+CD45RO+CD25+CD127low) proportions were unchanged, but their expression of CCR5 reduced (p=0.0411) and HLA-g increased (p=0.0043). CD4 TCRgD proportions and PIBF (progesterone induced blocking factor) expression were unchanged but CD8 TCRgD percentage showed an increasing trend. Proportions of tolerant DC (CD3-CD19-CD11c+HLA-DR+CD14+CD16+CD123+ILT4+CD83+HLA-g+) were reduced (p=0.0012). No changes were seen in NK proportions or PIBF expression. Proportions of T-helper subtypes (Th1, Th2 and Th17) were unchanged. Functional ELISpot data showed longitudinal increases in IFN production in response to EBV (p=0.0238), influenza A (Flu, p=0.0008) and tetanus toxoid (TTOX, p=0.0078), IL-10 production in response to CMV (p=0.0070), flu (p=0.0277), HSV (p=0.0146), purified protein derivative (p=0.0129) and TTOX (p=0.0445). IL-4 showed no changes but granzyme production increased with TTOX stimulation (p=0.0454). CONCLUSIONS: Vaccination in pregnancy is associated with increased antigen responsive memory subtypes with concurrent reductions and alteration of tolerant cell types and inhibitory receptor expression. IFN and IL-10 responses are enhanced without an altered T-helper dominance. Progesterone induced decidualization is accompanied by marked morphological and biochemical changes in the endometrium including edema, and increased vascular permeability. Decidualization is also associated with enhanced human endometrial stromal cell (HESC) expression of tissue factor, the primary initiator of hemostasis by thrombin generation, and dramatic changes in the HESC extracellular matrix (ECM). Thus, we analyzed ECM protein expression in the secretome of cultured HESCs treated with ovarian steroids ± thrombin by Mass Spectrometry analysis (MSA). METHODS: HESCs were treated with thrombin alone or with medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA), a mixed glucocorticoid-progestin agonist, Etonogestrel (ETO), a predominately progestin agonist, or the pure progestin agonist, Organon 2058. Cell lysates were collected in Trizol for microarray analysis and supernatants processed for MSA by trypsin treatment. Peptides in the secretome are analyzed using a hybrid Orbitrap Elite ETD mass spectrometer. Peptide counts are determined using the Mass Matrix search engine. RESULTS: More than 300 proteins/sample were identified by MSA. Statistical analysis of peptide counts, which are proportional to protein expression, revealed numerous proteins that were either over-or underexpressed following thrombin treatment (p<0.05). Scrutiny of thrombin up-regulated proteins demonstrated a preponderance of ECM proteins (n=19, p<0.05) in the HESC thrombin treated secretome. In addition, 12 unique collagen isotypes were minimally affected by thrombin treatment p>0.05). Comparison of mRNA expression from microarray data of thrombin treated HESCs demonstrated a high correlation with proteomic data. Unlike the marked response to thrombin, incubation with the specific progestins exerted only minimal effects. CONCLUSIONS: These results reveal that thrombin exerts striking effects on HESC ECM composition. Previously, we showed that at the maternal-fetal interface, DCs are the highest expressors of thrombin generating TF. Thus, thrombin regulated ECM expression may mediate decidual matrix remodeling and affect decidual trophoblast invasion and/ or play a role in post-menstrual repair of the endometrium. (LD) have been identified in the ovary and may serve as reservoirs of cholesterol for estradiol (E2) production during folliculogenesis. Perilipin 2 (Plin2), a LD-associated protein that moderates cellular lipid metabolism and storage, is reported to be expressed in mouse granulosa cells (GC) and oocytes. Our objectives were to evaluate the utilization of LDs in the follicle, E2 levels, and alternate Plin presence in Plin2-null mice during induced folliculogenesis.

C57Bl6 (WT) and Plin2-null mice received 5 IU PMS at 23 d of age followed by 5 IU hCG 46-48 h later. Mice were euthanized at 48 h p PMS or 12 h p hCG; serum and ovaries were collected. Frozen ovaries were sectioned and stained with BODIPY 493/503 and Hoescht for LDs and nuclei and imaged by laser confocal microscopy. LDs were quantified by area of BODIPY staining normalized to area of nuclear staining within the GC and theca (TC) of antral follicles using Slidebook 5.5; mean normalized BODIPY area was calculated for each animal. Serum E2 was determined by ELISA. Values were compared by Mann-Whitney; p<0.05 was significant. Plins1-5 were imaged by IF in fixed ovaries.

The amount of intracellular LD in antral follicles and serum E2 does not differ between WT and Plin2-null mice undergoing induced folliculogenesis. In antral follicles, Plin1 is present in TC, Plin2 is present in GC and TC (in WT), Plin3 is present in GC. CONCLUSIONS: Plin2 loss does not impair the ability to store or utilize intracellular lipid in GC or TC of antral follicles or the ability to produce E2 in mice. Plin3 may compensate for Plin2 loss.

Sugino, Isao Tamura. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Yamaguchi University Graduate School of Medicine, Ube, Japan. INTRODUCTION: IGFBP-1 and prolactin (PRL) are expressed in ESC undergoing decidualization. Manganese superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD), an anti-oxidant enzyme, is expressed in ESC, and its expression increases with decidualization. C/EBP b is an important transcriptional factor that regulates the expression of a number of decidualization-related genes. We investigated the molecular mechanism by which C/EBP b regulates the expression of IGFBP-1, PRL and Mn-SOD in ESC undergoing decidualization.
back_matter.section: Induction of IGFBP-1, PRL and Mn-SOD by cAMP Is Associated with Histone Acetylation Status of the C/EBP b Binding Site of Their Promoters in Human Endometrial Stromal Cells (ESC). Norihiro

back_matter.text: (1)ESC were incubated with dibutyryl-cAMP for 4 days to induce decidualization. To investigate the role of C/EBP b, ESC were transfected with C/EBP b siRNA.(2)The C/EBP b binding to the promoter regions was examined by ChIP assay. (3)The status of acetylation of histone-H3 lysine-27 (H3K27ac) and trimethylation of lysine-4 (H3K4me3), which are active chromatin markers, and trimethylation of lysine-27 (H3K27me3), which is a repressive chromatin marker were examined in the C/EBP b binding sites of the promoter or enhancer regions by ChIP assay. The effect of C/EBP b knockdown on the H3K27ac status of the C/EBP b binding sites was examined. RESULTS: (1) cAMP increased mRNA expressions of IGFBP-1, PRL and Mn-SOD, and the stimulatory effects of cAMP were inhibited by C/ EBP b knockdown. Basal Mn-SOD expression in non-decidualized ESC was also decreased by C/EBP b knockdown.(2) cAMP increased the C/ EBP b binding to the promoter or enhancer regions. In non-decidualized ESC, the C/EBP b binding activities in the Mn-SOD enhancer region were higher than those in the IGFBP-1 and PRL promoter region.(3)In non-decidualized ESC, the Mn-SOD enhancer region showed the higher levels of H3K27ac and H3K4me3 and lower levels H3K27me3 than those in IGFBP-1 and PRL promoter region. The H3K27ac level of the IGFBP-1 and PRL promoter regions was increased by cAMP and this effect was abolished by C/EBP b knockdown.CONCLUSIONS: IGFBP-1, PRL and Mn-SOD expressions were upregulated by cAMP through the recruitment of C/EBP b to the binding sites of the promoters. High H3K27ac levels of the C/EBP b binding site of the Mn-SOD enhancer in the absence of cAMP make the promoter accessible to C/EBP b to keep basal Mn-SOD expression. On the other hand, IGFBP-1 and PRL expression is induced by cAMP through the recruitment of C/EBP b to its binding site of the promoters and the concomitant induction of H3K27ac at the binding site.

VEGFR-1 Blockade Disrupts Peri-Implantation Decidual Macrophage Recruitment and Angiogenesis in Mice. Chantae S Sullivan-Pyke, Ralf C Zimmerman, Mark V Sauer, Jan K Kitajewski, Carrie J Shawber, Nataki C Douglas. Division of Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility, Columbia University, USA. INTRODUCTION: Macrophages in the uterus are implicated in mediating the maternal immune response, secretion of cytokines and in promoting angiogenesis. Our goal was to characterize expression of VEGFR-1 on macrophages and endothelial cells of the peri-implantation uterus and determine if VEGFR-1 function is required for macrophage recruitment, decidual angiogenesis, and/or the establishment and maintenance of pregnancy. METHODS: VEGFR-1 expression on CD31 + endothelial cells (EC) and F4/80 + macrophages in the peri-implantation uterus was characterized with immunohistochemistry. Intraperitoneal injections of VEGFR-1 blocking antibody (AF471, R&D Systems) were administered every 3 days to adult CD1 female mice. After 6 doses, females were mated and a final dose of AF471 was given by embryonic day (E) 3.5. Macrophages and EC were quantified at E7.5. Pregnancy was analyzed at E7.5 and E10.5. RESULTS: Macrophages are observed throughout the stroma and are abundant adjacent to the lumen and glands prior to implantation. VEGFR-1 is not expressed on macrophages, but is expressed on adjacent stromal EC (Fig. 1A) . EC are abundant in the peri-implantation uterus and VEGFR-1 is expressed on EC in the primary decidual zone at E6.5 (Fig. 1B, D) .Macrophages are scattered throughout the decidua and are found adjacent to cells expressing VEGFR-1 (Fig. 1C) .

Mitochondria from each cell type or tissue typed analyzed had a distinct proteomic profile. Unique banding patterns between fibroblasts, eggs, liver, and skeletal muscle were as follows: fibroblasts had 19 prominent bands, 3 <35 kDa, 3 in 35-50 kDa range, 4 in 50-75 kDa range, 3 in 75-100 kDa range, and 6 >100 kDa; eggs had 21 prominent bands, 4 <35 kDa , 3 in 35-50 kDa range, 3 in 50-75 kDa range, 1 in 80 kDa range, 3 in 100-150 kDa range, and 7 >150 kDa; liver had 9 prominent bands, including 2 in 30-35 kDa range, 5 in 50-75 kDa range, 1 in 130 kDa range, and 1 in 150 kDa range; and, skeletal muscle had 10 prominent bands, 2 in 30-35 kDa range, 3 in 50-75 kDa range, 1 in 80 kDa range, 1 in 100 kDa range, 3 >150 kDa. Protein bands unique to eggs are currently being processed for sequence analysis. CONCLUSIONS: Mitochondria from distinct cell lineages have a cellspecific mitochondrial proteomic map. Elucidation of this map should provide important insights into the nuclear-mitochondrial communication networks that control critical cellular processes in oocytes, including fertilization capacity and embryonic developmental potential (Support: NIH R37-AG012279).

Characterisation Recently MSC have been identified in the regenerative endometrial lining of the uterus and specific markers (W5C5/ SUSD2) for their prospective isolation identified. Postmenopausal endometrium is atrophic but regenerates with systemic estrogen treatment and has even lead to a successful IVF pregnancy in a 64 year old woman.The aim of this study was to determine whether postmenopausal endometrium contains a population of endometrial MSC (eMSC) that might be responsible for its regenerative capacity which could be exploited for future clinical applications. We hypothesized that eMSC are present in postmenopausal endometrium at similar frequency as in premenopausal endometrium.

Single-cell suspensions of endometrial stromal cells were obtained from hysterectomy tissues of 17 premenopausal (pre-MP), 19 postmenopausal (post-MP) and 15 postmenopausal women enrolled into a phase IV clinical trial of estrogen replacement therapy (2mg oral estradiol valerate daily) (post-MP+E 2 ) for 8 weeks. The proliferative potential and differentiation W5C5+ cells were assessed by colony forming unit CFU assays and differentiation-induction media culture. EMSC surface markers were determined using flow cytometry. RESULTS: In post-MP+E 2 Passage 1 (P1) stromal cultures, 3.7±1.8% (n=7) of the cells were W5C5+ cells and 7.7±6.3% (n=8) in post-MP cultures (p=0.69). The cloning efficiency for post-MP+E 2 W5C5+ P1 cells was 3.41±2.71% (n=6), and comparable to post-MP W5C5+ cells (3.73±1.19%; n=8) but statistically lower than P1 Pre-MP cells (p>0.05) (n=6). W5C5, CD140b, CD146, CD29, CD44, CD73, CD105 surface markers were present in both PostMP groups. PostMP W5C5+ cells differentiated into chondrocytes, adipocytes, myocytes and osteocytes, but to a lesser degree than PreMP W5C5+ cells. CONCLUSIONS: Postmenopausal endometria possess eMSC at similar frequency and potency irrespective of whether or not it is regenerated with estrogen. Human endometrium is a promising source of MSC independent of a woman's age or menopausal status.

Viability. Asli Uyar, Ozlem Guzeloglu-Kayisli, Emre Seli. Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Several cumulus cell transcripts have been identified as potential non-invasive biomarkers of human embryo development and implantation. Embryonic poly(A) binding protein (EPAB) is expressed exclusively in Xenopus, mouse, and human oocytes and early embryos, and is required for translational activation of maternally-derived transcripts and oocyte maturation. Importantly, although EPAB is not expressed in cumulus cells, cumulus expansion and ovulation are also impaired in Epab -/mice. We therefore asked whether the oocyte-specific EPAB is required for the optimal expression of cumulus cell biomarkers of embryo viability. METHODS: Epab knockout mice (Epab -/-) were generated by targeted deletion of Epab exon 2. Cumulus cells were collected from Epab -/and Epab +/+ mice 4 hours after hCG injection and three pooled samples were generated for each group. Microarrays were performed for each of the six samples using Affymetrix GeneChip Mouse Gene 1.0 ST Array platform. Probe level expression values were extracted and background adjustment, inter-array quantile normalization and probe set summarization were performed according to the Robust Multi-Chip Average algorithm. Genes that have been previously associated with human embryo viability and in vitro fertilization (IVF) outcome have been identified by analysis of previously published microarray data. RESULTS: 663 genes were up-regulated and 1205 genes were downregulated in Epab -/mice. The expression levels of 47 target genes that were previously identified as potential biomarkers of human embryo viability were cross-analyzed in Epab-driven mouse cumulus microarrays. Among those, 13 were found to be differentially expressed in Epab -/mice, and confirmed by qRT-PCR. These transcripts were previously shown to be associated with oocyte maturation (HAS2, PTGS2), fertilization (HAS2, GREM1, PTGS2, PTX3), early cleavage (HSPB1, TNFAIP6, CCND2), blastocyst development (PTGS2, SDC4), pregnancy (HIST1H4C, CAMK1D, SDC4), and live birth (PTGS2, CAMK1D). CONCLUSIONS: Cumulus cell transcripts identified as biomarkers of human oocyte and embryo viability demonstrated altered expression in Epab-deficient female mice, where diverse regulations remain to be further investigated. HLA-G expressed on trophoblast cells favours protolerogenic interactions with maternal leucocytes. We recently described that also maternal HLA-G + T lymphocytes and CD14 + CD16 + monocytes express HLA-G in the early decidua of physiological pregnancy. The aim of the present study was to investigate their role in first trimester spontaneous miscarriage. METHODS: Decidual tissue was obtained from 27 women affected by first trimester spontaneous miscarriage, and processed within 2 hours after collection. Leucocytes were separated by density gradient centrifugation and stained with the following human monoclonal antibodies: CD45, CD4, CD8, CD14, CD16, CD56, CD1c, BDCA-1, CD83, DC-SIGN, CD11c, HLA-G, ILT4. Samples were analyzed by flow cytometry. Results were compared with those obtained from n=10 patients undergoing elective termination of pregnancy. RESULTS: Compared to normally progressing pregnancies, the decidua of spontaneous abortions included a higher proportion of HLA-G + CD8 + T cells (13.94 ± 2.5% vs 5.90 ± 1.4%, p<0.05) and the MFI of both HLA-G and its ligand ILT-4 were increased on CD14 + CD16 + monocytes (1692 ± 188 vs 882 ± 129, p<0.001 and 1672 ± 176 vs 528 ± 58, p<0.001 respectively). Women with a pathological obstetric history (one previous abortion) showed both reduced HLA-G and ILT4 expression on CD14 + CD16 + monocytes (1110 ± 326 vs 1938 ± 206, p<0.05, and 924 ± 361 vs 1960 ± 660 respectively, p<0.001) . No correlation between HLA-G expression and fetal aneuploidy was observed. CONCLUSIONS: Maternal CD8 + T lymphocytes and CD14 + CD16 + monocytes over-express the regulatory molecule HLA-G during spontaneous first-trimester miscarriage, irrespective of fetal chromosomal content. These data hint for HLA-G up-regulation as a response to the onset of a pathological environment at the fetal-maternal interface. A pathological obstetric history was related to reduced expression of HLA-G + in the decidua, with possible implications for exogenous modulation of HLA-G expression in the treatment of early reproductive failures. The parallel ongoing analysis of specific HLA-G haplotypes will be correlated with the expression of decidual HLA-G + cells. There is a lack of targeted therapies. Incretin hormone glucagon like peptide-1(GLP-1) is useful in glucose homeostasis in Type 2 diabetes mellitus and also on cardiac function. GLP-1 levels are low in the later phase of OGTT in PCOS. Hence we hypothesized that a GLP-1 agonist would improve both cardiovascular and metabolic phenotypes in PCOS. To test this hypothesis we used an established rat model of PCOS. METHODS: A 7.5 mg (90 day release) dihydrotestosterone (DHT) pellet was implanted in 4 week old rats (n=8). Studies also were conducted on littermate matched controls with no DHT implant (n=6). Vaginal cytology was performed. Rats were weighed weekly and OGTT (n=4 per group) at 12 weeks and 24 weeks done. Radiotelemeters were inserted at 12 weeks. A subgroup of the rats (n=4) received a 0.2 mg/kg dose ofliraglutide (GLP-1 R agonist). Cardiac echo were conducted. RESULTS: The DHT treated rats had irregular cycles compared to control rats. There was a significant increase in weight in the DHT treated group at 16 weeks (273.25 grams+/-9 vs 245.25 grams +/-5.3; p-value= 0.02). This weight increase was prevented by liraglutide treatment in the DHT group (264 g +/-10) (compared to control p>0.05).The mean arterial pressures (103 mmHg liraglutide: 101 mmHg DHT vs 104 mmHg control) between the groups were not statistically significant. There was improvement in glucose excursion during OGTT in the liraglutide treated DHT rats (30 min 103 mg/dl +/-10 vs 134 mg/dl +/-11 p-value 0.04, 120 minutes 69 mg/dl +/-5 vs 101 mg/dl +/-9; p-value 0.02 post glucose load). There was increase in left ventricular internal diameter in diastole in the DHT treated rats over control (7.96 +/-vs 6.74+/-p-value 0.04), which was not reversed by Liraglutide. CONCLUSIONS: DHT induced PCOS rats were significantly heavier then control rats and this was prevented in the liraglutide treated DHT group. Liraglutide also improved glucose tolerance. However we were unable to replicate the changes in blood pressure reported by others using the DHT model, so were unable to establish a cardiovascular protective effect of GLP-1 agonism in experimental PCOS. We did see cardiac changes in the DHT model of PCOS that were not reversed by Liraglutide.
back_matter.section: S-240 Embryonic Poly(A) Binding Protein (EPAB) Is Required for Expression of Cumulus Cell Markers of Oocyte and Embryo

back_matter.text: Oocytes Generated during Adulthood Contribute to Natural Fertility in Mice. Ning Wang, 1 Chonthicha Satirapod, 1 Yasuyo Ohguchi, 1 Jonathan L Tilly. To confirm fidelity of the reporter, we also evaluated transgenic mice engineered to express green fluorescent protein (GFP) under control of the Stra8 promoter (pStra8-Gfp mice). Ovaries were collected from adult (2-3 months of age) pStra8-Gfp mice, and subjected to FACS for purification of GFP-positive cells. Adult female Stra8-R26R mice were treated with Dox for 21 days, housed with wild-type male mice in mating trials, and all offspring generated were assessed for YFP expression. RESULTS: GFP-positive cells purified from ovaries of pStra8-Gfp mice expressed primitive germline markers and endogenous Stra8, but no oocyte markers, confirming specificity of the promoter. Ovaries collected from adult female Stra8-R26R mice after 21 days of Dox induction possessed a 'chimeric' pool of follicles composed of both YFP-positive and YFP-negative oocytes enclosed in resting and growing CONCLUSIONS: Myeloid cells may contribute to maternal immune alterations during early pregnancy and placental development. Reductions in the myeloid population in allogeneic pregnancies suggest that a "foreign" fetus may trigger immunosuppressive cascades to support fetal tolerance. Thus, understanding myeloid cell maturation and differentiation in blood and the placenta may help elucidate the mechanism underlying pregnancy disorders, such as preeclampsia and preterm birth.
